{"uri": "2024-06-394355132", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:45:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:45:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:44:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://globalnation.inquirer.net/240064/diplomats-say-at-least-550-pilgrims-died-during-hajj-mostly-egyptians", "title": "Diplomats say at least 550 pilgrims died during hajj", "body": "RIYADH -- Diplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the grueling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighborhood of Mecca.\n\nREAD: Hajj pilgrimage ends amid deadly Saudi heat spike\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nREAD: Hajj pilgrims 'stone the devil' as Muslims mark Eid al-Adha\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nHeat stress\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said.", "source": {"uri": "globalnation.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Inquirer"}, "authors": [{"uri": While all of them died due to heat, one died due to crowd crush.\n\nDiplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, {"uri": "2024-06-393906565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:05:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:05:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T19:24:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/international-news/20240618-diplomats-say-at-least-550-pilgrims-died-during-hajj-mostly-egyptians", "title": "Diplomats say at least 550 pilgrims died during hajj, mostly Egyptians", "body": "Riyadh (AFP) - Diplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nHeat stress\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said.", "source": {"uri": "rfi.fr", "dataType": "news", hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\n- Heat stress -\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\n- Unregistered pilgrims Heat: Diplomats", "body": "At least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nJerusalem:\n\nDiplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\n- Unregistered pilgrims -\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death count was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said.\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "ndtv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://e.vnexpress.net/news/world/diplomats-say-at-least-550-pilgrims-died-during-hajj-mostly-egyptians-4760007.html", "title": "Diplomats say at least 550 pilgrims died during hajj, mostly Egyptians - VnExpress International", "body": "At least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighborhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nHeat stress\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials die during hajj in scorching temperatures reaching over 50C", "body": "At least 550 pilgrims have died during the hajj, diplomats say, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nThe hajj, the pilgrimage to the holy city of Mecca in Saudi Arabia, is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats co-ordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4C each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8C at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nHeat stress\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access airconditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The {"uri": "8184811830", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:03:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:03:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:02:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/hajj-mecca-plgrim-deaths-6413644-Jun2024/", "title": "Hundreds of people have died so far on annual pilgrimage to Mecca", "body": "Studies have shown that the pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change.\n\nDIPLOMATS HAVE SAID at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\", except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on yesterday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nHeat stress\n\nEarlier yesterday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP yesterday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said.", "source": "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.terradaily.com/reports/Diplomats_say_at_least_550_pilgrims_died_during_hajj_mostly_Egyptians_999.html", "title": "Diplomats say at least 550 pilgrims died during hajj, mostly Egyptians", "body": "At least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\n- Heat stress -\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\n- Unregistered pilgrims -\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said.\n\nJordan, Tunisia report additional hajj heat deaths\n\nRiyadh (AFP) June 18, 2024 - The death toll from extreme heat during the hajj pilgrimage rose Tuesday, with Jordan and Tunisia reporting more fatalities after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca.\n\nAs of Tuesday evening, the total number of reported deaths this year stands at 235, compared with more than 240 last year. Most countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nThe annual pilgrimage, one of the world's largest religious gatherings, unfolded again during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nJordan, which had earlier reported 14 deaths from sunstroke, on Tuesday said 41 permits to bury deceased pilgrims in Mecca had been issued.\n\nIt said officials were \"monitoring the procedures for burying Jordanian pilgrims who passed away during the hajj after suffering from heatstroke as a result of the extreme heat wave\".\n\nThe official Petra news agency also said an untold number of Jordanian pilgrims were missing and that authorities were trying to locate them and bring them home.\n\nTunisia's foreign ministry said on Tuesday that 35 hajj pilgrims died amid a \"sharp rise in temperatures\" in Saudi Arabia.\n\nNeither the Jordanian nor Tunisian statements said precisely how many deaths could be attributed to heat as opposed to other ailments.\n\nEgypt's foreign ministry said on Tuesday that Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a statement from the ministry said \"a certain number of deaths\" occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nEarlier this week Indonesia reported 132 deaths among hajj pilgrims, three of which were attributed to heatstroke, and heat was cited as \"one of the main reasons\" for 13 deaths among pilgrims from Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region.\n\nSenegal and Iran have also reported deaths without listing a cause.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4C each decade.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.", "source": {"uri": "8185139021", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:43:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:43:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:42:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13546541/At-550-Hajj-pilgrims-die-scorching-50C-heat-Mecca.html", "title": "At least 550 during Hajj pilgrims die in scorching 50C heat in Mecca", "body": "Diplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses revealed. 'All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat' except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman. The new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577. The diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once. The pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade. Temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj. While a ministry statement said 'a certain number of deaths' had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them. Saudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians. AFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool. Saudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime. Some pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times. Around 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas. This places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route. One of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was 'absolutely' boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n'Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,' said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission. 'The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.' They died 'from the heat because most people had no place' to take shelter. Earlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal. Most countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related. Saudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had 'been successfully carried out', preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported. Health officials 'provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,' SPA said.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, the two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a most of them Indonesians.\n\nSun exposure\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by {"uri": "8185720835", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:25:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:25:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T17:24:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/diplomats-say-at-least-550-pilgrims-died-during-hajj-mostly-egyptians/article_81bc8576-0bf9-513b-9c9b-d523d8bb90b0.html", "title": "Diplomats say at least 550 pilgrims died during hajj, mostly Egyptians", "body": "A Muslim pilgrim prays at dawn on Saudi Arabia's Mount Arafat during the climax of the hajj\n\nDiplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\n- Heat stress -\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nMore from this section Rates of Problem Marijuana Use Are Rising Among Seniors NYPD: 3 men shot in Williamsbridge, suspect at large Disability Rights Groups Demand Standard Accessibility Rules for Air Travel - TaiwanPlus News\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\n- Unregistered pilgrims -\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said.\n\nbur/jsa", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, During Hajj, Mostly Egyptians", "body": "Diplomats said on Tuesday that at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, the two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj without securing official hajj visas in order to save money, a more dangerous undertaking because these off-the-books pilgrims cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's title includes \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\" in the cities of Mecca and Medina.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighborhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology center said.\n\nHeat stress\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said.", "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Manila figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577.\n\nDiplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the month\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre {"uri": "8184267805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:59:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:59:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T20:58:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jun/18/hundreds-of-hajj-pilgrims-die-in-mecca-from-heat-related-illness", "title": "More than 550 hajj pilgrims die in Mecca as temperatures exceed 50C", "body": "At least 320 of the dead are from Egypt and Saudi officials report treating more than 2,000 people for heat stress\n\nAt least 550 pilgrims have died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, the two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them [the Egyptians] died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding that the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians have died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means to must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4C (0.72F) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8Cat the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice-cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAbout 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj without securing official hajj visas in order to save money, a more dangerous undertaking because these off-the-books pilgrims cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca before the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's title includes \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\" in the cities of Mecca and Medina.\n\nSaudi health minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nA virtual hospital \"provided virtual consultations to {"uri": "8185554853", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:19:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:19:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:18:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2024/06/19/hajj-death-toll-reaches-550-with-majority-being-egyptians/", "title": "Hajj death toll reaches 550, with majority being Egyptians", "body": "RIYADH: Diplomats from various countries have reported that at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, highlighting the grueling nature of the pilgrimage, which unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of the deceased were Egyptians, most of whom succumbed to heat-related illnesses, according to two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one diplomat said. The total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighborhood of Mecca.\n\nAdditionally, the diplomats reported that at least 60 Jordanians died, an increase from the official tally of 41 provided earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThese new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577. The diplomats confirmed that the total number of deaths at the morgue in Al-Muaisem was 550.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj. While a ministry statement mentioned \"a certain number of deaths,\" it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nLast year, at least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries, most of them Indonesians.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam, and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once. The pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that indicated temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising by 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, according to the Saudi national meteorology center.\n\nReporters in Mina, outside Mecca, observed pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them stay cool.\n\nSaudi officials advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water, and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day. However, many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat, which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims participated in the hajj this year, with 1.6 million of them coming from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj without securing official hajj visas to save money, a more dangerous undertaking because these off-the-books pilgrims cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route. One diplomat on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries reporting deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran, and Senegal. Most countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's title includes \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\" in the cities of Mecca and Medina.", "source": {"uri": "pakistantoday.com.pk", "dataType": "news", "title": "pakistantoday.com.pk"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185992384", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:55:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:55:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:51:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2472489/hundreds-of-pilgrims-die-as-intense-heat-grips-makkah", "title": "Hundreds of pilgrims die as intense heat grips Makkah", "body": "Diplomats on Tuesday said at least 577 pilgrims died amid scorching temperatures during the annual Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman. The new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times. Around 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the Hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's Hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the Hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal. Most countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the Hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said. {"uri": "8185104048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:22:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:22:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:19:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.dailymirror.lk/breaking-news/More-than-550-Hajj-pilgrims-die-in-intense-heat/108-285249", "title": "More than 550 Hajj pilgrims die in intense heat", "body": "June 19 (The Guardian) - At least 550 pilgrims have died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, the two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries.\n\n\"All of them died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding that the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians have died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means to must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate breakdown, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4C (0.72F) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8Cat the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice-cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAbout 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj without securing official hajj visas in order to save money, a more dangerous undertaking because these off-the-books pilgrims cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca before the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's title includes \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\" in the cities of Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe Saudi health minister, Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel, said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nA virtual hospital \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases.", "source": {"uri":
