{"uri": "2024-06-395349659", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:34:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:34:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T03:34:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://globalnation.inquirer.net/240115/loved-ones-search-for-missing-as-hajj-death-toll-passes-900", "title": "Loved ones search for missing as hajj death toll passes 900", "body": "An aerial view shows Mecca's Grand Mosque with the Kaaba, Islam's holiest site in the centre on June 17, 2024, during the annual hajj pilgrimage. Saudi Arabia on June 17 warned of a temperature spike in Mecca as Muslim pilgrims wrapped up the hajj in searing conditions, with more than a dozen heat-related deaths confirmed. Agence France-Presse\n\nRIYADH -- Friends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, which this year fell during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nREAD: Diplomats say at least 550 pilgrims died during hajj, mostly Egyptians\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nThe diplomat later added that Egyptian officials in Saudi Arabia had received \"1,400 reports of missing pilgrims\", including the 600 dead.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nREAD: Hajj pilgrims 'stone the devil' as Muslims mark Eid al-Adha\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nSearing heat\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\n'No news'\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "globalnation.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Inquirer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8184861784", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:40:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:40:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:39:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://strangesounds.org/2024/06/more-than-550-hajj-pilgrims-die-in-mecca-as-temperatures-exceed-50c.html", "title": "More than 550 hajj pilgrims die in Mecca as temperatures exceed 50C - Strange Sounds", "body": "At least 320 of the dead are from Egypt and Saudi officials report treating more than 2,000 people for heat stress...\n\nAt least 550 pilgrims have died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, the two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them [the Egyptians] died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding that the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians have died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means to must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate breakdown, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4C (0.72F) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8Cat the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice-cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAbout 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj without securing official hajj visas in order to save money, a more dangerous undertaking because these off-the-books pilgrims cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca before the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's title includes \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\" in the cities of Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe Saudi health minister, Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel, said on Tuesday that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nA virtual hospital \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases\", SPA said. {"uri": "8187599257", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:20:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:20:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:19:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.breitbart.com/news/death-toll-tops-1000-after-hajj-marked-by-extreme-heat-afp-tally/", "title": "Hajj death toll tops 1,000 after extreme heat: AFP tally - Breitbart", "body": "The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said Thursday, more than half unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who died, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAround 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nA Saudi study published last month said temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims try to join the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable, because without official permits they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday of Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nEgyptian officials were visiting hospitals to obtain information and help Egyptian pilgrims get medical care, the foreign ministry said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"However, there are large numbers of Egyptian citizens who are not registered in hajj databases, which requires double the effort and a longer time to search for missing persons and find their relatives,\" it said.\n\nEgyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi has ordered that a \"crisis cell\" headed by the prime minister follow up on the deaths of the country's pilgrims.\n\nSisi stressed \"the need for immediate coordination with the Saudi authorities to facilitate receiving the bodies of the deceased and streamline the process,\" said a statement from his office.\n\nMore fatalities were also confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, its religious affairs ministry said, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases, authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and relatives have been searching for missing pilgrims, scouring hospitals and pleading online for news, fearing the worst.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, cleaning the bodies and putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who said his country was working to notify loved ones as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\nJordan's foreign ministry said on Thursday that Saudi authorities had granted 68 permits for Jordanian pilgrims to be buried in Mecca.\n\nSixteen Jordanians remain missing and 22 are in hospital, including seven who are in critical condition, the foreign ministry said in a statement.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has seen a number of disasters over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual killed up to 2,300 people.", "source": {"uri": "breitbart.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breitbart"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185377725", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:20:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:20:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:17:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-13546983/Loved-ones-search-missing-pilgrims-hajj-heat-deaths.html", "title": "Loved ones search for missing pilgrims after hajj heat deaths", "body": "About 1.8 million pilgrims joined this year's hajj\n\nFriends and family of missing hajj pilgrims searched hospitals and pleaded online for news on Wednesday, fearing the worst after hundreds died during the annual rites in Saudi Arabia.\n\nArab diplomats on Tuesday told AFP at least 550 pilgrims died this year, the majority due to heat-related illnesses after temperatures reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries. About 1.8 million people attended the pilgrimage.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool off after hours of outdoor prayers, Mohammed said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nHe is far from the only one desperate for information.\n\nA pilgrim prays at the Grand Mosque in Mecca\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe searchers include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\n- Searing heat -\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nTemperatures reached as high as 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nThe figure of 550 dead provided by diplomats on Tuesday came from the hospital morgue in Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, one of the biggest in the city.\n\nIt includes 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, said the Arab diplomats who briefed AFP on the figures, one of whom noted that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nThe hajj pilgrimage\n\nOn Wednesday an Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\n- 'No news' -\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8187579831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:03:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:03:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:01:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.citizen.co.za/news/news-world/death-toll-tops-1000-after-hajj-marked-by-extreme-heat-afp-tally/", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat - AFP tally | The Citizen", "body": "The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who passed away, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nWATCH: Pilgrims commence final rites of Hajj as Muslims celebrate Eid al-Adha\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\nALSO READ: LISTEN: Naledi Pandor's son talks about his first Hajj\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nASO READ: Iran slaps one-year prison term on Nobel winner Mohammadi - lawyer\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has been the scene of a number of stampedes and fires over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual in Mina, near Mecca, killed up to 2,300 people in the event's mostly deadly disaster.", "source": {"uri": "citizen.co.za", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Citizen"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8184557237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:03:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:03:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:02:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.ptcnews.tv/world-news/over-550-hajj-pilgrims-die-in-mecca-as-temperatures-soar-above-50-degrees-4392397", "title": "Over 550 Hajj pilgrims die in Mecca as temperatures soar above 50 degrees", "body": "PTC News Desk: According to diplomats on Tuesday, at least 550 pilgrims lost their lives while doing the hajj, highlighting the arduous nature of the journey that took place in sweltering heat this year.\n\nAccording to two Arab ambassadors coordinating their countries' responses, at least 323 Egyptians lost their lives, the most of them from heat-related ailments.\n\nOne of the diplomats stated, \"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat,\" with the exception of one who died from injuries he received in a small crowd crush. The overall number of deaths was derived from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighborhood of Mecca.\n\nThe ambassadors reported that at least 60 Jordanians also perished, surpassing the official count of 41 that Amman had earlier on Tuesday announced. An AFP count puts the number of deaths recorded by various countries up to 577 with the addition of these latest deaths.\n\nAccording to the diplomats, there were 550 people overall at the largest morgue in Mecca, located at Al-Muaisem. One of the five pillars of Islam is the hajj, which every Muslim who has the means to do so must perform at least once.\n\nA Saudi report released last month claimed that the trip is becoming more and more impacted by climate change, with temperatures in the pilgrimage area rising by 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) every ten years.\n\nThe Saudi National Meteorological Center reported that on Monday, temperatures in the Grand Mosque in Mecca reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit).\n\nHeat stress\n\nEgypt's foreign ministry had earlier on Tuesday said that Cairo was working with Saudi authorities to look for Egyptians who had vanished during the hajj.\n\nA statement from the ministry stated that \"a certain number of deaths\" had happened, although it did not say if Egyptians were among them. The Saudi authorities have stated that they are treating over 2,000 pilgrims who are experiencing heat exhaustion; however, they have not updated this number since Sunday and have not disclosed any information regarding fatalities.\n\nLast year, at least 240 pilgrims -- mostly from Indonesia -- were reported deceased by several nations. Reporters from AFP observed pilgrims in Mina, outside of Mecca, on Monday dousing themselves in water bottles while volunteers provided them with chilled beverages and chocolate ice cream that melted quickly to keep cool.\n\nPilgrims were instructed by Saudi officials to carry umbrellas, stay hydrated, and stay out of the sun during the hottest parts of the day. But spending hours outside during the day is a requirement of several hajj rites, including as the prayers on Mount Arafat that were performed on Saturday.\n\nSome pilgrims reported witnessing lifeless bodies at the side of the road and occasionally feeling overrun by medical services. Saudi authorities estimate that approximately 1.8 million pilgrims performed the hajj this year, with 1.6 million coming from outside the country.\n\nUnregistered Travellers\n\nTens of thousands of pilgrims seek to complete the hajj through unofficial means every year because they are unable to pay the very expensive processes required to obtain official hajj visas.\n\nDue to their inability to use the air-conditioned facilities that Saudi authorities have supplied along the hajj route, these unreported pilgrims are put in danger.\n\nA diplomat who talked with AFP on Tuesday claimed that a significant number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims had \"absolutely\" increased the number of Egyptian deaths.\n\nAn Egyptian official overseeing the nation's hajj mission claimed that \"irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services.\"\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\" \"The majority of people had no place\" to seek refuge, so many died from the heat.\n\nPrior to the hajj, hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims were removed from Mecca, according to Saudi officials earlier this month. Senegal, Indonesia, and Iran are among the other nations that have reported hajj-related fatalities this year.\n\nThe majority of nations have not disclosed the number of deaths linked to heat. According to the official Saudi Press Agency, Saudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel declared on Tuesday that health preparations for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out,\" averting significant illness outbreaks and other hazards to public health.\n\nHealth professionals \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" according to SPA.", "source": {"uri": "ptcnews.tv", "dataType": "news", "title": "PTC News"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8184549130", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "02:52:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T02:52:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T02:51:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/heatwave-horror-over-550-pilgrims-die-during-hajj-majority-egyptians/articleshow/111099230.cms", "title": "Heatwave horror: Over 550 pilgrims die during Hajj, majority Egyptians", "body": "Diplomats reported that at least 550 pilgrims died during this year's hajj, with high temperatures exacerbating the challenging pilgrimage conditions. Two Arab diplomats noted that 323 of the deceased were Egyptians, primarily due to heat-related illnesses, except for one casualty from a minor crowd crush. Diplomats on Tuesday reported that a minimum of 550 pilgrims died during this year's hajj, highlighting the challenging conditions of the pilgrimage, exacerbated by high temperatures. Two Arab diplomats overseeing their nations' responses told AFP that at least 323 of the deceased were Egyptians, with the majority succumbing to heat-related illnesses.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nDiplomats reported that the number of Jordanian fatalities had risen to at least 60, an increase from the earlier official count of 41 provided by Amman on Tuesday.\n\nAccording to an AFP count, the latest deaths have pushed the overall reported toll from multiple countries to 577.\n\nThey added that the morgue at Al-Muaisem in Mecca, one of the largest in the area, had a total of 550 bodies.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nWith inputs from AFP", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8187082872", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:09:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:09:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:08:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/world/2024/0620/1455709-saudi-arabia/", "title": "Up to 300 Irish on hajj as hundreds die from extreme heat", "body": "Up to 300 people from Ireland have performed the hajj pilgrimage in which hundreds of pilgrims have died due to extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe figures were provided by Chairperson of the Irish Muslim Council, who warned people not to undertake the pilgrimage without registering because unregistered pilgrims are not permitted to access air-conditioned spaces.\n\nShaykh Dr Umar Al-Qadri told RT\u00c9's News at One that so far none of the Irish pilgrims have been affected by the heat.\n\nHe said the hajj pilgrimage is a very physically demanding.\n\n\"You'll have to travel in four to five days a distance of about 25km on foot and considering the heatwave and climate change and especially temperatures that are close to 50C, it is you know understandable that people have lost their lives, especially elderly people,\" he said.\n\nDr Al-Qadri, who has made the hajj pilgrimage three times, advised people to do it when they are young.\n\n\"Do not delay it, you know because by delaying will mean that you will be less able to physically conduct all those actions, and if you try, you can actually hurt yourself.\n\n\"You can injure yourself, and unfortunately, the heatwave that is now going on and climate change is affecting us all,\" he said.\n\nDeath toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat - AFP tally\n\nIt comes as an AFP tally of deaths reported that more than 1,000 pilgrims have died on this year's hajj.\n\nMore than half of them were unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who died, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nIn total, around ten countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims - with the means - must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8C this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4C each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often-expensive official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nBurials begin\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nThey scoured hospitals yesterday and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\n'Extreme danger'\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has been the scene of several stampedes and fires over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual in Mina, near Mecca, killed up to 2,300 people in the event's mostly deadly disaster.", "source": {"uri": "rte.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "RTE.ie"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8187491056", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:47:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:47:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:47:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jun/20/more-than-1000-hajj-pilgrims-die-in-mecca-as-temperatures-hit-high-of-51c", "title": "More than 1,000 hajj pilgrims die in Mecca as temperatures hit high of 51C", "body": "Saudi authorities reported clearing unregistered pilgrims but many still took part with no access to cooler spaces\n\nThe death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, with more than half of the victims unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported on Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who died, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAbout 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nA Saudi study published last month said temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims try to join the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday. This group was more vulnerable, because without official permits they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday of Saturday's daylong outdoor prayers that marked the climax of the hajj.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other problems.\n\nEgyptian officials were visiting hospitals to obtain information and help Egyptian pilgrims receive medical care, the foreign ministry said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"However, there are large numbers of Egyptian citizens who are not registered in hajj databases, which requires double the effort and a longer time to search for missing persons and find their relatives,\" it said.\n\nEgypt's president Abdel Fattah El-Sisi has ordered that a \"crisis cell\" headed by the prime minister follow up on the deaths of the country's pilgrims.\n\nSisi stressed \"the need for immediate coordination with the Saudi authorities to facilitate receiving the bodies of the deceased and streamline the process,\" said a statement from his office.\n\nMore fatalities were also confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of about 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat told AFP. \"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had about 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, its religious affairs ministry said, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases, authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and relatives have been searching for missing pilgrims, scouring hospitals and pleading online for news, fearing the worst.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, cleaning the bodies and putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who said his country was working to notify loved ones as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt, which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year, various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of the {"uri": "8187040638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:43:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:43:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:42:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.thedailystar.net/news/world/middle-east/news/death-toll-tops-1000-after-hajj-marked-extreme-heat-3637631", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat", "body": "Muslim devotees walk around the Kaaba, Islam's holiest shrine, at the Grand Mosque in Saudi Arabia's holy city of Mecca on June 13, 2024, ahead of the annual Hajj pilgrimage.\n\nThe death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who passed away, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nBurials begin\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile, friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\nExtreme danger\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has been the scene of a number of stampedes and fires over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual in Mina, near Mecca, killed up to 2,300 people in the event's mostly deadly disaster.", "source": {"uri": "thedailystar.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Daily {"uri": "2024-06-393950557", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "21:11:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T21:11:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T20:28:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://howafrica.com/diplomats-say-at-least-550-pilgrims-died-during-hajj-mostly-egyptians/", "title": "Diplomats Say At Least 550 Pilgrims Died During Hajj, Mostly Egyptians", "body": "Diplomats claimed on Tuesday that at least 550 pilgrims perished during the hajj, highlighting the arduous nature of the trip, which took place in hot conditions this year.\n\nAccording to the two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses, at least 323 Egyptians perished, the most of them from heat-related ailments.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who got fatal injuries during a brief crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding that the entire figure came from the hospital morgue in Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighborhood.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians perished, according to the diplomats, up from Amman's official figure of 41 earlier on Tuesday.\n\nThe fresh deaths raise the total reported by numerous countries to 577, according to an AFP calculation.\n\nAccording to diplomats, the number at Al-Muaisem morgue, one of Mecca's largest, was 550.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said it was working with Saudi officials to locate Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile the ministry stated that \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not indicate if Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress, but have not updated the tally since Sunday and have not released any information on fatalities.\n\nLast year, numerous countries reported the deaths of at least 240 pilgrims, the majority of whom were Indonesians.\n\nSun exposure\n\nThe hajj is one of Islam's five pillars, and all Muslims who have the means must perform it at least once.\n\nClimate change is progressively affecting the pilgrimage, according to a Saudi research published last month, which found that temperatures in the area where rites are done were rising by 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) per decade.\n\nOn Monday, temperatures in Mecca's Grand Mosque reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit), according to the Saudi national meteorology centre.\n\nOn Monday, AFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, watched pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads while volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to keep them cool.\n\nSaudi officials had recommended pilgrims to bring umbrellas, drink plenty of water, and avoid the sun during the warmest hours of the day.\n\nHowever, several hajj rites, like Saturday's prayers on Mount Arafat, require spending hours outside during the day.\n\nSome pilgrims reported witnessing unmoving bodies by the wayside and ambulance personnel that appeared overburdened at times.\n\nAccording to Saudi authorities, over 1.8 million pilgrims performed the hajj this year, with 1.6 million coming from outside Saudi Arabia.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nEvery year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to undertake the hajj without obtaining official hajj visas in order to save money, which is a riskier endeavor because these off-the-books pilgrims cannot access air-conditioned facilities supplied by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the ambassadors who spoke with AFP on Tuesday stated that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" inflated by a huge number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials announced that they had evacuated hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries reporting deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran, and Senegal.\n\nThe majority of countries have not mentioned how many deaths were caused by high temperatures.\n\nHosting the hajj provides prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's title includes \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\" at Mecca and Medina.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel stated on Tuesday that health measures for the hajj were \"successfully carried out,\" preventing major illness outbreaks and other public health hazards, according to the official Saudi Press Agency.\n\nA virtual medical center \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" claimed the SPA.", "source": {"uri": "howafrica.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-06-394179393", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "04:24:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T04:24:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T04:22:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/over-550-hajj-pilgrims-die-in-mecca-amidst-scorching-52-degree-heat-saudi", "title": "Over 550 Hajj Pilgrims Die in Mecca Amidst Scorching 52-Degree Heat", "body": "Jerusalem: Over 550 pilgrims died during the Hajj, diplomats said on Tuesday, highlighting the grueling nature of the pilgrimage, which once again took place in scorching temperatures this year. At least 323 of the deceased were Egyptians, with the majority succumbing to heat-related illnesses, according to two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nThe diplomats also reported that at least 60 Jordanians had died, an increase from the official count of 41 provided earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThese additional deaths raise the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an international news agency tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe Hajj, one of the five pillars of Islam, is a mandatory pilgrimage for all Muslims who have the means to undertake it at least once in their lifetime.\n\nA Saudi study published last month indicates that the pilgrimage is increasingly impacted by climate change, with temperatures in the ritual areas rising by 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nOn Monday, the Saudi national meteorology center reported that temperatures at the Grand Mosque in Mecca reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit).\n\nHeat Stress\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry announced that Cairo was working closely with Saudi authorities to locate Egyptians who had gone missing during the Hajj.\n\nAlthough the ministry acknowledged \"a certain number of deaths,\" it did not specify whether any Egyptians were among the casualties.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating over 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress, but have not updated this figure since Sunday and have not released information on fatalities.\n\nLast year, various countries reported at least 240 pilgrim deaths, predominantly among Indonesians.\n\nJournalists in Mina, near Mecca, witnessed pilgrims pouring water over themselves while volunteers distributed cold beverages and quickly melting chocolate ice cream to help them stay cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink ample water, and avoid sun exposure during the hottest parts of the day. However, many Hajj rituals, including Saturday's prayers on Mount Arafat, require spending hours outdoors.\n\nSome pilgrims recounted seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and observed ambulance services appearing overwhelmed at times.\n\nAccording to Saudi authorities, approximately 1.8 million pilgrims participated in this year's Hajj, with 1.6 million coming from overseas.\n\nUnregistered Pilgrims\n\nEvery year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to participate in the Hajj through unofficial channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas. These unregistered pilgrims are exposed to heightened risks as they lack access to the air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the Hajj route.\n\nAccording to a diplomat, the death toll among Egyptians was significantly increased by a large number of unregistered pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the Hajj.\n\nOther countries, including Indonesia, Iran, and Senegal, have also reported deaths during this year's Hajj, but specific numbers related to heat-related fatalities have not been disclosed by most countries.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel stated on Tuesday that health plans for the Hajj were executed successfully, preventing significant outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, according to the official Saudi Press Agency.\n\nHealth officials provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, allowing for prompt intervention and reducing the potential for a surge in cases, SPA reported.", "source": {"uri": "republicworld.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Republic World"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187236046", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "14:47:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T14:47:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T14:46:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.terradaily.com/afp/240620140321.1ut6veqd.html", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat: AFP tally", "body": "The new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who passed away, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nEgyptian officials were visiting hospitals to obtain data on Egyptian pilgrims and help those still alive to get medical care, the foreign ministry said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"However, there are large numbers of Egyptian citizens who are not registered in hajj databases, which requires double the effort and a longer time to search for missing persons and find their relatives,\" the ministry said.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases, authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile, friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has been the scene of a number of stampedes and fires over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual in Mina, near Mecca, killed up to 2,300 people in the event's mostly deadly disaster.", "source": {"uri": "terradaily.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Terra Daily"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8187430455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:01:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:01:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:00:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2024/06/hajj-death-toll-tops-1000-after-extreme-heat-afp-tally", "title": "Hajj death toll tops 1,000 after extreme heat: AFP tally", "body": "A Turkish pilgrim pours cold water on her head to cool off in Saudi Arabia's holy city of Mecca - Abdel Ghani BASHIR\n\nThe death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said Thursday, more than half unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who died, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAround 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nA Saudi study published last month said temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims try to join the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable, because without official permits they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday of Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nEgyptian officials were visiting hospitals to obtain information and help Egyptian pilgrims get medical care, the foreign ministry said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"However, there are large numbers of Egyptian citizens who are not registered in hajj databases, which requires double the effort and a longer time to search for missing persons and find their relatives,\" it said.\n\nEgyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi has ordered that a \"crisis cell\" headed by the prime minister follow up on the deaths of the country's pilgrims.\n\nSisi stressed \"the need for immediate coordination with the Saudi authorities to facilitate receiving the bodies of the deceased and streamline the process,\" said a statement from his office.\n\n- Burials begin -\n\nMore fatalities were also confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, its religious affairs ministry said, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases, authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and relatives have been searching for missing pilgrims, scouring hospitals and pleading online for news, fearing the worst.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, cleaning the bodies and putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who said his country was working to notify loved ones as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\n- 'Extreme danger' -\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has seen a number of disasters over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual killed up to 2,300 people.", "source": {"uri": "al-monitor.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Al-Monitor"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajj", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "2024-06-396235585", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:33:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:33:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:20:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.fox41yakima.com/hajj-death-toll-tops-1000-after-extreme-heat-afp-tally/", "title": "Hajj death toll tops 1,000 after extreme heat: AFP tally", "body": "The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said Thursday, more than half unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who died, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAround 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nA Saudi study published last month said temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims try to join the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable, because without official permits they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday of Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nEgyptian officials were visiting hospitals to obtain information and help Egyptian pilgrims get medical care, the foreign ministry said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"However, there are large numbers of Egyptian citizens who are not registered in hajj databases, which requires double the effort and a longer time to search for missing persons and find their relatives,\" it said.\n\nEgyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi has ordered that a \"crisis cell\" headed by the prime minister follow up on the deaths of the country's pilgrims.\n\nSisi stressed \"the need for immediate coordination with the Saudi authorities to facilitate receiving the bodies of the deceased and streamline the process,\" said a statement from his office.\n\n- Burials begin -\n\nMore fatalities were also confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, its religious affairs ministry said, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases, authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and relatives have been searching for missing pilgrims, scouring hospitals and pleading online for news, fearing the worst.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, cleaning the bodies and putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who said his country was working to notify loved ones as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\n- 'Extreme danger' -\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has seen a number of disasters over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual killed up to 2,300 people.\n\nbur/srm\n\nFOX41 Yakima\u00a9FOX11 TriCities\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox41yakima.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 11 41 Tri Cities Yakima"}, "authors": [{"uri":
