hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said Thursday, more than half unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who died, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAround 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nA Saudi study published last month said temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims try to join the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable, because without official permits they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday of Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nEgyptian officials were visiting hospitals to obtain information and help Egyptian pilgrims get medical care, the foreign ministry said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"However, there are large numbers of Egyptian citizens who are not registered in hajj databases, which requires double the effort and a longer time to search for missing persons and find their relatives,\" it said.\n\nEgyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi has ordered that a \"crisis cell\" headed by the prime minister follow up on the deaths of the country's pilgrims.\n\nSisi stressed \"the need for immediate coordination with the Saudi authorities to facilitate receiving the bodies of the deceased and streamline the process,\" said a statement from his office.\n\n- Burials begin -\n\nMore fatalities were also confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, its religious affairs ministry said, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases, authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and relatives have been searching for missing pilgrims, scouring hospitals and pleading online for news, fearing the worst.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, cleaning the bodies and putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words {"uri": "2024-06-395832644", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:38:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:38:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:27:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/death-toll-tops-1000-after-hajj-marked-extreme-heat-afp-tally-1848791", "title": "Death Toll Tops 1,000 After Hajj Marked By Extreme Heat: AFP Tally", "body": "The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who passed away, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has been the scene of a number of stampedes and fires over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual in Mina, near Mecca, killed up to 2,300 people in the event's mostly deadly disaster.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business Times AU"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8186568426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "07:54:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T07:54:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T07:53:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/relatives-search-missing-saudi-arabia-062927779.html", "title": "Relatives search for missing in Saudi Arabia as hajj death toll tops 900", "body": "Loved ones search for missing pilgrims after hajj heat deaths\n\nFriends and family of missing hajj pilgrims searched hospitals and pleaded online for news on Wednesday, fearing the worst after hundreds died during the annual rites in Saudi Arabia.Arab diplomats on Tuesday told AFP at least 550 pilgrims died this year, the majority due to heat-related illnesses after temperatures reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city.The total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries. About 1.8 million people attended the pilgrimage.Mabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.Because she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool off after hours of outdoor prayers, Mohammed said.\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"He is far from the only one desperate for information.Facebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.The searchers include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"- Searing heat -The hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.Its timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.For the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.According to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.The figure of 550 dead provided by diplomats on Tuesday came from the hospital morgue in Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, one of the biggest in the city.It includes 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, said the Arab diplomats who briefed AFP on the figures, one of whom noted that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".Fatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.On Wednesday an Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.Saudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.Last year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.- 'No news' -Each year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.This has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he&nbsp;said.\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"Even pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.After praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.bur/th/dv", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News UK"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-06-394788389", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:54:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:54:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:56:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/international-news/20240619-loved-ones-search-for-missing-pilgrims-after-hajj-heat-deaths", "title": "Loved ones search for missing pilgrims after hajj heat deaths", "body": "Riyadh (Saudi Arabia) (AFP) - Friends and family of missing hajj pilgrims searched hospitals and pleaded online for news on Wednesday, fearing the worst after hundreds died during the annual rites in Saudi Arabia.\n\nArab diplomats on Tuesday told AFP at least 550 pilgrims died this year, the majority due to heat-related illnesses after temperatures reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries. About 1.8 million people attended the pilgrimage.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool off after hours of outdoor prayers, Mohammed said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nHe is far from the only one desperate for information.\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe searchers include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nSearing heat\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nThe figure of 550 dead provided by diplomats on Tuesday came from the hospital morgue in Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, one of the biggest in the city.\n\nIt includes 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, said the Arab diplomats who briefed AFP on the figures, one of whom noted that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nOn Wednesday an Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\n'No news'\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", {"uri": "8187003762", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:21:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:21:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:20:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/news/world/hajj-2024-death-toll-due-to-extreme-heat-tops-1000-11718884533591.html", "title": "Hajj 2024: Death toll due to extreme heat tops 1,000 | Today News", "body": "Hajj 2024: Around 10 countries reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who passed away, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has been the scene of a number of stampedes and fires over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual in Mina, near Mecca, killed up to 2,300 people in the event's mostly deadly disaster.", "source": {"uri": "livemint.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-06-394771084", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:38:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:38:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:00:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/loved-ones-search-missing-pilgrims-after-hajj-heat-deaths-1848763", "title": "Loved Ones Search For Missing Pilgrims After Hajj Heat Deaths", "body": "Friends and family of missing hajj pilgrims searched hospitals and pleaded online for news on Wednesday, fearing the worst after hundreds died during the annual rites in Saudi Arabia.\n\nArab diplomats on Tuesday told AFP at least 550 pilgrims died this year, the majority due to heat-related illnesses after temperatures reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries. About 1.8 million people attended the pilgrimage.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool off after hours of outdoor prayers, Mohammed said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nHe is far from the only one desperate for information.\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe searchers include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nThe figure of 550 dead provided by diplomats on Tuesday came from the hospital morgue in Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, one of the biggest in the city.\n\nIt includes 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, said the Arab diplomats who briefed AFP on the figures, one of whom noted that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nOn Wednesday an Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", {"uri": "8187461779", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:25:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:25:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:24:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/hajj-death-toll-tops-1-000-after-extreme-heat-afp-tally/article_0f3fb18d-81f3-5a35-9f1d-5588c1bfad78.html", "title": "Hajj death toll tops 1,000 after extreme heat: AFP tally", "body": "A Turkish pilgrim pours cold water on her head to cool off in Saudi Arabia's holy city of Mecca\n\nThe death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said Thursday, more than half unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who died, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAround 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nA Saudi study published last month said temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims try to join the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable, because without official permits they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday of Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nEgyptian officials were visiting hospitals to obtain information and help Egyptian pilgrims get medical care, the foreign ministry said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"However, there are large numbers of Egyptian citizens who are not registered in hajj databases, which requires double the effort and a longer time to search for missing persons and find their relatives,\" it said.\n\nEgyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi has ordered that a \"crisis cell\" headed by the prime minister follow up on the deaths of the country's pilgrims.\n\nSisi stressed \"the need for immediate coordination with the Saudi authorities to facilitate receiving the bodies of the deceased and streamline the process,\" said a statement from his office.\n\n- Burials begin -\n\nMore fatalities were also confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nMore from this section Thailand: Nation To Become First To Legalize Same-Sex Marriage In Southeast Asia 2 Sounds of the past | \u0110\u1ed9c \u0111\u00e1o \u0111\u00e0n \u0111\u00e1 Kh\u00e1nh S\u01a1n German rappers spark buzz with rhubarb-bar blabber\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, its religious affairs ministry said, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases, authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and relatives have been searching for missing pilgrims, scouring hospitals and pleading online for news, fearing the worst.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, cleaning the bodies and putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who said his country was working to notify loved ones as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\n- 'Extreme danger' -\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has seen a number of disasters over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual killed up to 2,300 people.\n\nbur/srm", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "agence_france_presse@reformer.com", "name": "Agence {"uri": "8186732491", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "09:36:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T09:36:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:35:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.omanobserver.om/article/1155272/world/region/search-for-missing-as-hajj-death-toll-passes-900", "title": "Search for missing as hajj death toll passes 900", "body": "Riyadh - Friends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, which this year fell during the oven-like Saudi summer. An Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries. The diplomat later added that Egyptian officials in Saudi Arabia had received \"1,400 reports of missing pilgrims\", including the 600 dead. Mabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said. \"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said.\n\n\"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\" Facebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information. Those searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities. \"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\n- Searing heat - The hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once. Its timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar. For the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer. According to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals. An Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing. \"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone. Last year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia. - 'No news' - Each year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits. This has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham. \"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\" One of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered. Even pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back. \"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "omanobserver.om", "dataType": "news", "title": "Oman Observer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "agence_france_presse@omanobserver.om", "name": "Agence {"uri": "2024-06-394775006", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:42:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:42:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:41:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://today.rtl.lu/news/world/a/2206414.html", "title": "Fearing the worst: Loved ones search for missing pilgrims after hajj heat deaths", "body": "Friends and family of missing hajj pilgrims searched hospitals and pleaded online for news on Wednesday, fearing the worst after hundreds died during the annual rites in Saudi Arabia.\n\nArab diplomats on Tuesday told AFP at least 550 pilgrims died this year, the majority due to heat-related illnesses after temperatures reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries. About 1.8 million people attended the pilgrimage.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool off after hours of outdoor prayers, Mohammed said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nHe is far from the only one desperate for information.\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe searchers include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\n- Searing heat -\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nThe figure of 550 dead provided by diplomats on Tuesday came from the hospital morgue in Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, one of the biggest in the city.\n\nIt includes 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, said the Arab diplomats who briefed AFP on the figures, one of whom noted that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nOn Wednesday an Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\n- 'No news' -\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "today.rtl.lu", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8186991705", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:14:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:14:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:13:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.malaymail.com/news/world/2024/06/20/afp-tally-death-toll-tops-1000-after-hajj-marked-by-extreme-heat/140676", "title": "AFP tally: Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat", "body": "RIYADH, June 20 -- The death toll from this year's haj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said today, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported today included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who passed away, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP today, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nBurials begin\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\n'Extreme danger'\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the haj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has been the scene of a number of stampedes and fires over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual in Mina, near Mecca, killed up to 2,300 people in the event's mostly deadly disaster. -- AFP", "source": {"uri": "malaymail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Malay Mail"}, {"uri": "8185616168", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:07:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:07:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:02:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/world/archives/2024/06/20/2003819641", "title": "At least 550 people died during 'hajj,' officials say - Taipei Times", "body": "VISA ISSUES: A diplomat said the death toll among Egyptians was boosted by the number of people who traveled to Saudi Arabia without properly registering\n\nDiplomats on Tuesday said that at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses said.\n\n\"All of them [the Egyptians] died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding that the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the al-Muaisem neighborhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, an Agence France-Presse tally showed.\n\nThe diplomats said that the total at the morgue in al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8\u00b0C at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi Arabian National Meteorology Center said.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, the Egyptian Ministry of Foreign Affairs said that Cairo was collaborating with Saudi Arabian authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said that \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi Arabian authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims for heat stress, but had not updated that figure since Sunday and had not provided information on fatalities.\n\nJournalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi Arabian officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nHowever, many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat that took place on Saturday last week, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, Saudi Arabian authorities said.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of people attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels, as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk, as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to reporters on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission. \"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air-conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter, the official said.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi Arabian officials said that they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Arabian Minister of Health Fahd bin Abdul Rahman al-Jalajel on Tuesday said that health plans for the hajj had \"been successfully carried out,\" preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" it said.", "source": {"uri": "taipeitimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Taipei Times"}, "authors": {"uri": "8187118623", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:30:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:30:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:30:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://dailytrust.com/hajj-death-toll-tops-1000/", "title": "Hajj death toll tops 1,000 - Daily Trust", "body": "The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who passed away, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe National Meteorological Centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nBurials begin\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases, authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile, friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities, it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.", "source": {"uri": "dailytrust.com", heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding that the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area "https://cdn.wionews.com/sites/default/files/2024/06/13/437521-hajj-story.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9663052", "eventUri": "eng-9663052", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, {"uri": "8186997421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:17:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:17:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:16:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.terradaily.com/afp/240620112123.8bs84l8i.html", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat: AFP tally", "body": "The new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who passed away, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has been the scene of a number of stampedes and fires over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual in Mina, near Mecca, killed up to 2,300 people in the event's mostly deadly disaster.", "source": {"uri": "terradaily.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Terra Daily"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8187156844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:56:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:56:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:55:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/more-1-000-die-amid-134338685.html", "title": "More than 1,000 die amid extreme heat at hajj in Saudia Arabia, AFP says", "body": "Riyadh -- The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia. The new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once. The figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological center reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca. Egyptian officials reached by CBS News would not confirm the figures stated by the AFP, but dozens of videos posted on social media in recent days showed bodies laying on the streets around the Grand Mosque.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius, or just less than one degree Fahrenheit, each decade.\n\nEvery year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits. Saudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorized pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed to AFP by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nMelinda French Gates reflects on personal growth, commitment to advocacy", {"uri": "8185486002", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:30:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:30:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:29:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jun/19/hajj-heat-deaths-missing-pilgrims-search-saudi-arabia", "title": "Search for missing pilgrims continues after hajj heat deaths", "body": "Relatives seek news of missing loved ones after hundreds reported dead as temperatures hit 51.8C in Saudi Arabia\n\nFriends and family of missing hajj pilgrims searched hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after hundreds died during the annual rites in Saudi Arabia.\n\nArab diplomats on Tuesday told Agence France-Presse at least 550 pilgrims had died this year, the majority due to heat-related illnesses after temperatures reached 51.8C (125F) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city.\n\nThe total number of people reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries. About 1.8 million people attended the pilgrimage.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana, of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband, Mohammed, told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool off after hours of outdoor prayers, Mohammed said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nHe is not the only one desperate for information. Facebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe searchers include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once. Its timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past few years, the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer. According to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees celsius (0.72 degrees fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nThe figure of 550 dead provided by diplomats on Tuesday came from the hospital morgue in Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, one of the biggest in the city. It includes 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, said the Arab diplomats who briefed AFP on the figures, one of whom noted that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nOn Wednesday, an Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing. \"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone. Last year, more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nEach year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits. This has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said. \"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable. Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim, has been missing since Saturday. After praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity. \"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are {"uri": "8184517776", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "02:09:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T02:09:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T02:08:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/saudi-arabia-mecca-haj-pilgrims-death-toll-egyptians-heatwave-heat-stroke-2555023-2024-06-19", "title": "550 Haj pilgrims die amid scorching heat in Mecca, mercury rises to 51 degrees", "body": "60 Jordanians also died, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman\n\nDiplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the Haj, underscoring the grueling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe Haj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology center said.\n\nHEAT STRESS\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the Haj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the Haj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the Haj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nUNREGISTERED PILGRIMS\n\nEach year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the Haj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the Haj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the Haj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the Haj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the Haj had \"been successfully carried out,\" preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said.", "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "India Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
