{"uri": "8187472331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:34:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:34:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:33:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://leadership.ng/desperate-searches-continue-as-hajj-death-toll-climbs-900/", "title": "Desperate Searches Continue As Hajj Death Toll Climbs 900", "body": "Friends and family members were desperately searching for missing Hajj pilgrims as the death toll from the annual rituals, conducted in searing heat in Saudi Arabia, has surged past 900.\n\nRelatives were scouring hospitals and pleading online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures soared to 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nApproximately 1.8 million people from around the globe, many of them elderly and infirm, participated in the days-long, predominantly outdoor pilgrimage, which coincided with the intense Saudi summer this year.\n\nAn Arab diplomat revealed to AFP that the number of deaths among Egyptians alone had increased to \"at least 600\" from more than 300 the previous day, primarily due to the extreme heat. This figure brings the total reported deaths to 922, according to an AFP tally based on figures released by various countries.\n\nThe diplomat added that Egyptian officials in Saudi Arabia had received \"1,400 reports of missing pilgrims,\" including the 600 deceased.\n\nOne of the missing pilgrims is Mabrouka bint Salem Shushana from Tunisia, in her early 70s. She has been missing since Saturday's climax of the pilgrimage at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday. Due to her unregistered status and lack of an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities. \"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nSocial media networks like Facebook have been inundated with pictures of the missing pilgrims and requests for information about them. Family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday, are among those seeking news. \"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said a family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who requested anonymity to avoid angering Saudi authorities. \"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nHajj, one of the five pillars of Islam, is mandatory for all Muslims with the means to complete it at least once in their lifetime. Its timing is based on the Islamic lunar calendar, causing it to shift forward each year in the Gregorian calendar. Recently, the mainly outdoor rituals have coincided with the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nA recent Saudi study indicated that temperatures in the region are rising by 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade. Fatalities have been reported in Egypt, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though many authorities have not specified the causes.\n\nA second Arab diplomat informed AFP that Jordanian officials were searching for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others initially reported missing were located in hospitals. An Asian diplomat reported \"around 68 dead\" from India, with others missing. \"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided official information on fatalities, although it reported over 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone. Last year, more than 200 pilgrims, mostly from Indonesia, were reported dead.\n\nThe cost of official permits forces tens of thousands of pilgrims to perform the hajj through irregular channels each year. This has become easier since 2019, with Saudi Arabia's introduction of a general tourism visa, according to Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham. \"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect,\" he said.\n\nMany of the deceased Egyptians were unregistered, according to an Arab diplomat. Even pilgrims with official permits can be at risk, such as Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday. After praying on Mount Arafat, she went to a public bathroom to clean her abaya and never returned. \"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said a friend, who spoke on condition of anonymity. \"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "leadership.ng", "dataType": "news", "title": "Leadership"}, "authors": [{"uri": "nafisat_abdulrahman@leadership.ng", "name": "Nafisat Abdulrahman", "type": Business Hallmark", "body": "Over 1,000 people have died from heatwave in Saudi Arabia, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in the country.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered, according to AFP report.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided {"uri": "8185985417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:45:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:45:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:42:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/world/loved-ones-search-for-missing-pilgrims-after-hajj-heat-deaths", "title": "Loved ones search for missing as hajj death toll passes 900", "body": "Friends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, which this year fell during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nThe diplomat later added that Egyptian officials in Saudi Arabia had received \"1,400 reports of missing pilgrims\", including the 600 dead.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.\n\n\u00a9 2024 AFP", "source": {"uri": "japantoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Japan Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8184590253", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:40:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:40:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:38:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/world/hajj-2024-extreme-heat-kills-at-least-550-mostly-egyptian-pilgrims-12751560.html", "title": "Hajj 2024: Extreme heat kills at least 550, mostly Egyptian pilgrims", "body": "Earlier this month, Saudi officials reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nIntense heat has claimed at least 550 pilgrims during this year's Hajj, news agency AFP reported on Tuesday, quoting diplomats. The deceased include 323 Egyptians who primarily succumbed to heat-related illnesses, according to two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, AFP reported, noting that the total figure was confirmed by the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighborhood of Mecca.\n\nThe death toll for Jordanians rose to at least 60, up from an earlier official tally of 41 reported by Amman on Tuesday.\n\nThese new fatalities bring the overall reported death toll to 577, according to an AFP tally. The morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the largest in Mecca, recorded 550 bodies, the diplomats said.\n\nScorching Heat and Health Strain\n\nThe Hajj, one of Islam's five pillars, must be undertaken by all Muslims at least once in their lifetime. However, the demand for the pilgrimage is increasingly exacerbated by climate change, as noted in a recent Saudi study revealing a 0.4 degrees Celsius rise per decade in the area where Hajj rituals are performed.\n\nOn Monday, temperatures soared to 51.8 degrees Celsius at Mecca's Grand Mosque, AFP reported, citing the Saudi Met Office.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry announced collaboration with the Saudi authorities to search for missing Egyptian pilgrims. Although a ministry statement acknowledged \"a certain number of deaths\", it did not specify if Egyptians were among them.\n\nWhile the Saudi authorities reported treating over 2,000 pilgrims for heat stress, they have not updated this figure since Sunday, nor have they provided specific information on fatalities.\n\nA Harrowing Experience\n\nLast year, at least 240 pilgrims, mostly Indonesians, were reported dead. This year, AFP journalists in Mina observed pilgrims drenching themselves with water and volunteers distributing cold drinks and ice cream to help them cope with the heat.\n\nSaudi officials advised the pilgrims to use umbrellas, stay hydrated, and avoid the sun during peak hours. Despite these measures, many Hajj rituals, including prayers on Mount Arafat, require prolonged outdoor exposure during the day.\n\nSome pilgrims reported seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and overburdened ambulance services. This year, around 1.8 million pilgrims participated in the Hajj, with 1.6 million coming from abroad, according to the Saudi authorities.\n\nPerils of Unregistered Pilgrims\n\nEach year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt the Hajj through irregular channels, unable to afford official visa procedures. These off-the-books pilgrims lack access to air-conditioned facilities provided by the Saudi authorities, increasing their vulnerability.\n\nOne diplomat indicated that the high number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims significantly contributed to the death toll. An Egyptian official overseeing the country's Hajj mission noted that irregular pilgrims caused chaos, leading to service collapses and prolonged deprivation of food, water, and air-conditioning.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the Hajj.\n\nGlobal Impact\n\nOther countries, including Indonesia, Iran, and Senegal, have also reported deaths during this year's Hajj. However, most nations have not detailed the causes of these fatalities.\n\nDespite the challenges, Saudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel announced on Tuesday that health plans for the Hajj were successfully implemented, preventing major disease outbreaks and other public health threats, as reported by the official Saudi Press Agency (SPA).\n\nHealth officials provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating a potential surge in cases, according to SPA.", "source": {"uri": passes 900 - World News", "body": "Friends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, which this year fell during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nThe diplomat later added that Egyptian officials in Saudi Arabia had received \"1,400 reports of missing pilgrims\", including the 600 dead.\n\n23 of the Turkish pilgrims in Mecca were also reported among the dead.\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal and Tunisia, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\n'No news'\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "hurriyetdailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hurriyet Daily News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8186653720", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "08:48:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T08:48:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T08:47:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2024/06/20/loved-ones-search-for-missing-as-hajj-death-toll-passes-900/", "title": "Loved ones search for missing as Hajj death toll passes 900", "body": "Friends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in the holy city of Makkah on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding {"uri": "8186702030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "09:17:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T09:17:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:16:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.newsofbahrain.com/world/100341.html", "title": "Loved ones search for missing as hajj death toll passes 900 | THE DAILY TRIBUNE | KINGDOM OF BAHRAIN", "body": "AFP | Riyadh, Saudi Arabia\n\nThe Daily Tribune - www.newsofbahrain.com\n\nFriends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims yesterday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900. Relatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat. That figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said. \"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals.\n\nUntil now I don't have a clue.\" Facebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information. Those searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities. \"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nSearing heat For the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer. According to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA econd Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals. Saudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone. Last year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\n'No news' Each year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham. \"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said. \"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on {"uri": "8185530101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:02:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:02:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:01:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2024/06/loved-ones-search-missing-hajj-death-toll-passes-900", "title": "Loved ones search for missing as hajj death toll passes 900", "body": "Friends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\n- Searing heat -\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\n- 'No news' -\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "al-monitor.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Al-Monitor"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Over 550 Pilgrims In Saudi Arabia Due To Scorching Heat Conditions ", "body": "According to Arab diplomats managing their countries' responses, at least 323 of the deceased were Egyptians, with the majority succumbing to heat-related ailments.\n\nDiplomats revealed on Tuesday that more than 550 pilgrims lost their lives during this year's hajj pilgrimage, highlighting the arduous conditions exacerbated by extreme temperatures.\n\nAccording to Arab diplomats managing their countries' responses, at least 323 of the deceased were Egyptians, with the majority succumbing to heat-related ailments.\n\nThe diplomats clarified that the fatalities included 60 Jordanians, an increase from earlier figures released by Amman, bringing the total reported deaths to 577 across multiple nations, as per AFP's tally.\n\nThe figure of 550 deaths was confirmed by diplomats citing the morgue in Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, one of Mecca's largest facilities.\n\nThe hajj, a fundamental pillar of Islam, requires completion at least once by Muslims with the means to undertake the journey.\n\nHowever, climate change is increasingly impacting the pilgrimage, with a recent Saudi study indicating a rise in temperatures by 0.4 degrees Celsius per decade in areas where rituals are performed.\n\nOn Monday, temperatures soared to 51.8 degrees Celsius at Mecca's Grand Mosque, according to the Saudi national metrology centre, highlighting the severe heat stress endured by pilgrims.\n\nEarlier in the day, Egypt's foreign ministry announced its collaboration with Saudi authorities in search operations for missing Egyptian pilgrims, without specifying if any had been among the casualties.\n\nSaudi health authorities reported treating over 2,000 pilgrims for heat-related stress, although updates on fatalities were not provided since Sunday.\n\nLast year, various countries reported 240 pilgrim deaths, predominantly Indonesians. AFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, observed volunteers aiding pilgrims with cold drinks and ice cream amid sweltering conditions.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, stay hydrated, and avoid direct sun exposure during peak daytime hours. However, challenges persisted, with reports of overwhelmed emergency services and pilgrims encountering difficulties.\n\nThis year, approximately 1.8 million pilgrims participated in the hajj, including 1.6 million from abroad, according to Saudi authorities. The influx, compounded by unregistered pilgrims attempting the hajj through unofficial channels, posed additional risks due to lack of access to essential facilities.\n\nAn Egyptian official overseeing the hajj mission attributed a significant number of Egyptian deaths to unregistered pilgrims, highlighting chaotic conditions and inadequate services in their camps.\n\nDespite these {"uri": "2024-06-395735858", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:17:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:17:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:59:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/death-toll-tops-1-000-095904262.html", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat: AFP tally", "body": "The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.theborneopost.com/2024/06/20/death-toll-tops-1000-after-hajj-marked-by-extreme-heat/", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat", "body": "RIYADH (June 20): The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said today, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported today included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP today, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided {"uri": "8185569353", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:29:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:29:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:28:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.theborneopost.com/2024/06/19/loved-ones-search-for-missing-as-hajj-heat-death-toll-passes-900/", "title": "Loved ones search for missing as hajj heat death toll passes 900", "body": "RIYADH (June 19): Friends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims today as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP today.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nSearing heat\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP today that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\n'No news'\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP today said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added. - AFP", "source": {"uri": "theborneopost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Borneo Post Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-395086661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:10:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:10:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:01:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/1201522-search-for-missing-continues-as-hajj-death-toll-passes-900", "title": "Search for missing continues as hajj death toll passes 900", "body": "As temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius, relatives of dead pilgrims scoured hospitals, pleaded online for news\n\nFriends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in the holy city of Makkah on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nSearing heat\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\n'No news'\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "thenews.com.pk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The News International"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8186914621", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:27:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:27:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:26:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/hajj-2024-pilgrims-deaths-heatwave-mecca-saudi-arabia-13784353.html", "title": "Extreme heat claims over 1,000 Hajj pilgrims lives, most of them unregistered: Report", "body": "Muslim worshippers pray around the Kaaba, Islam's holiest shrine, at the Grand Mosque in Saudi Arabia's holy city of Mecca. Source: AFP\n\nHajj 2024 death toll has exceeded 1,000, more than half of them unregistered pilgrims who worshiped in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia, a report by AFP said.\n\nThis year, the Hajj pilgrimage began on June 14. As per the report, the new deaths deported on Thursday (June 20) included 58 from Egypt.\n\nAs per an Arab diplomat, who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from Egypt, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAround 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage this year.\n\nAFP said the death figures at Hajj pilgrimage 2024 have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe report also quoted a Saudi Arabia diplomat as saying that, 68 Indians have died during Hajj in Mecca owing to soaring temperatures.\n\n\"We have confirmed around 68 dead. Some are because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" the Saudi diplomat said.\n\nAlso Read: 68 Indian pilgrims die during Hajj due to extreme heat, death toll rises to 600\n\nThe Hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once. The timing of the pilgrimage is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar and this year too it fell during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe temperature at the Grand Mosque of Mecca was recorded a maximum of 51.8 degree Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) earlier this week.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nTens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj each year through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more prone to the heat because as without the official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" AFP quoted an Arab diplomat as saying on Thursday. The person was referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat further said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt and India, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still {"uri": "8185815115", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:47:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:47:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:46:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.geo.tv/latest/550075-loved-ones-search-for-missing-as-hajj-death-toll-passes-900", "title": "Loved ones search for missing as hajj death toll passes 900", "body": "Relatives of dead pilgrims scoured hospitals, pleaded online for news, fearing worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius\n\nFriends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in the holy city of Makkah on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "geo.tv", "dataType": "news", "title": "GEO TV"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajj", "type": "wiki", "score": "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.rawstory.com/toll-tops-1000-after-hajj-marked-by-extreme-heat/", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat", "body": "A man affected by scorching heat is stretchered away during the hajj pilgrimage (FADEL SENNA/AFP)\n\nThe death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorized pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided {"uri": "8185793739", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:28:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:28:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:26:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.breitbart.com/middle-east/2024/06/19/at-least-550-muslims-have-died-on-hajj-pilgrimage-as-temperatures-hit-125of-in-mecca/", "title": "At Least 550 Muslims Have Died on Hajj Pilgrimage, as Temperatures Hit 125\u00baF in Mecca", "body": "Two Arab diplomats told Agence France-Presse (AFP) on Tuesday that at least 550 Muslims have died during 2024's hajj pilgrimage to Mecca in Saudi Arabia, most of them from \"heat-related illnesses.\"\n\nTemperatures in Mecca have soared to 125 degrees Fahrenheit in June. Saudi officials said on Sunday that more than 2,000 pilgrims have been treated for heat stress, but they did not mention any fatalities and have not provided updated information since Sunday.\n\nAFP's tally of deaths, based on local media sources, stood at 645 on Wednesday. The Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP said 550 bodies were being held at the largest morgue in Mecca.\n\nOf the deaths recorded so far, 323 were Egyptians, and 60 were Jordanians, as confirmed by the Jordanian government. The diplomats said one of the Egyptians \"sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush,\" while the others all died of complications from the heat.\n\nThe Egyptian Foreign Ministry said on Tuesday that it is working with the Saudis to rescue Egyptians who have gone missing during the hajj. Egyptian officials said \"a certain number of deaths\" have occurred but did not mention any specific numbers.\n\n\"Some pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times,\" AFP reported.\n\nThe task of locating the missing and counting the dead is complicated by the large number of pilgrims who enter Mecca illegally because they cannot afford to pay for Saudi visas or because various political problems make it difficult for them to enter Saudi Arabia.\n\nOne of AFP's diplomatic sources said many of the Egyptians who died were \"irregular pilgrims\" who \"went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\n\"Other countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran, and Senegal,\" AFP added.\n\nThe UK Guardian on Wednesday said friends and family of missing hajj pilgrims have been frantically searching for them in hospitals and pleading for news online. The husband of a missing 70-year-old Tunisian feared the worst because his wife was an \"unregistered\" pilgrim who had no access to air-conditioned facilities after spending hours praying in the sun.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep. I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now, I don't have a clue,\" he said.\n\nThe hajj is always a dangerous affair due to the heat, the advanced age of many pilgrims, and occasional crowd stampedes. The pilgrimage is technically mandatory at least once during the lifetime of every Muslim.\n\nMillions descend each year upon Mecca, a city that was not constructed with such immense crowds in mind. The Saudis are often criticized by other governments for not doing enough to protect the pilgrims.", "source": {"uri": "breitbart.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breitbart"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8186196358", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "02:22:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T02:22:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T02:21:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/06/20/world/americas-emea/loved-ones-search-for-missing-as-hajj-death-toll-passes-900/1952325", "title": "Loved ones search for missing as hajj death toll passes 900", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia -- Friends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, which this year fell during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nThe diplomat later added that Egyptian officials in Saudi Arabia had received \"1,400 reports of missing pilgrims\", including the 600 dead.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nSearing heat\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n'No news'\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding {"uri": "8186884895", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:09:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:09:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:08:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.newarab.com/news/death-toll-tops-1000-after-hajj-marked-extreme-heat-afp", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat: AFP", "body": "Rescuers carry away a man, affected by the scorching heat, on a stretcher as Muslim pilgrims arrive to perform the symbolic 'stoning of the devil' ritual as part of the hajj pilgrimage in Mina on June 16, 2024. [Getty]\n\nThe death toll from this year's Hajj has exceeded 1,000 on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown to news agency AFP showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe Hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided
