{"uri": "8185774953", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:11:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:11:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:09:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/families-search-for-missing-as-hajj-pilgrims-death-count-rises-over-900-5926201", "title": "Families Search For Missing As Hajj Pilgrims Death Count Rises Over 900", "body": "Relatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nSocial Media has been flooded with pictures of the missing\n\nFriends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death count at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nSearing heat\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\n'No news'\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is {"uri": "8185572455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:32:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:32:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:31:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.terradaily.com/afp/240619145544.juwgpkhh.html", "title": "Loved ones search for missing as hajj death toll passes 900", "body": "Relatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "terradaily.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Terra Daily"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajj", "type": {"uri": "8184686856", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:19:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:19:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:18:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.dawn.com/news/1840594", "title": "Diplomats say at least 550 pilgrims, mostly Egyptians, died during haj this year", "body": "Diplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Makkah.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Makkah, was 550.\n\nThe Haj pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Makkah on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the haj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Makkah, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the haj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the haj this year, 1.6m of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the haj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the haj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's haj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Makkah ahead of the haj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the haj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the haj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said.", "source": {"uri": "dawn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Dawn"}, "authors": [{"uri": Some are because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told AFP.The new toll comes after two Arab diplomats told AFP on Tuesday that 550 deaths had been recorded during the hajj, one of the five pillars of Islam that all Muslims with the means must perform at least once.\n\nThat figure included 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, the Arab diplomats said, and one specified that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nThe diplomat who confirmed the Indian fatalities said there were also some Indian pilgrims missing, but he declined to provide an exact number.\n\n\"This happens every year... {"uri": "8185474406", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:21:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:21:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:20:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://news.abplive.com/news/world/mecca-over-550-including-indians-dead-at-hajj-extreme-heat-temperature-exceeds-50-degrees-1696827", "title": "Over 550 Hajj Pilgrims, Including 68 Indians, Die In Mecca As Temperature Exceeds 50 Degrees", "body": "At least 550 pilgrims, including 68 Indians, lost their lives during the Hajj pilgrimage this year, amid the scorching heat in Mecca. ( Image Source :X/@AFP )\n\nAt least 550 pilgrims, including 68 Indians, lost their lives during the Hajj due to the scorching heat in Mecca, according to news agency AFP. The majority of the dead, around 323, were reportedly Egyptians, losing their lives to heat-related illnesses. The temperature at the Grand Mosque in Mecca soared to 51.8 degrees Celsius on Monday, as per the Saudi National Meteorology Centre.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who got seriously injured during a crowd crush, one of the two diplomats told AFP, adding the total figure of 550 came from the hospital morgue located in Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood.\n\nThose dead also include at least 60 Jordanians, the diplomats stated. This tally has gone up from the official tally of 41 given on Tuesday by Jordan.\n\nAs per AFP's tally, the new deaths have increased the the total reported so far by various countries to 577.\n\nHowever, the diplomats stated tha the total as per the Al-Muasisem morgue, which is one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nSaudi authorities reported treating over 2,000 pilgrims suffering due to heat but have not yet updated the figures and information on casualties since Sunday.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to drink adequate water, use umbrellas, and avoid sun exposure during the hottest hours. However, some Hajj rituals require pilgrims to stay outdoors for prolonged periods during the day.\n\nSome pilgrims even recounted seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and overhwhelmed ambulance services, the report noted.\n\nThis year, around 1.8 million pilgrims participated in the Hajj, 1.6 million of whom were foreigners, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nSome other countries that have reported deaths during the Hajj this year include Iran, Indonesia, and Senegal.\n\nHowever, most of the countries have not yet specified about the figures on heat-related deaths.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" the report quoted the Saudi Press Agency as saying.\n\nLast year, at least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by several countries, most of them Indonesians.\n\nClimate change, is increasingly affecting the Hajj pilgrimage, according to a Saudi study published last month. As per the study, temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEvery year thousands of pilgrims, who cannot afford the expensive procedures for the Hajj visas, attempt to perform the pilgrimage through irregular channels.\n\nThis makes them off-the-books pilgrims, putting them at risk, since they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the Hajj route, AFP reported.", "source": {"uri": "news.abplive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "english"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185613297", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:02:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:02:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:01:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/06/19/death-toll-from-heat-at-hajj-pilgrimage-in-saudi-arabia-passes-900_6675195_4.html", "title": "Death toll from heat at hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia passes 900", "body": "The reported death toll from the scorching heat in Saudi Arabia surged past 900 hajj pilgrims on Wednesday, June 19, as friends and family searched for missing loved ones.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told Agence France-Presse (AFP) that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600,\" from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat. That figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer. Relatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8\u00b0C in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday. Facebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause. A second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing. \"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once. Its timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar. For the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4\u00b0C each decade.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits. {"uri": "8184687496", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:20:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:20:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:19:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2472335/intense-heat-claims-lives-of-550-pilgrims-during-hajj-confirm-diplomats", "title": "Intense heat claims lives of 550 pilgrims during Hajj, confirm diplomats", "body": "This year's hajj involved around 1.8 million participants, with 1.6 million from abroad\n\nOn Tuesday, diplomats reported that at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, highlighting the challenging conditions of this year's pilgrimage marked by sweltering temperatures.\n\nMost of the deaths, including 323 Egyptians, were attributed to heat-related illnesses, according to Arab diplomats coordinating responses with AFP.\n\nOne Egyptian pilgrim died due to injuries sustained in a minor crowd incident, while the overall tally was confirmed by the Al-Muaisem hospital morgue in Makkah.\n\nAdditionally, 60 Jordanian pilgrims were reported deceased, an increase from the earlier official count of 41 by Jordanian authorities. These new figures bring the total deaths reported by multiple countries to 577, as per AFP's count.\n\nThe pilgrimage, a fundamental practice in Islam, is increasingly impacted by climate change, with a recent Saudi study noting a rise in temperatures in the ritual areas.\n\nOn Monday, temperatures soared to 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Makkah, as reported by the Saudi national meteorology center.\n\nSaudi efforts included treating over 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress, although specific updates on fatalities have not been provided since Sunday. Last year, various countries reported 240 deaths among pilgrims, predominantly Indonesians.\n\nDuring the hajj rituals, such as prayers on Mount Arafat, pilgrims endured prolonged outdoor exposure despite Saudi advisories to use umbrellas, stay hydrated, and avoid the sun during peak hours.\n\nNonetheless, reports indicated challenges with overwhelmed ambulance services and instances of pilgrims succumbing to extreme heat along the route.\n\nThis year's hajj involved around 1.8 million participants, with 1.6 million from abroad. A significant number attempted the pilgrimage through unofficial channels due to the costs associated with official hajj visas, placing them at greater risk without access to Saudi-provided amenities.\n\nAn Egyptian official highlighted that many unregistered Egyptian pilgrims contributed to chaos in camps, resulting in inadequate services such as food, water, and cooling facilities, which likely exacerbated the death toll from heat-related causes.\n\nSaudi authorities had earlier cleared hundreds of thousands of unauthorized pilgrims from Makkah ahead of the hajj. Countries including Indonesia, Iran, and Senegal also reported deaths during this year's pilgrimage, although specific details on heat-related fatalities were generally not disclosed.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel noted successful health plans during the hajj, which prevented major outbreaks of disease and managed over 5,800 virtual consultations primarily for heat-related illnesses, ensuring timely medical intervention.", "source": {"uri": "tribune.com.pk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Express Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8186684585", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "09:08:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T09:08:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:07:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://thearabweekly.com/relatives-search-missing-haj-pilgrims-heat-death-toll-mounts", "title": "Relatives search for missing haj pilgrims as heat death toll mounts |  | AW", "body": "A man effected by the scorching heat is helped by a member of the Saudi security forces. AFP\n\nFriends and family of missing haj pilgrims searched hospitals and pleaded online for news on Wednesday, fearing the worst after hundreds died during the annual rites in Saudi Arabia.\n\nArab diplomats on Tuesday told AFP at least 550 pilgrims died this year, the majority due to heat-related illnesses after temperatures reached 51.8 degrees Celsius in Mecca, Islam's holiest city.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries. About 1.8 million people attended the pilgrimage.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official haj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool off after hours of outdoor prayers, Mohammed said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nHe is far from the only one desperate for information.\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe searchers include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nThe haj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nThe figure of 550 dead provided by diplomats on Tuesday came from the hospital morgue in Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, one of the biggest in the city.\n\nIt includes 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, said the Arab diplomats, one of whom noted that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nOn Wednesday an Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the haj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", Some are because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told AFP.\n\nThe new toll comes after two Arab diplomats told AFP on Tuesday that 550 deaths had been recorded during the hajj, one of the five pillars of Islam that all Muslims with the means must perform at least once.\n\nThat figure included 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, the Arab diplomats said, and one specified that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nThe diplomat who confirmed the Indian fatalities said there were also some Indian pilgrims missing, but he declined to provide an exact number.\n\n\"This happens every year... We can't say that it is abnormally high this year,\" he said.\n\n\"It's somewhat similar to last year but we will know more in the coming days.\"\n\nFor the past several years the hajj has fallen {"uri": "8186528357", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "07:26:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T07:26:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T07:25:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://thethaiger.com/news/world/scorching-temps-claims-over-550-hajj-pilgrims-in-mecca", "title": "Scorching temps claims over 550 Hajj pilgrims in Mecca", "body": "Among the deceased, 323 were Egyptians, with most succumbing to heat-related conditions, according to two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses, as reported by AFP.\n\nA diplomat noted that one Egyptian individual sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, referencing figures sourced from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca, which is one of Mecca's largest. The current official death toll according to the morgue is listed at 550.\n\nThe diplomats also reported that at least 60 Jordanians have died, up from the previously reported 41 as of Tuesday. These new fatalities bring the total number reported by various countries to 577.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry announced it was working with Saudi authorities to search for Egyptians missing during the Hajj. While the ministry acknowledged 'a certain number of deaths' it did not specify if Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have treated over 2,000 pilgrims for heat stress but have not updated this figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nRising temperatures\n\nThe Hajj, one of the five pillars of Islam, is obligatory for all Muslims with the means to perform it at least once in their lifetime. A recent Saudi study indicated that the pilgrimage is increasingly impacted by climate change, with temperatures in the area rising by 0.4\u00b0C each decade. According to the Saudi National Meteorology Centre, temperatures at the Grand Mosque in Mecca reached 51.8\u00b0C this past Monday.\n\nPilgrims were observed pouring water over their heads while volunteers distributed cold drinks and quickly melting chocolate ice cream to help them stay cool. Saudi officials advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water, and avoid the sun during the hottest parts of the day.\n\nHowever, many Hajj rituals, such as the prayers on Mount Arafat on Saturday, require prolonged outdoor exposure.\n\nSome pilgrims reported seeing motionless bodies along the roadside and described ambulance services as overwhelmed at times. According to Saudi authorities, roughly 1.8 million pilgrims participated in this year's Hajj, with 1.6 million coming from abroad.\n\nEach year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt the Hajj without official visas to save money, a dangerous practice as these unregistered pilgrims cannot access the air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the Hajj route.\n\nOne diplomat noted that the high number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims contributed to the high Egyptian death toll.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca before the Hajj. Other countries reporting deaths during this year's pilgrimage include Indonesia, Iran, and Senegal, though most have not specified how many were heat-related, reported The Guardian.", "source": Some are because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims.\n\nAnd some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told AFP. The new toll comes after two Arab diplomats told AFP on Tuesday that 550 deaths had been recorded during the hajj, one of the five pillars of Islam that all Muslims with the means must perform at least once.\n\nThat figure included 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, the Arab diplomats said, and one specified that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\". Fatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally. Last year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia. We can't say that it is abnormally high this year,\" he said.\n\n\"It's somewhat similar to last year but we will know more in the coming days.\" For the past several years the hajj has fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer. intense heat", "body": "Egypt has highest number of pilgrims fatalities alongside deaths reported by Pakistan, India and others this year\n\nThe death toll from this year's Hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe Hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8\u00b0C (125\u00b0F) earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4\u00b0C each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the Hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the Hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided {"uri": "8186488605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "06:58:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T06:58:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T06:57:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://tribuneonlineng.com/heatwave-hajj-pilgrims-death-toll-reaches-900-in-saudi-arabia/", "title": "Heatwave: Hajj pilgrims' death toll reaches 900 in Saudi Arabia", "body": "The death toll of Hajj pilgrims at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, which this year fell during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nALSO READ: Heatstroke: At least 14 Hajj pilgrims die in Saudi Arabia\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nThe diplomat later added that Egyptian officials in Saudi Arabia had received \"1,400 reports of missing pilgrims\", including the 600 dead.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat {"uri": "8185153184", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:53:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:53:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:52:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/saudi-hundreds-pilgrims-died-in-hajj-heat", "title": "More than 570, including 320 Egyptians, died in Hajj", "body": "More than 570 pilgrims at the annual Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia have died, mostly due to heat-related illnesses, AFP reported on Tuesday.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, according to two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses who spoke to AFP.\n\nOne of the diplomats said that all the Egyptian deaths were heat-related, except for one pilgrim who died after a crowd crush.\n\nThe sources said that 550 deaths were recorded at the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of the holy city of Mecca.\n\nAFP put the total number of reported deaths at 577, as of Tuesday evening.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians were among those to have died, according to the diplomats.\n\nIndonesia, Iran and Senegal also reported deaths at this year's Hajj, which began on 14 June, but did not specify if they were heat-related.\n\nTemperatures at the Grand Mosque in Mecca reached 51.8 degrees celsius on Monday, Saudi Arabia's national meteorology centre said.\n\nSaudi authorities said on Sunday that 2,000 Hajj pilgrims had suffered heat stress. It has not updated the figures since then, and provided no information on fatalities.\n\nVideos shared on social media showed scores of pilgrims lying lifeless on the side of roads in the scorching heat.\n\nEgyptian social media platform Rassd News posted one such video, with the caption: \"Some of them could have been treated. Pilgrims document the Saudi authorities' neglect of the bodies of those killed during Hajj and leave them for hours on the sidewalks.\"\n\nCairo's foreign ministry said on Tuesday that it was working with Saudi authorities to search for Egyptians who had gone missing during the pilgrimage.\n\n'Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services'\n\n- Egyptian official\n\nAn Egyptian official who spoke to AFP said the high Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by unregistered pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said the official, who is supervising Egypt's Hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water or air conditioning for a long time,\" the official said, adding that people died because they had no place to take shelter.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims performed the Hajj this year, of whom 1.6 million were from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nOn the Day of Arafat, which took place on Saturday, pilgrims spent the whole day near a hill known as Mount Arafat (the Mount of Mercy), where the Prophet Muhammad delivered his final sermon.\n\nSaudi officials advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, stay hydrated and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours.\n\nThe annual pilgrimage, which is one of the five pillars of Islam, is increasingly being affected by climate change.\n\nA recent Saudi study found that temperatures in areas where Hajj rituals are performed are rising by 0.4 degrees {"uri": "8187630673", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:49:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:49:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:48:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.newagebd.net/post/middle-east/238117/death-toll-tops-1000-after-hajj-marked-by-extreme-heat", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after Hajj marked by extreme heat", "body": "The death toll from this year's Hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who passed away, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe Hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius this week at the Grand Mosque in Makkah.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the Hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Makkah this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n'People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,' one Arab diplomat said on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the Hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nEgyptian officials were visiting hospitals to obtain data on Egyptian pilgrims and help those still alive to get medical care, the foreign ministry said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n'However, there are large numbers of Egyptian citizens who are not registered in Hajj databases, which requires double the effort and a longer time to search for missing persons and find their relatives,' the ministry said.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally said.\n\n'I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,' the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 2,40,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases, authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile, friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats said on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n'The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,' said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of 'heat exhaustion' on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the Hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the Hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for Hajj pilgrims will exceed the 'extreme danger threshold' from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, 'with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses'.\n\nHosting the Hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words 'Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques', in Makkah and Medina.\n\nThe Hajj has been the scene of a number of stampedes and fires over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the 'stoning the devil' ritual in Mina, near Makkah, killed up to 2,300 people in the event's mostly deadly disaster.", "source": {"uri": "newagebd.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "New Age | The Most Popular Outspoken English Daily "body": "Egypt reports highest number of heat-related deaths among pilgrims which is 685 including 58 new casualties\n\nThe death toll from this year's Hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe Hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Makkah.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the Hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Makkah earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the Hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.", "source": {"uri": "geo.tv", "dataType": "news", "title": "GEO TV"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8186006266", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:09:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:09:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:07:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://howafrica.com/loved-ones-search-for-missing-as-hajj-death-toll-passes-900/", "title": "Loved Ones Search For Missing As Hajj Death Toll Passes 900 | HowAfrica Latest news, views, gossip, photos and video", "body": "Friends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday, as the death toll from the annual ceremonies, which took place in sweltering temperatures, surpassed 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and asked for updates online, expecting the worst after temperatures in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) on Monday.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims from all over the world, many of them were elderly and infirm, participated in the days-long, primarily outdoor pilgrimage, which took place this year during Saudi Arabia's scorching hot summer.\n\nAn Arab ambassador told AFP that mortality among Egyptians had increased to \"at least 600\" from more than 300 a day earlier, owing primarily to the oppressive heat.\n\nThis amount brings the overall number of recorded deaths to 922, according to an AFP assessment of numbers published by several countries.\n\nThe envoy later stated that Egyptian officials in Saudi Arabia had received \"1,400 reports of missing pilgrims,\" including the 600 deceased.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has gone missing since the pilgrimage's climax on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed informed AFP on Wednesday.\n\nHe stated that because she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was prohibited to use air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nThe hajj is one of Islam's five pillars, and all Muslims who have the means must perform it at least once.\n\nIts time is regulated by the Islamic lunar calendar, which moves forward every year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years, the majority of outdoor rites have occurred during the hot Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising by 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) per decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region have acknowledged casualties, though authorities have often not explained the cause.\n\nA second Arab ambassador told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were seeking for 20 missing pilgrims, while 80 others who were initially reported missing had been found in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian ambassador told AFP that there were \"around 68 dead\" in India, with more missing.\n\n\"Some perished due to natural causes, and we had many elderly pilgrims. And some are due to weather conditions, we believe,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not published numbers on fatalities, but it did disclose over 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year, more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, the most of whom were from Indonesia.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nOne of the Arab diplomats who spoke to AFP on Wednesday said many of the dead Egyptians were unregistered.\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "howafrica.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "How Africa News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajj", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, {"uri": "8186918348", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:29:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:29:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:28:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://guardian.ng/death-toll-tops-1000-after-hajj-marked-by-extreme-heat-afp-tally/", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat: AFP tally", "body": "The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, with more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\n- Burials begin -\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the hajj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the hajj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for hajj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe hajj has been the scene of a number of stampedes and fires over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual in Mina, near Mecca, killed up to 2,300 people in the event's mostly deadly disaster.", "source": {"uri": "guardian.ng", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/death-toll-tops-1-000-095904021.html", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat: AFP tally", "body": "The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided {"uri": "8186848586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:48:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:48:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:46:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.legit.ng/world/asia/1598150-hajj-2024-900-deaths-recorded-families-search-loved-ones/", "title": "Hajj 2024: Over 900 deaths recorded, as families search for loved ones", "body": "An Arab diplomat reported that Egyptian deaths alone had surged to at least 600, with the overall death toll reaching 922\n\nMakkah, Saudi Arabia-Relatives combed through hospitals and sought updates online, fearing the worst after temperatures in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, soared to 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) on Monday, June 17.\n\nApproximately 1.8 million people from around the globe, many elderly and frail, participated in the predominantly outdoor pilgrimage, which this year coincided with the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAs reported by The Guardian, an Arab diplomat informed AFP that the number of Egyptian deaths alone had risen to \"at least 600,\" up from more than 300 the previous day, primarily due to the relentless heat.\n\nThis figure brought the total death count to 922, based on an AFP tally of reports from various countries. Mabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday, June 19.\n\nDue to her lack of registration and an official Hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities meant to help pilgrims cope with the heat, he explained.\n\nHis words:\n\n\"She's an elderly woman, exhausted, extremely hot, and without a place to rest,\" he said. \"I have searched all the hospitals for her. Until now, I have no clue about her whereabouts.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media platforms have been flooded with photos of missing individuals and pleas for information, Vanguard reported.\n\nAmong those searching are the family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\nA family friend in Saudi Arabia said:\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt, pleading with me to post anything on Facebook that could help locate her or find her,\"\n\n\"The silver lining is that we haven't found her name on the list of deceased, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nThe Hajj, one of Islam's five pillars, is mandatory for all Muslims who have the means to complete it at least once. Its timing is based on the Islamic lunar calendar, causing it to shift forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past few years, the predominantly outdoor rituals have taken place during Saudi Arabia's scorching summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the region are rising by 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nBesides Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though specific causes have often not been disclosed.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were searching for 20 missing pilgrims, while 80 others initially reported missing were found in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat mentioned that:\n\n\"India had \"around 68 dead,\" with some pilgrims still missing. \"Some died due to natural causes, particularly the elderly, while others likely succumbed to the extreme weather conditions.\"\n\nSaudi Arabia has not released information on fatalities but reported over 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year, more than 200 pilgrims, mostly from Indonesia, were reported dead.\n\nEvery year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt the Hajj through unofficial channels due to the high cost of official permits.\n\nThis has been facilitated by Saudi Arabia's introduction of a general tourism visa in 2019, explained Umer Karim, a Saudi politics expert at the University of Birmingham.\n\nHe said:\n\n\"Previously, only residents of the kingdom could attempt this, but now tourists, unaware of the challenges, are attempting it.\"\n\nIn another report, over 500 pilgrims have lost their lives during the 2024 Hajj pilgrimage to Mecca amidst scorching temperatures, as reported by various press outlets and foreign ministries.\n\nAccording to diplomats speaking to French news agency Agence France Presse (AFP) on Tuesday, at least 550 people have died during the hajj.\n\nThe majority of the fatalities, numbering 323, were Egyptians who succumbed to heat-related illnesses, as confirmed by two Arab diplomats.", "source": {"uri": "legit.ng", {"uri": "8187240698", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "14:50:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T14:50:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T14:49:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.arabtimesonline.com/news/hajj-death-toll-exceeds-1000-amid-extreme-heat-in-saudi-arabia/", "title": "Hajj death toll exceeds 1,000 amid extreme heat in Saudi Arabia", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, June 20: The death toll from this year's hajj pilgrimage has surpassed 1,000, according to an AFP tally released on Thursday. Over half of the fatalities were unregistered worshippers who endured extreme heat conditions while performing the pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia. The latest reported deaths, including 58 from Egypt, underscored the severity of the situation, with 630 out of 658 total Egyptian deaths being unregistered pilgrims.\n\nReports from approximately 10 countries have contributed to the tally of 1,081 deaths during the annual hajj pilgrimage, a fundamental pillar of Islam that all financially capable Muslims are required to complete at least once in their lifetime. Official statements from various countries and information shared by diplomats have provided insights into the magnitude of the tragedy.\n\nThis year's hajj coincided with the sweltering Saudi summer, with temperatures soaring to 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Makkah, as reported by the National Meteorological Center. While Egyptian officials have refrained from confirming AFP's figures, numerous social media videos have depicted distressing scenes of bodies strewn across the streets near the Grand Mosque.\n\nA Saudi study published recently highlighted a concerning trend of rising temperatures in the region, with temperatures increasing by approximately 0.4 degrees Celsius per decade. Despite efforts by Saudi authorities to clear hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier in the month, many still participated in the main hajj rites, which commenced last Friday.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims faced heightened vulnerability to the extreme heat as they lacked access to air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for authorized pilgrims. Without official permits, they endured hours of walking and praying outdoors without respite from the scorching temperatures.\n\nAccording to an Arab diplomat, the primary cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was heat-related complications, exacerbating issues such as high blood pressure. Alongside Egypt, countries including Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, and Iraq's Kurdistan region have reported fatalities, although specific causes have not always been specified.\n\nFamilies and friends continue to search for missing pilgrims, with concerns escalating as temperatures remain dangerously high. Despite Saudi Arabia reporting over 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone, official information on fatalities has not been disclosed.", "source": {"uri": "arabtimesonline.com", {"uri": "8184390195", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:21:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:21:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:19:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.malaymail.com/news/world/2024/06/19/diplomats-say-at-least-550-pilgrims-died-during-haj-mostly-egyptians/140390", "title": "Diplomats say at least 550 pilgrims died during Haj, mostly Egyptians", "body": "RIIYADH, June 19 -- Diplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the Haj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe Haj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nHeat stress\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the Haj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the Haj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the Haj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the Haj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official Haj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the Haj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's Haj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the Haj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the Haj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the Haj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said. -- AFP", "source": {"uri": "malaymail.com",
