{"uri": "8187368379", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:16:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:16:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:14:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/06/21/world/americas-emea/heat-plagued-hajj-death-toll-exceeds-1000/1952325", "title": "Heat-plagued Hajj death toll exceeds 1,000", "body": "(UPDATE) RIYADH -- The death toll from this year's Hajj has exceeded 1,000, an Agence France-Presse (AFP) tally showed on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported on Thursday included 58 from Egypt, said an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of the 658 dead from the North African country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told, about 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam, which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe Hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nThe national meteorological center reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in the holy city of Mecca.\n\nA Saudi study published last month said temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nEach year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the Hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites, which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorized pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's daylong outdoor prayers that marked the Hajj's climax.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday, they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.", "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8184593402", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:43:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:43:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:42:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/hajj-mecca-pilgrims-die-of-heatstroke-saudi-arabia-13783779.html", "title": "Over 500 pilgrims die of heatstroke during hajj as Mecca's temperature soar above 50 degrees Celcius", "body": "Most of the rituals of the Hajj, an annual pilgrimage that Muslims are obligated to make at least once in their lifetime, are held outside under the direct sun. Pilgrims are often exposed to extreme heat as they walk around the Kaaba in circles read more\n\nSweltering heat amid soaring temperatures has claimed the lives of a whopping 550 pilgrims during the Hajj in Saudi Arabia's Mecca. At least 323 of the dead were Egyptians, diplomats have said.\n\nTalking to AFP, the two Arab officials said that the pilgrims succumbed to heat-related illnesses. \"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nTemperatures in the Muslim pilgrim city touched 51.8 degrees Celcius on Monday, according to the National Center for Meteorology.\n\nMost of the rituals of the Hajj, an annual pilgrimage that Muslims are obligated to make at least once in their lifetime, are held outside under the direct sun. Pilgrims are often exposed to extreme heat as they walk around the Kaaba in circles.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nHajj and heatwave\n\nThe Hajj has been facing the wrath of climate change recently but that is not stopping pilgrims from visiting the holy site. Around 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nStudies suggest that increasing humidity and temperatures pose a threat to the health of pilgrims. Researchers from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles predict that the annual pilgrimage could turn more dangerous from 2047 to 2052 and from 2079 to 2086 during the hottest months of the year.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nThousands of unregistered Muslims who often cannot afford the costly procedures for official visas attempt to perform the hajj via irregular channels. These pilgrims are the ones who are inadvertently affected more by the heat conditions as they do not have access to air-conditioned services and facilities.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nWhat's the authority doing?\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nExperts have also recommended putting a cap on the number of visitors and allowing only those pilgrims who are in the best of health.\n\nMeanwhile, authorities are also doing the best they can to ensure maximum comfort to pilgrims by providing cold water, installing large umbrellas with mist fans and setting up hospitals to treat heat-related illnesses.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslims", "type": "loc", "score": 5, Some are because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told AFP.\n\nThe new toll comes after two Arab diplomats told AFP on Tuesday that 550 deaths had been recorded during the hajj.\n\nThat figure included 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, the Arab diplomats said, and one specified that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nSaudi Arabia has reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nThe diplomat who confirmed the Indian fatalities said there were also some Indian pilgrims missing, but he declined to provide an exact number.\n\n\"This happens every year... {"uri": "2024-06-394469702", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "09:24:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T09:24:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T09:07:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.dnpindia.in/world/over-550-pilgrims-die-during-hajj-amid-scorching-heat-in-mecca/421486/", "title": "Over 550 Pilgrims Die During Hajj Amid Scorching Heat in Mecca", "body": "More than 550 pilgrims died at this year's Hajj, according to reports released by diplomats on Tuesday. This underscores how difficult the journey is, particularly in the sweltering heat. Once again, the oppressive heat has been a major factor, since this year's pilgrimage took place in extremely hot weather.\n\nHigh Death Toll Among Egyptians\n\nAt least 323 Egyptians died out of the 550 total, primarily from heat-related illnesses, according to two Arab ambassadors who oversaw their nations' reactions. One ambassador stated that all Egyptian deaths were due to the heat, with the exception of one Egyptian who passed away from wounds received in a small crowd crush. The hospital mortuary in the Mecca neighbourhood of Al-Muaisem verified this number.\n\nIncrease in Jordanian Deaths\n\nThe ambassadors also mentioned that 60 Jordanians had passed away, which was more than the official toll of 41 that Amman had earlier announced. According to an AFP count, with these additional numbers, the total number of deaths recorded by different nations has reached 577. One of Mecca's biggest mortuaries, Al-Muaisem, announced 550 fatalities in all.\n\nImpact of Climate Change on Hajj\n\nThe Hajj pilgrimage, a vital practice in Islam, requires all Muslims with the means to perform it at least once. However, climate change has increasingly impacted the pilgrimage. A Saudi study published last month indicated that temperatures in the area where rituals are performed have been rising by 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade. On Monday, temperatures soared to 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca, as reported by the Saudi national meteorology center.\n\nHeat Stress and Health Challenges\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry stated that Cairo was working with Saudi authorities to find Egyptians who went missing during the Hajj. While the ministry acknowledged \"a certain number of deaths,\" it did not clarify if Egyptians were among them. Saudi authorities have treated over 2,000 pilgrims for heat stress but have not updated this figure since Sunday, nor have they provided information on fatalities.\n\nLast year, 240 pilgrims died, most of them Indonesians. This year, AFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, observed pilgrims pouring water over their heads while volunteers distributed cold drinks and quickly melting chocolate ice cream to help them stay cool. Saudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water, and avoid the sun during the hottest parts of the day. However, many Hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat, require being outdoors for extended periods during the day.\n\nStruggles of Unregistered Pilgrims\n\nEach year, many pilgrims attempt the Hajj without official visas due to the high costs, putting them at significant risk as they lack access to air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities. A diplomat mentioned that the high number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims \"absolutely\" increased the death toll. An Egyptian official overseeing the country's Hajj mission stated that these irregular pilgrims caused chaos in the camps, leading to a collapse of services. Many went without food, water, or air conditioning, ultimately succumbing to the heat.\n\nEfforts to Manage the Crisis\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the Hajj. Other countries, including Indonesia, Iran, and Senegal, have also reported deaths during this year's pilgrimage, though most have not specified if these were heat-related.\n\nAccording to the official Saudi Press Agency, Saudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel declared on Tuesday that the Hajj health plans were effectively carried out, averting significant illness outbreaks and other public health hazards. More than 5,800 virtual consultations were given by health experts, primarily for ailments associated to heat waves, to ensure early management and avoid a spike in cases.", "source": {"uri": Some are because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told AFP.\n\nThe new toll comes after two Arab diplomats told AFP on Tuesday that 550 deaths had been recorded during the hajj, one of the five pillars of Islam that all Muslims with the means must perform at least once.\n\nThat figure included 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, the Arab diplomats said, and one specified that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nThe diplomat who confirmed the Indian fatalities said there were also some Indian pilgrims missing, but he declined to provide an exact number.\n\n\"This happens every year... We can't say that it is abnormally high this year,\" he said.\n\n\"It's somewhat similar to last year but we will know more in the coming days.\"\n\nFor the past several years the hajj has fallen {"uri": "8184803672", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:57:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:57:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T06:56:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.avapress.com/en/news/292173/diplomats-say-at-least-550-pilgrims-died-during-this-year-s-hajj", "title": "Diplomats say at least 550 pilgrims died during this years Hajj | AVA", "body": "Afghan Voice Agency (AVA) - Monitoring: At least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighborhood of Makkah.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Makkah, was 550.\n\nThe Haj pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Makkah on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology center said.\n\nHeat stress\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the haj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Makkah, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the haj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the haj this year, 1.6m of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the haj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the haj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's haj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Makkah ahead of the haj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the haj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the haj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said./Dawn", "source": {"uri": "avapress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "\u062e\u0628\u0631\u06af\u0632\u0627\u0631\u06cc \u0635\u062f\u0627\u06cc {"uri": "8185859186", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:34:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:34:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:28:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.newagebd.net/post/middle-east/238036/550-pilgrims-die-during-hajj", "title": "550 pilgrims die during Hajj", "body": "Friends and family of missing Hajj pilgrims searched hospitals and pleaded online for news on Wednesday, fearing the worst after hundreds died during the annual rites in Saudi Arabia.\n\nArab diplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died this year, the majority due to heat-related illnesses after temperatures reached 51.8 degrees Celsius in Makkah, Islam's holiest city.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries. About 1.8 million people attended the pilgrimage.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed said on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official Hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool off after hours of outdoor prayers, Mohammed said.\n\n'She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,' he said. 'I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.'\n\nHe is far from the only one desperate for information.\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe searchers include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n'I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,' said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia.\n\n'The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.'\n\nThe Hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nThe figure of 550 dead provided by diplomats on Tuesday came from the hospital morgue in Makkah's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, one of the biggest in the city.\n\nIt includes 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, said the Arab diplomats who briefed AFP on the figures, one of whom noted that nearly all the Egyptians died 'because of heat'.\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nOn Wednesday an Asian diplomat said there were 'around 68 dead' from India and that others were missing.\n\n'Some died because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,' he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of 'heat exhaustion' on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the Hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019 when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n'Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,' he said.\n\n'For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.'\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim who has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n'We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,' said the friend.\n\n'We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,' the friend added.", "source": {"uri": "newagebd.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "New Age | The Most Popular Outspoken English Daily in Bangladesh"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8184671586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:06:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:06:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:05:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.dailyexcelsior.com/at-least-550-haj-pilgrims-died-mostly-due-to-heat-say-arab-diplomats/", "title": "At Least 550 Haj Pilgrims Died, Mostly Due To Heat, Say Arab Diplomats - Daily Excelsior", "body": "Riyadh (Saudi Arabia), June 19: Diplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the haj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nClick here to connect with us on WhatsApp\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman. The new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally. The diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe haj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the haj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the haj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the haj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the haj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official haj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the haj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's haj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the haj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the haj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the haj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said. (Agencies)", "source": {"uri": "dailyexcelsior.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jammu Kashmir Latest News | Tourism | Breaking News J&K"}, "authors": [{"uri": "daily_excelsior@dailyexcelsior.com", "name": "Daily Excelsior", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptians", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Egyptians"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajj", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Hajj"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pilgrim", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Pilgrim"}}, {"uri": "8184631840", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "04:22:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T04:22:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T04:21:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/at-least-550-haj-pilgrims-died-mostly-due-to-heat-say-arab-diplomats/article68306707.ece", "title": "At least 550 haj pilgrims died, mostly due to heat, say Arab diplomats", "body": "Diplomats on Tuesday said at least 550 pilgrims died during the haj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nPilgrims commence the final rites of Haj as Muslims celebrate Eid al-Adha\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman. The new deaths bring the total reported so far by multiple countries to 577, according to an AFP tally. The diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nThe haj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nHeat stress\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, Egypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was collaborating with Saudi authorities on search operations for Egyptians who had gone missing during the haj.\n\nWhile a ministry statement said \"a certain number of deaths\" had occurred, it did not specify whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress but have not updated that figure since Sunday and have not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them Indonesians.\n\nAFP journalists in Mina, outside Mecca, on Monday saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the haj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the haj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the haj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official haj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the haj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP on Tuesday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's haj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\"\n\nThey died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the haj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the haj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nSaudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel said on Tuesday that health plans for the haj had \"been successfully carried out\", preventing major outbreaks of disease and other public health threats, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.\n\nHealth officials \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases,\" SPA said.\n\nRead Comments", "source": {"uri": "thehindu.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hindu"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/death-toll-tops-1-000-after-hajj-marked-by-extreme-heat-afp-tally/article_f573b227-dedf-5b7a-b522-484f5a0bc0a1.html", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat: AFP tally", "body": "The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nbur/th/it\n\nMore from this section\n\nLuvme Hair PartingMax Glueless Wig Voted Best {"uri": "2024-06-395113550", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:50:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:50:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T09:36:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/least-550-die-pilgrimage-mecca-093620375.html", "title": "More than 550 die in searing Saudi heat on Mecca pilgrimage", "body": "More than 550 die in searing Saudi heat on Mecca pilgrimage\n\nJorg Luyken\n\nJune 19, 2024 at 11:36 AM\n\nHundreds have died in chaotic scenes at the hajj pilgrimage to Mecca, as temperatures in the Saudi Arabian desert soared above 50C.\n\nMore than 550 people have now been confirmed dead after this year's pilgrimage - a religious duty for many Muslims - took place under a blistering Gulf summer sun.\n\nAmong the casualties were 232 Egyptian pilgrims, over 60 Jordanians and scores of Tunisians, diplomats have said. Deaths have also been reported among pilgrims from Iran and Senegal.\n\nAll the Egyptians who died on the trip suffered from heat stroke, one Arab diplomat told AFP.\n\nSaudi authorities said they have made efforts to reduce the impact of the heat by setting up air conditioned tents and painting the streets between sites white to reflect more sunlight, cutting heat-related deaths by 50 per cent over the past four decades.\n\nHowever, the strength of this year's sun was too overwhelming for many. Witnesses in the city of Mecca this year described seeing motionless bodies lying on the roadside and local emergency services overwhelmed by the number of people in distress.\n\nOn Sunday, Saudi authorities reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress. The figure has not been updated since and they have also not provided information on fatalities.\n\nThe hajj, which ran from Friday to Wednesday, fell during one of the hottest weeks of the year, with local authorities reporting unusually high temperatures.\n\nStudies show that climate change has pushed temperatures in the Gulf desert by up to 0.4C per decade.\n\nThe situation appears to have been exacerbated by the arrival of huge numbers of unregistered visitors, who arrived at the holy site despite with no official hajj visa. This precluded them from accessing the rest stations.\n\nThe Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims, one diplomat said.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time\" and died \"because they had no place\" to take shelter, he said.\n\nSaudi officials advised pilgrims to drink plenty of water, use umbrellas, and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the rituals, including prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours at a time during the hottest part of the day.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them coming from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nThe pilgrimage to Mecca has been the occasion of repeated mass casualty incidents over the years. These have been caused by stampedes, extreme weather, construction failures and disease.\n\nIn 2015, more than 2,000 people died in a stampede near a bridge at the holy site in what is believed to be one of the deadliest hajj events. In the same year a crane collapsed into the Masjid al-Haram mosque, killing more than one hundred.\n\nIn 2023, the pilgrimage also took place in high summer temperatures. At least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries, with the majority being Indonesians, many suffering dehydration and heart failure.\n\nThe final days of the annual hajj coincide with Muslims around the world celebrating the Eid al-Adha holiday.\n\nBroaden your horizons with award-winning British journalism. {"uri": "8184977955", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "09:01:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T09:01:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T09:00:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://sarajevotimes.com/at-least-550-pilgrims-died-during-the-hajj/", "title": "At least 550 Pilgrims died during the Hajj - Sarajevo Times", "body": "At least 550 pilgrims died during the Hajj, the great Muslim pilgrimage, which took place again this year in high temperatures, writes AFP.\n\nNumerous believers arrived in Mecca to perform the Hajj, one of the obligations that all Muslim believers must perform once in their life, provided they are physically able to make the journey to the birthplace of the Prophet Muhammad and provided they have sufficient financial resources.\n\nPermits to Mecca are allocated based on quotas per country.\n\nPilgrims from Egypt died the most\n\nOf the 550 deceased pilgrims, at least 323 were from Egypt. Most of them succumbed to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats told AFP.\n\n\"Egyptians died because of the heat,\" said one of the diplomats, adding that the total figure came from a hospital mortuary in the Al-Muaisem district of Makkah.\n\nDiplomats say at least 60 Jordanians have died.\n\nThe new deaths increase the total number reported so far in several countries to 577, according to AFP.\n\nDiplomats said the total death toll at the Al-Muaisem morgue, one of the largest in Makkah, was 550.\n\nSaudi authorities: 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress are being treated\n\nEarlier yesterday, the Egyptian Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced that Cairo is cooperating with Saudi authorities in search operations for Egyptians who went missing during the Hajj.\n\nAlthough the ministry's statement said there had been a \"certain number of deaths\", it did not say whether Egyptians were among them.\n\nSaudi authorities reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress, but did not update that figure as of Sunday and did not provide information on deaths.\n\nLast year, around 240 pilgrims from various countries died during the Hajj, most of them Indonesians.\n\nIn Mecca at the beginning of the week, the temperature was higher than 50 degrees\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate disruption, according to a Saudi study published last month.\n\nThe study says that every decade the temperature in the Hajj area rises by 0.4 C. The temperature in Mecca on Monday was 51.8 Celsius, the Saudi National Meteorological Center announced.\n\nAFP reporters in Mina, near Mecca, saw pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads on Monday as volunteers handed out cold drinks and quick-melting ice cream to help cool them down.\n\nSaudi officials advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid sun exposure during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many Hajj rites, including the Mount Arafat prayer that took place on Saturday, involve spending several hours outdoors during the day.\n\nSome pilgrims said they saw motionless bodies on the road and emergency services seemed overwhelmed at times.\n\nAbout 1.8 million pilgrims participated in the Hajj this year, of which 1.6 million are from abroad, {"uri": "8186239390", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:12:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:12:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T03:12:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://newsable.asianetnews.com/india/68-indians-among-600-dead-during-hajj-pilgrimage-confirms-saudi-diplomat-gcw-sfczed", "title": "68 Indians among 600 dead during Hajj pilgrimage, confirms Saudi diplomat", "body": "A diplomat in Saudi Arabia said on Wednesday that 68 Indian nationals died during the hajj pilgrimage this year marked by searing heat, bringing the overall tally to more than 600. \"We have around 68 verified deaths. Some are the result of natural causes, and there were a lot of elderly pilgrims. We presume that some of them are caused by the weather,\" the diplomat told AFP while remaining anonymous.\n\nThe new toll comes after two Arab diplomats told AFP on Tuesday that 550 deaths had been recorded during the hajj, one of the five pillars of Islam that all Muslims with the means must perform at least once.\n\nThe Arab diplomats stated that this number included 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, with one stating that almost all of the Egyptian deaths were \"caused by heat.\"\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nAn AFP count indicates that there have been 645 confirmed deaths to date. Over 200 pilgrims were reported deceased last year, the majority of them were from Indonesia. Saudi Arabia recorded more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone, but it has not released any statistics on deaths.\n\nThe diplomat who confirmed the Indian fatalities said there were also some Indian pilgrims missing, but he declined to provide an exact number. \"This happens every year... We can't say that it is abnormally high this year,\" he said.\n\nFor the past several years the hajj has fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer. {"uri": "8187279829", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:14:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:14:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:13:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.khaleejtimes.com/world/gulf/haj-2024-death-toll-exceeds-1000-due-to-extreme-heat", "title": "Haj 2024: Death toll exceeds 1,000 due to extreme heat", "body": "The death toll from this year's Haj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported on Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who passed away, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe Haj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Makkah.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the Haj through irregular channels.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Makkah this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nEgyptian officials were visiting hospitals to obtain data on Egyptian pilgrims and help those still alive to get medical care, the foreign ministry said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"However, there are large numbers of Egyptian citizens who are not registered in Haj databases, which requires double the effort and a longer time to search for missing persons and find their relatives,\" the ministry said.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally, told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. {"uri": "2024-06-395849398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:51:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:51:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:51:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/hajj-pilgrim-death-toll-passes-1000-after-brutal-50c-heatwave-hit-worlds-largest-gathering-of-muslims-in-saudi-arabia/", "title": "Hajj pilgrim death toll passes 1,000 after brutal 50C heatwave hit world's largest gathering of Muslims in Saudi Arabia", "body": "The death toll at the hajj pilgrim has exceeded 1,000, according to reports, as a brutal heatwave has seen temperatures topping 50C at the world's biggest gathering of Muslims in Saudi Arabia.\n\nHorrifying pictures show bodies being covered and left in the street after they fell victim to the soaring temperatures, while many others suffered severe heatstroke and had to be urgently rushed inside.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims make up more than half of those who have perished, with many unable to access air-conditioned facilities and help from authorities.\n\nThe new deaths reported today include 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nA British Imam described the scenes as 'harrowing' and said that it was impossible for pilgrims to walk through the streets and not to see people suffering from the heat.\n\nA man, affected by the scorching heat, is helped by a member of the Saudi security forces as Muslim pilgrims arrive to perform the symbolic 'stoning of the devil' ritual during the annual hajj pilgrimage in Mina on June 16, 2024\n\nA man, suffering from apparent heatstroke, is helped by another Muslim pilgrim earlier this week\n\nMuslim pilgrims use umbrellas to shade themselves from the sun as they arrive at the base of Mount Arafat, also known as Jabal al-Rahma or Mount of Mercy, during the hajj pilgrimage\n\n'There are so many stories from the pilgrims who are with me about what they saw in the streets, particularly last Sunday,' he told the BBC on Sunday.\n\n'As you were walking, you could not walk 20 yards except you would see someone struggling in the heat.\n\n'People were doing whatever they could to shade themselves, they were taking water from kind individuals who were giving them towels, they were taking shade in hotel receptions.\n\n'It was harrowing at times, I've never seen so many people struggle collectively.'\n\nHe went on to say that while authorities had been on hand to help, they need to learn lessons from the awful scenes caused by the extreme heat, made worse by overcrowding.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities\n\nMuslim pilgrims walk under mist dispensers, which Saudi authorities have set up to try to keep people cool\n\n'I think the Saudi authorities perhaps do need to start thinking about controlling the numbers of how many pilgrims come each and every year,' the British Imam said.\n\n'With climate change, with the fact that the pilgrimage happens in the summer months, they really need to look into this in more detail.'\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun, with curfews reportedly put in place at camps telling people not to leave their tents during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime\n\nFortunately in the coming years the Hajj, the date of which comes 11 days earlier in the Islamic calendar every year, is set to fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nMuslim devotees walk around the Kaaba, Islam's holiest shrine, at the Grand Mosque in Saudi Arabia's holy city of Mecca on June 13, 2024\n\nPilgrim deaths are reported every year, not only due to heat but also the difficulty of the walk and the sheer amount of people who undertake it.\n\nThe deadliest incident ever recorded at the pilgrimage was in 2015, when a stampede in the Mina camp killed over 2,400 pilgrims. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede.\n\nA separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at Hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.", "source": {"uri": "expressdigest.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "expressdigest.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187081398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:09:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:09:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:07:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/death-toll-tops-1000-after-haj-marked-by-extreme-heat-afp-tally/article68312224.ece", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after haj marked by extreme heat: AFP tally", "body": "The death toll from this year's haj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 Egyptians who passed away, 630 were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\n68 Indians among over 600 to die due to heat during Haj pilgrimage\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe haj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the haj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nAt least 550 haj pilgrims died, mostly due to heat, say Arab diplomats\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the haj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nBurials begin\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP.\n\n\"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats told AFP on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves.\n\n\"The burial is done by the Saudi authorities. They have their own system so we just follow that,\" said one diplomat, who pointed out that his country was working to notify loved ones of the dead as best it could.\n\nThe other diplomat said that given the number of fatalities it would be impossible to notify many families ahead of time, especially in Egypt which accounts for so many of the dead.\n\n'Extreme danger'\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year various countries reported more than 300 deaths during the haj, mostly Indonesians.\n\nThe timing of the haj moves back about 11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar, meaning that next year it will take place earlier in June, potentially in cooler conditions.\n\nA 2019 study by the journal Geophysical Research Letters said because of climate change, heat stress for haj pilgrims will exceed the \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052 and 2079 to 2086, \"with increasing frequency and intensity as the century progresses\".\n\nHosting the haj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's official title includes the words \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\", in Mecca and Medina.\n\nThe haj has been the scene of a number of stampedes and fires over the years, most recently in 2015 when a stampede during the \"stoning the devil\" ritual in Mina, near Mecca, killed up to 2,300 people in the event's mostly deadly disaster.\n\nRead Comments", "source": {"uri": "thehindu.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hindu"}, "Death toll tops 1,000 after hajj marked by extreme heat: AFP tally", "body": "The death toll from this year's hajj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe hajj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nMore from this section Japan: Torrential Rains Cause Flooding They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, {"uri": "8184732015", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:01:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:01:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:58:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/over-500-hajj-pilgrims-died-in-saudis-mecca-due-to-severe-heat/articleshow/111103743.cms", "title": "Over 500 Hajj pilgrims died in Saudi's Mecca due to severe heat", "body": "At least 550 pilgrims died from extreme heat during this year's Hajj, with temperatures reaching 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at Mecca's Grand Mosque. Egyptians accounted for the highest casualties, totaling 323 deaths, primarily from heat-related illnesses. Saudi officials treated over 2,000 pilgrims for heat stress. The pilgrimage is increasingly impacted by climate change, as temperatures rise by 0.4 degrees Celsius per decade in ritual areas.At least 550 pilgrims lost their lives during this year's Hajj due to severe heat, Arab diplomats disclosed. The Saudi national meteorology center recorded temperatures soaring to 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at Mecca's Grand Mosque on Monday.\n\nThe highest casualties were Egyptians, with 323 succumbing primarily to heat-related illnesses. According to a diplomat, \"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat,\" except for one who was fatally injured in a minor crowd crush. The total death toll was confirmed from Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighborhood morgue.\n\nBesides Egyptians, approximately 60 Jordanians also perished during the pilgrimage, contributing to a total reported death toll of 577 from various countries, as per AFP's count. Diplomats reiterated that the Al-Muaisem morgue, among Mecca's largest, recorded 550 deaths.\n\nSaudi authorities reported treating over 2,000 pilgrims for heat stress, although updated figures on fatalities haven't been released since Sunday.\n\nDespite Saudi advisories urging pilgrims to use umbrellas, stay hydrated, and avoid sun exposure during peak heat, many Hajj rituals necessitate prolonged outdoor exposure. Witness accounts mentioned seeing motionless bodies along roadsides and overwhelmed ambulance services.\n\nAccording to a recent Saudi study, the Hajj pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, with temperatures in the ritual areas rising by 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) per decade.\n\nSaudi authorities reported that approximately 1.8 million pilgrims participated in the Hajj this year, with 1.6 million coming from overseas.\n\nEvery year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the Hajj without obtaining official visas in order to save money, which poses greater risks because these unofficial pilgrims cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the Hajj route.\n\nAn AFP interview with one diplomat on Tuesday indicated that the high number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims significantly contributed to the Egyptian death toll.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials announced they had expelled hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the Hajj.\n\nOther countries such as Indonesia, Iran, and Senegal also reported deaths during this year's Hajj.\n\n(Inputs from agencies)", "source": {"uri": Among the deceased, 323 persons were Egyptians, who succumbed to heat-related illness, AFP reported citing Arab diplomats.\n\n\"All of the Egyptians died due to the heat,\" one of the diplomats said, adding that only one person died after he sustained fatal injuries during a crowd crush. He said the death toll has been reported by the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nALSO READ: India-Canada Ties: Days After Meeting PM Modi In Italy, Trudeau Says He Sees 'Opportunity' To Engage With New Indian Govt\n\nAs many as 60 Jordanians are also among the 550 pilgrims who lost their lives, up from the tally of 41 released by the authorities earlier.\n\nAs per the Saudi study, the people in the area are reeling under acute heat. The temperature, where rituals are performed, has been surging by 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade. On Monday, the temperature hit 51.8 degrees Celsius at the Mecca Mosque, the Saudi National Meteorology Centre said.\n\nEgypt's foreign ministry said Cairo was working with Saudi authorities to ascertain the whereabouts of Egyptians who had gone missing during the hajj. The ministry has however said there were heat-related deaths but did not specify whether Egyptians were among the deceased.\n\nThe authorities in Saudi have been treating over 2,000 pilgrims for heat stress. {"uri": "8185679282", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:52:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:52:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:51:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://tnp.straitstimes.com/news/world/loved-ones-search-missing-pilgrims-after-haj-heat-deaths", "title": "Loved ones search for missing pilgrims after haj heat deaths", "body": "RIYADH - Friends and family of missing haj pilgrims searched hospitals and pleaded online for news on June 19, fearing the worst after hundreds died during the annual rites in Saudi Arabia.\n\nArab diplomats on June 18 told AFP at least 550 pilgrims died in 2024, the majority due to heat-related illnesses after temperatures reached 51.8 deg C in Mecca, Islam's holiest city.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people attended the pilgrimage.\n\nMrs Mabrouka Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on June 15 at Mount Arafat, her husband, Mohammed, told AFP on June 18.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official haj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool off after hours of outdoor prayers, her husband said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now, I don't have a clue.\"\n\nHe is far from the only one desperate for information.\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe searchers include family and friends of Egyptian pilgrim Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, unaccounted for since June 15.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger the Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nThe haj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years, the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published in May, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 deg C each decade.\n\nThe figure of 550 dead provided by diplomats on June 18 came from the hospital morgue in Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, one of the biggest in the city.\n\nIt includes 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, said the Arab diplomats who briefed AFP on the figures, one of whom noted that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on June 16 alone.\n\nIn 2023, more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the haj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nThis has become easier since 2019, when Saudi Arabia introduced a general tourism visa, said Mr Umer Karim, an expert on Saudi politics at the University of Birmingham.\n\n\"Before, the only people who could have done that were residents of the kingdom, and they know the situation,\" he said.\n\n\"For these tourist visa guys, it's like being on the migrant route without any idea of what to expect.\"\n\nEven pilgrims who have official permits can be vulnerable, including Egyptian pilgrim Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, 70, who has been missing since June 15.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\n\"We've searched for her from door to door and we have not found her until now,\" said the friend, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"We know many who are still searching for their family members and relatives and they are not finding them, or if they are finding them they are finding them dead,\" the friend added. - AFP", "source": {"uri": "tnp.straitstimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New Paper"}, {"uri": "8186852294", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:48:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:48:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:47:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13550299/Hajj-pilgrim-death-toll-1000-brutal-50C-heatwave-Muslims-Saudi-Arabia.html", "title": "Hajj pilgrim death toll passes 1,000 after brutal 50C heatwave", "body": "Unregistered pilgrims make up more than half of those who have died in the heat\n\nThe death toll at the hajj pilgrim has exceeded 1,000, according to reports, as a brutal 50C heatwave hit the world's biggest gathering of Muslims in Saudi Arabia.\n\nHorrifying pictures show bodies being covered and left in the street after they fell victim to the soaring temperatures, while many others suffered severe heatstroke and had to be urgently rushed inside.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims make up more than half of those who have perished, with many unable to access air-conditioned facilities and help from authorities as a result.\n\nThe new deaths reported Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nA British Imam described the scenes as 'harrowing' and said that it was impossible for pilgrims to walk through the streets and not to see people suffering from the heat.\n\nA man, affected by the scorching heat, is helped by a member of the Saudi security forces as Muslim pilgrims arrive to perform the symbolic 'stoning of the devil' ritual during the annual hajj pilgrimage in Mina on June 16, 2024\n\nA man, suffering from apparent heatstroke, is helped by another Muslim pilgrim earlier this week\n\nMuslim pilgrims use umbrellas to shade themselves from the sun as they arrive at the base of Mount Arafat, also known as Jabal al-Rahma or Mount of Mercy, during the hajj pilgrimage\n\n'There are so many stories from the pilgrims who are with me about what they saw in the streets, particularly last Sunday,' he told the BBC on Sunday.\n\n'As you were walking, you could not walk 20 yards except you would see someone struggling in the heat.\n\n'People were doing whatever they could to shade themselves, they were taking water from kind individuals who were giving them towels, they were taking shade in hotel receptions.\n\n'It was harrowing at times, I've never seen so many people struggle collectively.'\n\nHe went on to say that while authorities had been on hand to help, they need to learn lessons from the awful scenes caused by the extreme heat, made worse by overcrowding.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities\n\nMuslim pilgrims walk under mist dispensers, which Saudi authorities have set up to try to keep people cool\n\n'I think the Saudi authorities perhaps do need to start thinking about controlling the numbers of how many pilgrims come each and every year,' the British Imam said.\n\n'With climate change, with the fact that the pilgrimage happens in the summer months, they really need to look into this in more detail.'\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nFortunately in the coming years the Hajj, the date of which comes 11 days earlier in the Islamic calendar every year, is set to fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nMuslim devotees walk around the Kaaba, Islam's holiest shrine, at the Grand Mosque in Saudi Arabia's holy city of Mecca on June 13, 2024\n\nPilgrim deaths are reported every year, not only due to heat but also the difficulty of the walk and the sheer amount of people who undertake it.\n\nThe deadliest incident ever recorded at the pilgrimage was in 2015, when a stampede in the Mina camp killed over 2,400 pilgrims. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede.\n\nA separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest The report showed that more than half of those who died were unregistered worshippers who performed the hajj pilgrimage in extreme heat this year.\n\nThe new deaths reported on Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAround 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once. The figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses, reported AFP.\n\nThe dates and timings of the hajj are determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, and once again, it fell during the sweltering summer of Saudi Arabia. Earlier this week, weather agencies reported a temperature of over 51 degrees Celsius in the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nWhile this year the Saudi authorities cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims for hajj, it was reported that many of them still participated in the pilgrimage without proper permits. Since unregistered pilgrims did not have access to air-conditioned areas and other facilities, they were the most susceptible to the heatwave.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe main cause of death for majority of the pilgrims was the extreme heat, which triggered complications linked to high blood pressure, cardiovascular issued and other problems.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia,
