{"uri": "8185966460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:24:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:24:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:20:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2024/jun/19/a-deadly-toll-as-an-intense-heat-grips-saudi-arabi/", "title": "A deadly toll as an intense heat grips Saudi Arabia", "body": "Dozens of people have died amid scorching temperatures during the annual hajj pilgrimage to the holy city of Mecca in Saudi Arabia, according to reports from official media in Europe, the Middle East and Africa.\n\nWith forecasts saying that temperatures would top 113 degrees Fahrenheit, or 45 degrees Celsius, on Tuesday, Saudi officials issued advisories to pilgrims urging them to stay hydrated, minimize outdoor activities, and carry umbrellas to block direct sunlight.\n\nWhile Saudi Arabia had not reported deaths, news reports from a number of countries whose faithful went to the hajj suggested that the heat had proved deadly.\n\nOn Sunday, Jordan's official news agency said 14 pilgrims had died from exposure to extreme sun and heat. On Wednesday, the agency said burial permits had been issued for 41 Jordanian pilgrims in Mecca, but did not provide details on the causes of death.\n\nTunisia's Foreign Ministry said at least 35 Tunisians had died, the state-run Agence Tunis Afrique Presse reported Tuesday, noting the \"sharp rise in temperatures\" and \"scorching sun\" that had accompanied the hajj.\n\nAt least 13 people from India's Kerala state died performing hajj, according to Sathyapalan C., a local official, while the Russian state news agency TASS reported the deaths of four citizens from \"natural causes related to health and age.\" Three pilgrims from Senegal also died, according to a statement from the country's Foreign Ministry, without citing a cause of death.\n\nAnd Egypt's Foreign Ministry said consular staff in Saudi Arabia were working \"around the clock\" to help facilitate burials and searches for missing Egyptian pilgrims, without giving a number. Egypt's Ministry of Immigration has set up an \"operations room\" amid numerous distress calls about missing relatives, the State Information Service said in a statement. It added that officials were visiting hospitals and medical centers in Saudi Arabia to search for any missing pilgrims and to assist with repatriating the dead.\n\nSaudi ministries did not immediately respond to questions about the reports of deaths.\n\nMuslims travel to Mecca from around the world each year to perform the five-day pilgrimage, which ends Wednesday. The hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam; all Muslims who are financially and physically able must perform the ritual at least once in their lives.\n\nMore than 1.8 million people made the pilgrimage this year, according to the Saudi General Authority for Statistics, with 1.6 million coming from abroad.\n\nThe first hajj took place in 632. The pilgrimage is now one of the world's largest Muslim gatherings. Over the years, it has been plagued by a number of calamities, including stampedes, fires and outbreaks of disease. A stampede on a bridge in 2006 killed more than 300 people and another in 2015 killed more than 2,200 people.\n\nMany pilgrims, who are often older, have also experienced heat stress in recent years, with scores dying from the heat. Saudi authorities had taken measures to reduce the risk of heat stress, including setting up hydration stations and using water mist sprays to cool the air.\n\nOn Tuesday, Saudi officials billed this year's hajj season a \"success,\" with state media reporting that the health minister, Fahd al-Jalajel, expressed \"particular satisfaction with the fact that there were no outbreaks or other public health threats despite the significant number of pilgrims and the challenges posed by high temperatures.\"\n\nThe authorities also cited \"advanced cooling systems\" and the \"consistent availability\" of water for pilgrims for ensuring a \"smooth and secure hajj for all.\"", "source": {"uri": "spokesman.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Spokesman Review"}, "authors": [], some Indian pilgrims missing, but he declined to provide an exact number.\n\nThe news about Indian casualties came amid friends and family searching for missing pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8\u00b0C (125\u00b0F) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on {"uri": "8184877302", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:51:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:51:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:51:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://in-cyprus.philenews.com/international/at-least-550-pilgrims-die-during-hajj-amid-scorching-temperatures/", "title": "At least 550 pilgrims die during Hajj amid scorching temperatures", "body": "At least 550 pilgrims died during this year's Hajj in Saudi Arabia, with the majority succumbing to extreme heat, according to Arab diplomats.\n\nThe annual pilgrimage, which took place from July 14-16, coincided with the region's peak summer season, where temperatures soared to 51.8\u00b0C in Mecca.\n\nDiplomats speaking anonymously to Agence France-Presse (AFP) on July 18 stated that at least 323 Egyptian pilgrims died from the heat, with one additional fatality from crowd trampling. They attributed the total death toll to a morgue in Mecca's Al-Muaisem district, which reportedly received around 550 bodies.\n\nAn independent count by AFP suggests 577 deaths during the pilgrimage, though the cause for all fatalities remains unclear. The Egyptian Ministry of Foreign Affairs confirmed investigating missing Egyptians and a \"certain number of deaths\" on the same day.\n\nSaudi authorities reported providing care to roughly 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heatstroke but did not specify fatalities. The diplomats also mentioned at least 60 Jordanian deaths, with Jordanian authorities previously issuing permits for burying 41 pilgrims in Mecca.\n\nThe Hajj, a mandatory pilgrimage for able-bodied Muslims, is increasingly impacted by climate change. A recent Saudi study indicates a 0.4\u00b0C temperature rise every decade at pilgrimage sites. While Saudi authorities advised pilgrims on sun protection, hydration, and avoiding peak heat hours, many ceremonies occurred during the day.\n\nAccording to the diplomats, the high number of Egyptian deaths is attributed partly to a lack of permits, which restricts access to essential resources like food, water, and shelter. Deaths of pilgrims from Tunisia, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, and other nations were also reported.\n\nApproximately 1.8 million pilgrims participated in this year's Hajj, with over 1.6 million being {"uri": "2024-06-395840862", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:44:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:44:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:19:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/tragic-death-toll-rises-to-over-1000-as-hajj-pilgrims-battle-extreme-50c-heatwave-in-saudi-arabia/", "title": "\"Tragic Death Toll Rises to Over 1,000 as Hajj Pilgrims Battle Extreme 50C Heatwave in Saudi Arabia\" - Internewscast Journal", "body": "The death toll at the hajj pilgrim has exceeded 1,000, according to reports, as a brutal heatwave has seen temperatures topping 50C at the world's biggest gathering of Muslims in Saudi Arabia.\n\nHorrifying pictures show bodies being covered and left in the street after they fell victim to the soaring temperatures, while many others suffered severe heatstroke and had to be urgently rushed inside.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims make up more than half of those who have perished, with many unable to access air-conditioned facilities and help from authorities.\n\nThe new deaths reported today include 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nA British Imam described the scenes as 'harrowing' and said that it was impossible for pilgrims to walk through the streets and not to see people suffering from the heat.\n\n'There are so many stories from the pilgrims who are with me about what they saw in the streets, particularly last Sunday,' he told the BBC on Sunday.\n\n'As you were walking, you could not walk 20 yards except you would see someone struggling in the heat.\n\n'People were doing whatever they could to shade themselves, they were taking water from kind individuals who were giving them towels, they were taking shade in hotel receptions.\n\n'It was harrowing at times, I've never seen so many people struggle collectively.'\n\nHe went on to say that while authorities had been on hand to help, they need to learn lessons from the awful scenes caused by the extreme heat, made worse by overcrowding.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\n'I think the Saudi authorities perhaps do need to start thinking about controlling the numbers of how many pilgrims come each and every year,' the British Imam said.\n\n'With climate change, with the fact that the pilgrimage happens in the summer months, they really need to look into this in more detail.'\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun, with curfews reportedly put in place at camps telling people not to leave their tents during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime\n\nFortunately in the coming years the Hajj, the date of which comes 11 days earlier in the Islamic calendar every year, is set to fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nPilgrim deaths are reported every year, not only due to heat but also the difficulty of the walk and the sheer amount of people who undertake it.\n\nThe deadliest incident ever recorded at the pilgrimage was in 2015, when a stampede in the Mina camp killed over 2,400 pilgrims. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede.\n\nA separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at Hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8186489440", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "06:59:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T06:59:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T06:57:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://in-cyprus.philenews.com/international/more-than-900-hajj-pilgrims-reported-dead-as-temperatures-heat-51-8c/", "title": "More than 900 Hajj pilgrims reported dead as temperatures heat 51.8C", "body": "At least 922 pilgrims have died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Mecca, with scorching temperatures and heat exhaustion blamed for many fatalities.\n\nThe figure is based on tallies from various countries reported to the Agence France-Presse (AFP), as Saudi authorities haven't released official death tolls.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP the number of deaths among Egyptians alone had surged to at least 600, up from 300 a day earlier. The intense heat, reaching 51.8 degrees Celsius on Monday, proved especially dangerous for elderly and infirm pilgrims.\n\nConcerns mounted as social media platforms overflowed with pleas for information about missing pilgrims. Mabrouka bint Salem Shushana, a Tunisian woman in her 70s, has been missing since Saturday, according to her husband. He said her lack of an official Hajj permit meant she couldn't access air-conditioned areas to cool down.\n\nThe Hajj, a mandatory pilgrimage for able-bodied Muslims with the means, is often held during the sweltering Saudi summer due to its alignment with the Islamic lunar calendar. A Saudi study revealed rising temperatures in the region, with a 0.4-degree Celsius increase per decade.\n\nFatalities were also reported by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, and Iraq's Kurdistan region. Authorities haven't confirmed causes of death in all cases.\n\nA separate Arab diplomat said Jordanian officials were searching for 20 missing pilgrims, while 80 others initially reported missing were found in hospitals. An Asian diplomat reported around 68 deaths from India, with others unaccounted for.\n\nSaudi Arabia reported over 2,700 cases of heat exhaustion on Sunday alone. Last year, over 200 pilgrims, mostly Indonesians, died during the Hajj.\n\nOne Arab diplomat confirmed that many deceased Egyptians were unregistered pilgrims.\n\nThe rising number of unregistered pilgrims attempting the Hajj through unofficial channels due to expensive permits was a growing concern, according to Umer Karim, a Saudi politics expert. {"uri": "8185439369", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:58:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:58:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:57:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/19/world/europe/hajj-deaths-mecca-heat.html", "title": "A Deadly Toll as an Intense Heat Grips Saudi Arabia", "body": "Dozens of people have died amid scorching temperatures during the annual hajj pilgrimage to the holy city of Mecca in Saudi Arabia, according to reports from official media around the Middle East and Africa.\n\nWith forecasts saying that temperatures would top 113 degrees Fahrenheit, or 45 degrees Celsius, on Tuesday, Saudi officials issued advisories to pilgrims urging them to stay hydrated, minimize outdoor activities, and carry umbrellas to block direct sunlight.\n\nWhile Saudi Arabia had not reported deaths, news reports from a number of countries whose faithful went to the hajj suggested that the heat had proven deadly.\n\nOn Sunday, Jordan's official news agency said that 14 pilgrims had died from exposure to extreme sun and heat. On Wednesday, the agency said that burial permits had been issued for 41 Jordanian pilgrims in Mecca, but did not provide details on the causes of death.\n\nTunisia's Foreign Ministry said at least 35 Tunisians had died, the state-run Agence Tunis Afrique Presse reported on Tuesday, noting the \"sharp rise in temperatures\" and \"scorching sun\" that had accompanied the hajj.\n\nThree pilgrims from Senegal also died, according to a statement from the country's Foreign Ministry, without citing a cause of death. And Egypt's Foreign Ministry said consular staff in Saudi Arabia were working \"around the clock\" to help facilitate burials and searches for missing Egyptian pilgrims, without giving an number.\n\nSaudi ministries did not immediately respond to questions about the reports of deaths.\n\nMuslims travel to Mecca from around the world each year to perform the five-day pilgrimage, which ends Wednesday. The hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam -- and all Muslims who are financially and physically able must perform the ritual at least once in their lives.\n\nMore than 1.8 million people made the pilgrimage this year, according to the Saudi General Authority for Statistics -- with 1.6 million coming from abroad.\n\nThe first hajj took place in 632. The pilgrimage is now one of the world's largest Muslim gatherings. Over the years, it been plagued by a number of calamities, from stampedes to fires to outbreaks of disease. A stampede on a bridge in 2006 killed more than 300 people and another in 2015 killed more than 2,200 people.\n\nMany pilgrims, who are often older, have also experienced heat stress in recent years, with scores dying from the heat.\n\nOn Tuesday, Saudi officials billed this year's hajj season a \"success,\" with state media reporting that the health minister, Fahd al-Jalajel expressing \"particular satisfaction with the fact that there were no outbreaks or other public health threats despite the significant number of pilgrims and the challenges posed by high temperatures.\"\n\nThe authorities also cited \"advanced cooling systems\" and the \"consistent availability\" of water for pilgrims for ensuring a \"smooth and secure hajj for all.\"\n\nHwaida Saad contributed reporting.", They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat said on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the Haj's climax. The diplomat said the main cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, new fatalities were confirmed on Thursday by Pakistan and Indonesia.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has so far recorded 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told reporters. \"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, raised its death toll to 183, according to the ministry of religious affairs, compared with 313 deaths recorded last year.\n\nDeaths have also been confirmed by Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. In many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nMeanwhile friends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nTwo diplomats said that on Thursday that Saudi authorities had begun the burial process for dead pilgrims, which involves cleaning up the bodies, putting them in white burial cloth and taking them to be interred in individual graves. -- AFP", "source": {"uri": "omanobserver.om", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8186821605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:30:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:30:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:29:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://en.kabar.kg/news/unbearable-heat-in-saudi-arabia-claims-900-lives-at-hajj/", "title": "Unbearable heat in Saudi Arabia claims 900+ lives at Hajj", "body": "Death toll at the annual Hajj pilgrimage, which were carried out in scorching heat in Saudi Arabia, has surged past 900, TRT World reported.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told the AFP news agency on Wednesday that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\" from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nThe diplomat later added that Egyptian officials in Saudi Arabia had received \"1,400 reports of missing pilgrims\", including the 600 dead.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official Hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said.\n\n\"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now, I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia.\n\n\"The good news is that until now, we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nHouria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim, has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.\n\nThe Hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once. Its timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years, the outdoor rituals have fallen mainly during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP on Wednesday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes, and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions; that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nLast year, more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.", "source": {"uri": "en.kabar.kg", The bodies of 550 deceased people are kept at the mortuary.\n\nEarlier, the authorities had announced that 2000 pilgrims who fell ill due to extreme heat were admitted to the hospital.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day. {"uri": "8186918258", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:29:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:29:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:28:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.dawn.com/news/1840835", "title": "Death toll tops 1,000 after Haj marked by extreme heat", "body": "The death toll from this year's Haj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday, more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported on Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told, around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe Haj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degree Celsius earlier this week at Makkah's Grand Mosque.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the Haj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Makkah earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the Haj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Malaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for pilgrims who are still missing.\n\nOn Wednesday, they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.", "source": {"uri": "dawn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Dawn"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185481555", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:27:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:27:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:26:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/world/2024/0619/1455575-weather/", "title": "At least 600 Egyptians die as heat rises in Saudi Arabia", "body": "An Arab diplomat said that at least 600 Egyptians died during the hajj pilgrimage, citing searing heat that reached 51.8C in Saudi Arabia on Monday.\n\n\"All of the (newly confirmed) deaths were because of the heat as well,\" the diplomat said, after Arab officials earlier reported a figure of at least 323 Egyptian deaths.\n\nDiplomats yesterday said that at least 550 pilgrims died during the hajj, underscoring the gruelling nature of the pilgrimage which again unfolded in scorching temperatures this year.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4Ceach decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8C at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians also died, the diplomats said, up from an official tally of 41 given earlier yesterday by Amman.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj without securing official hajj visas in order to save money, a more dangerous undertaking because these off-the-books pilgrims cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP yesterday said that the Egyptian death toll was \"absolutely\" boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials said they had cleared hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the hajj.\n\nOther countries to report deaths during the hajj this year include Indonesia, Iran and Senegal.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related.\n\nHosting the hajj is a source of prestige for the Saudi royal family, and King Salman's title includes \"Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques\" in the cities of Mecca and Medina.\n\nGreece wildfire outside Athens fanned by strong winds\n\nGreek firefighters and aircraft battled a blaze in the town of Koropi 30 kilometres south of Athens as strong winds fanned the flames and forced residents to flee their homes and businesses.\n\nTraffic was suspended along a main highway connecting Koropito Athens suburbs. One storage facility was on fire and flames crept into a boat dry dock and across fields of dry grass and olive trees, images on local TV showed.\n\nThere were no reports of deaths or injuries, a fire service official told Reuters. Civil protection and authorities evacuated two nearby villages.\n\n\"Its a very difficult day today. We have a new fire breaking out every 10 minutes,\" Fire Service spokesman Vassilis Vathrakogiannis said in a televised message.\n\nWildfires are common in the Mediterranean nation but they have become more devastating as summers have become hotter and drier, which scientists relate to climate change.\n\nOn Tuesday more than 40 fires broke out across the country, the fire service said.\n\nIt was not immediately clear what caused today's blaze. Four firefighting planes, six helicopters, dozens of fire engines and more than 50 firefighters were dispatched to the scene, the fire service official said.\n\nMuch of the Athens area has had no rain for weeks, leaving large areas bone dry. Volunteers and professional firefighters dragged hoses over blackened fields in 35C heat. Smoke filled the sky and was driven sideways by strong wind gusts.\n\n\"I saved my home at the last moment. It all happened so fast,\" a resident whose face was blackened by smoke told local Skai TV channel.\n\nAfter forest fires last year forced 19,000 people to flee the island of Rhodes and killed 20 in the northern mainland, Greece has scaled up its preparations this year by hiring more staff and increasing training.", "source": {"uri": "rte.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "RTE.ie"}, "authors": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13551285/Horrifying-video-shows-bodies-loaded-trucks-Hajj-pilgrims-passing-streets-1-000-died-searing-50C-heat-religious-gathering-Mecca.html", "title": "Horrifying video shows scores of corpses amid 50C heatwave at Hajj", "body": "Horrifying video has shown corpses being loaded onto trucks and people passing out in the streets as more than 1,000 people have died amid severe heat at the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.\n\nWorshippers have faced temperatures of more than 50C over recent days, with many succumbing to heat made worse by the huge crowds as some 1.8 million Muslims gathered for the annual event.\n\nPictures shared online appear to show bodies being covered and left in the street after they fell victim to the blistering heatwave, while many others suffered severe exhaustion and had to be urgently stretchered to safety.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims make up more than half of those who perished, according to a count by AFP, with many unable to access air-conditioned facilities and help from authorities.\n\nA British Imam described the scenes as 'harrowing' and said that it was impossible for pilgrims to walk through the streets and not to see people suffering from the scorching heat.\n\nView this post on Instagram\n\nA post shared by Mekke_Medine\ud83d\udcab (@yasemin_0761)\n\nPilgrims have been pictured lying in the street surrounded by empty water bottles amid the deadly heatwave in Saudi Arabia\n\nCrews have been seen carrying away corpses amid the deadly heatwave in Saudi Arabia\n\nCorpses have been filmed being loaded onto vehicles as the death toll has reportedly surpassed 1,000 at this year's pilgrimage\n\nPilgrims have been seen being carried away on stretchers amid the deadly heatwave\n\nHorrific pictures show bodies in the streets being taken away by health workers at the hajj\n\nElderly people in particular have been struggling with the heat during the pilgrimage\n\nExhausted pilgrims are seen desperately trying to stay cool in the blistering heat\n\nA man, affected by the scorching heat, is helped by a member of the Saudi security forces as Muslim pilgrims arrive to perform the symbolic 'stoning of the devil' ritual during the annual hajj pilgrimage in Mina on June 16, 2024\n\nA man, suffering from apparent heatstroke, is helped by another Muslim pilgrim earlier this week\n\nParamedics carry a pilgrim for a medical check after he fell down due to a heat stroke in Mina, near the holy city of Mecca\n\nShocking video shared on social media shows trolleys carting scores of covered corpses to be buried, with what appear to be family members gathered around.\n\nOfficials in hi-vis jackets have also been pictured carrying pilgrims away on stretchers after they were unable to complete the lengthy route.\n\nElderly people were filmed struggling in the heat, with worried bystanders tending to those who were less able to deal with the extreme conditions.\n\nIn one video, a woman is seen surrounded by friends who are pouring water into her mouth in a bid to cool her down.\n\n'There are so many stories from the pilgrims who are with me about what they saw in the streets, particularly last Sunday,' a British Muslim told the BBC.\n\n'As you were walking, you could not walk 20 yards except you would see someone struggling in the heat.\n\n'People were doing whatever they could to shade themselves, they were taking water from kind individuals who were giving them towels, they were taking shade in hotel receptions.\n\n'It was harrowing at times, I've never seen so many people struggle collectively.'\n\nMuslim pilgrims use umbrellas to shade themselves from the sun as they arrive at the base of Mount Arafat, also known as Jabal al-Rahma or Mount of Mercy, during the hajj pilgrimage\n\nPilgrims struggling with the soaring heat are seen resting against a wall\n\nRescuers carry away a man, affected by the scorching heat, on a stretcher\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities\n\nA man shades his head with a cardboard box as he browses his phone while standing next to other women in Saudi Arabia's holy city of Mecca on June 20, 2024\n\nHe went on to say that while authorities had been on hand to help, they need to learn lessons from the awful scenes caused by the extreme heat, made worse by overcrowding.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the pilgrimage to Mecca this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThis places these off-the-books pilgrims at risk as they cannot access air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities along the hajj route.\n\n'I think the Saudi authorities perhaps do need to start thinking about controlling the numbers of how many pilgrims come each and every year,' the British Imam said.\n\n'With climate change, with the fact that the pilgrimage happens in the summer months, they really need to look into this in more detail.'\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nA Muslim pilgrim splashes water on his head to cools off at the base of Saudi Arabia's Mount Arafat\n\nMuslim pilgrims walk under mist dispensers, which Saudi authorities have set up to try to keep people cool\n\nMuslim pilgrims arrive to perform the symbolic 'stoning of the devil' ritual as part of the hajj pilgrimage\n\nA Turkish Muslim pilgrim pours cold water from a bottle on her head to cool off as she waits in Saudi Arabia's holy city of Mecca on June 20, 2024\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun, with curfews reportedly put in place at camps telling people not to leave their tents during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThe new deaths reported include 58 from Egypt , according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP earlier in the week said that the Egyptian death toll was 'absolutely' boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nIn the coming years the Hajj, the date of which comes 11 days earlier in the Islamic calendar every year, is set to fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month\n\nPilgrims in Mecca have been pictured pouring cold water over their heads to cool off\n\nMuslim devotees walk around the Kaaba, Islam's holiest shrine, at the Grand Mosque in Saudi Arabia's holy city of Mecca on June 13, 2024\n\nPilgrim deaths are reported every year, not only due to heat but also the difficulty of the walk and the sheer amount of people who undertake it\n\nPilgrim deaths are reported every year, not only due to heat but also the difficulty of the walk and the sheer amount of people who undertake it.\n\nThe deadliest incident ever recorded at the pilgrimage was in 2015, when a stampede in the Mina camp killed over 2,400 pilgrims. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede.\n\nA separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume.\"\n\nThe diplomat also said that a few pilgrims from India were missing, AFP reported. However, he did not provide an exact number. \"This happens every year...We can't say that it is abnormally high this year,\" he said.\n\nTemperatures rose to as high as 51.8 degree Celsius in Mecca on Monday, Reuters reported citing a Saudi state-run news agency.\n\nThe Hajj pilgrimage is one of the five key obligations of Islam that Muslims with the means to do so are expected to fulfil at least once in their lifetime. The dates of the Hajj are determined by the position of the moon according to the Islamic lunar calendar. The ritual lasts several days and ends in Mecca.\n\nOn Tuesday, two other unidentified Saudi diplomats told AFP that 550 deaths were recorded during this year's Hajj pilgrimage. However, the news agency's final tally put the number at 645.\n\nThree hundred and twenty-three of them were Egyptians and 60 were from Jordan, the diplomats said. Nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of [the] heat\", AFP quoted the diplomats as saying.\n\nAuthorities from Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region also confirmed that their citizens had died during the pilgrimage, AFP reported. The causes of all the deaths were not specified.\n\nThe pilgrimage this year began on June 14 and ended on Wednesday. More than 1.8 million Muslims performed the Hajj this year. This included more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries.\n\nThe Saudi government reported over 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" during the day on Sunday.", "source": {"uri": "scroll.in", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.geo.tv/latest/550013-577-hajj-pilgrims-succumb-to-saudi-arabias-intense-heat-this-year", "title": "577 Hajj pilgrims 'succumb' to Saudi Arabia's intense heat this year", "body": "Pilgrims say they saw motionless bodies on roadside during Hajj.\n\nAt least 577 Hajj pilgrims have died in the holy city of Makkah in Saudi Arabia due to the country's soaring temperatures in the past few days, AFP reported.\n\nAccording to the total figure that came from the hospital morgue in Makkah's Al Muaisem neighbourhood, at least 550 pilgrims died during the Hajj pilgrimage this year due to the intense heat.\n\nHowever, the total number of deaths reported by multiple countries so far brought the tally to 577, according to AFP.\n\nTwo Arab diplomats, coordinating their countries' responses, revealed that among the pilgrims who died, 323 were Egyptians, most of whom succumbed to heat-related illnesses.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\", except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said.\n\nThe diplomats maintained that at least 60 Jordanians also died, adding to the official tally of 41 given earlier on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nThe Hajj pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4\u00b0C each decade.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8\u00b0C at the Grand Mosque in Makkah on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nAt least 240 pilgrims were reported dead by various countries last year, most of them were Indonesians.\n\nPilgrims in Mina, outside Makkah, on Monday were seen pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to use umbrellas, drink plenty of water and avoid exposure to the sun during the hottest hours of the day.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nAround 1.8 million pilgrims {"uri": "2024-06-395035067", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:03:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:03:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:00:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.omanobserver.om/article/1155265/world/region/loved-ones-search-for-missing-as-haj-death-toll-tops-900", "title": "Loved ones search for missing as Haj death toll tops 900", "body": "Pilgrims circle the Kaaba as they perform Tawaf at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Tuesday. -- Reuters\n\nRIYADH: Friends and family searched for missing Haj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat said that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed said.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official Haj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia. \"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat said that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat said there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" he said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia. -- AFP", "source": {"uri": "omanobserver.om", "dataType": "news", "title": "Oman She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and {"uri": "8184587514", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:37:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:37:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:35:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/world/over-550-hajj-pilgrims-die-as-temperature-breaches-50-degrees-in-mecca-2582994", "title": "Over 550 Hajj pilgrims die as temperature breaches 50 degrees in Mecca", "body": "Riyadh: Amid blistering heat in Saudi Arabia, at least 550 pilgrim have died while on the annual Hajj pilgrimage. According to authorities, most of the visitors who lost their lives were from Egypt. The temperatures rose to 51 degrees Celsius at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nOf the 550 pilgrims, at least 323 were Egyptians and most of them died due to heat-related illnesses, AFP reported citing two Arab diplomats. \"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush,\" one of the diplomats said, adding the total figure came from the hospital morgue in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood of Mecca.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians were also among those killed during the annual pilgrimage, according to the diplomats. According to Iranian state news outlet as many as 11 Iranians have died and 24 were hospitalised during the pilgrimage. The deceased also included 35 Tunisian citizens, as per a Tunisian news agency. The Arab diplomats said the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, was 550.\n\nSaudi national meteorology center said temperatures soared on Monday as high as 51.8 degrees Celsius at the Grand Mosque in Mecca. Many of the rituals are performed outdoors and on foot, creating challenges especially among the elderly.\n\n\"Of course, it is something very hard and tiring. The temperature is abnormal compared to the past years and this affects us a lot,\" Ahmed Al-Baradie, an Egyptian pilgrim, said on Monday after finishing his second symbolic stoning.\n\nA 2019 study by Geophysical Research Letters said that as temperatures rise in arid Saudi Arabia due to climate change, pilgrims performing Hajj will face \"extreme danger\".\n\nSaudi health ministry have so far treated more than 2,000 pilgrims who suffered from heat-related illness. The ministry, however, has not updated the figure since Sunday and also not provided information on fatalities.\n\nAll Muslims are required to make the Hajj, one of the five pillars of Islam, once in their lives if they are physically and financially able to do so. More than 1.83 million Muslims took part in the Hajj this year, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to Saudi Hajj {"uri": "2024-06-396141376", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:59:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:59:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:17:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/saudi-arabia-shuts-pilgrims-air-151742715.html", "title": "Saudi Arabia shuts pilgrims out of air-conditioned areas as over 1000 die in extreme heat", "body": "Saudi Arabia shuts pilgrims out of air-conditioned areas as over 1000 die in extreme heat\n\nJames Crisp\n\nJune 20, 2024 at 5:17 PM\n\nSaudi Arabian officials shut illegal pilgrims out of air-conditioned rest areas in Mecca during extreme heat that killed more than 1,000 people on hajj.\n\nMore than half of the deaths were among unregistered worshippers who had not bought costly permits for the annual pilgrimage, which all Muslims with the means are encouraged to complete at least once.\n\nThe death toll from this year's hajj exceeded 1,000, diplomats said, as temperatures hit 125.2F (51.8C) in Mecca this week.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat said on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nTens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj, which involves rituals performed in the summer heat, through irregular channels every year because they can't afford the official permits.\n\nWithout official permits, they were not able to access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for missing pilgrims. They searched hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nFootage on social media showed bodies on the streets and one abandoned on the pavement covered with a sheet of metal. Other videos showed shrouded corpses lined up to be removed.\n\nOne witness said bodies lay on the side of the road near Mina, just outside Mecca, covered with the white ihram cloth - a simple garb worn by pilgrims - until medical vehicles arrived.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, although it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nIn one clip shared on social media, a pilgrim blamed the \"extremely poor management by the Saudi government\" for the chaotic scenes.\n\n\"Ambulances are just standing there doing nothing,\" he said in the film shot in Mina, which is five miles from Mecca and is famous for its tents housing pilgrims during the pilgrimage.\n\nHe said there had been no buses or taxis, which forced pilgrims to walk on foot through the oven-like temperatures.\n\nWilayet Mustafa, a Pakistani pilgrim, said: \"It was so harsh and the people cannot bear that type of heat.\"\n\nCarl-Friedrich Schleussner, a scientific advisor at German institute Climate Analytics, believes the climate crisis is one of the reasons for the heat at the site worsening.\n\n\"The hajj has been conducted in a certain way for more than 1,000 years now, and it's always been a hot climate but... the climate crisis is adding to the severity of the climate conditions,\" said Mr Schleussner.\n\nBroaden your horizons with award-winning British journalism. Some are because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told AFP.\n\nAt least 550 haj pilgrims died, mostly due to heat, say Arab diplomats\n\nThe new toll comes after two Arab diplomats told AFP on Tuesday that 550 deaths had been recorded during the haj, one of the five pillars of Islam that all Muslims with the means must perform at least once.\n\nThat figure included 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, the Arab diplomats said, and one specified that nearly all the Egyptians died \"because of heat\".\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nThe total reported dead so far is 645, according to an AFP tally.\n\nLast year more than 200 pilgrims were reported dead, most of them from Indonesia.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, though it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nThe diplomat who confirmed the Indian fatalities said there were also some Indian pilgrims missing, but he declined to provide an exact number. \"This happens every year... We can't say that it is abnormally high this year,\" he said.\n\n\"It's somewhat similar to last year but we will know more in the coming days.\"\n\nFor the past several years the haj has fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area where rituals are performed are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) {"uri": "2024-06-396115136", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:34:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:34:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:17:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/saudi-arabia-shuts-pilgrims-air-151742385.html", "title": "Saudi Arabia shuts pilgrims out of air-conditioned areas as over 1000 die in extreme heat", "body": "Saudi Arabian officials shut illegal pilgrims out of air-conditioned rest areas in Mecca during extreme heat that killed more than 1,000 people on hajj.\n\nMore than half of the deaths were among unregistered worshippers who had not bought costly permits for the annual pilgrimage, which all Muslims with the means are encouraged to complete at least once.\n\nThe death toll from this year's hajj exceeded 1,000, diplomats said, as temperatures hit 125.2F (51.8C) in Mecca this week.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat said on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nTens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj, which involves rituals performed in the summer heat, through irregular channels every year because they can't afford the official permits.\n\nWithout official permits, they were not able to access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\nFriends and family members have been searching for missing pilgrims. They searched hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst during the scorching temperatures.\n\nFootage on social media showed bodies on the streets and one abandoned on the pavement covered with a sheet of metal. Other videos showed shrouded corpses lined up to be removed.\n\nOne witness said bodies lay on the side of the road near Mina, just outside Mecca, covered with the white ihram cloth - a simple garb worn by pilgrims - until medical vehicles arrived.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not provided information on fatalities, although it reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nIn one clip shared on social media, a pilgrim blamed the \"extremely poor management by the Saudi government\" for the chaotic scenes.\n\n\"Ambulances are just standing there doing nothing,\" he said in the film shot in Mina, which is five miles from Mecca and is famous for its tents housing pilgrims during the pilgrimage.\n\nHe said there had been no buses or taxis, which forced pilgrims to walk on foot through the oven-like temperatures.\n\nWilayet Mustafa, a Pakistani pilgrim, said: \"It was so harsh and the people cannot bear that type of heat.\"\n\nCarl-Friedrich Schleussner, a scientific advisor at German institute Climate Analytics, believes the climate crisis is one of the reasons for the heat at the site worsening.\n\n\"The hajj has been conducted in a certain way for more than {"uri": "8186139977", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "01:07:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T01:07:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T01:06:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/news/india/over-600-pilgrims-dead-including-68-indians-during-hajj-in-saudi-arabia-says-diplomat-11718844281642.html", "title": "Over 600 pilgrims dead, including 68 Indians, during Hajj in Saudi Arabia, says diplomat | Today News", "body": "As many as 68 Indian nationals died during the Hajj pilgrimage this year, which was marked by searing heat and intense high temperatures. The overall death toll has risen to 600.\n\nAs many as 68 Indian nationals died during the Hajj pilgrimage this year, which was marked by searing heat and intense high temperatures, said people familiar with the matter on Wednesday. The overall death toll stands at more than 600.\n\n\"We have confirmed around 68 dead... Some are because of natural causes, and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" the diplomat told AFP on the condition of anonymity.\n\nThe Indian government has not issued any official statement on the death toll during the Hajj pilgrimage yet.\n\nThe updated death toll was reported after two Arab diplomats informed AFP on Tuesday that 550 fatalities had been recorded during the hajj. This pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam, is an obligation for all Muslims who have the financial and physical capability to undertake it at least once in their lifetime.\n\nAccording to the Arab diplomats, the total included 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, with one diplomat noting that almost all the Egyptians succumbed \"due to heat.\"\n\nDeaths have also been reported by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many instances, the authorities have not disclosed the exact causes.\n\nLast year, most of the 200 dead pilgrims were from Indonesia. Saudi Arabia has not disclosed the number of fatalities but reported over 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\n\"This happens every year... We can't say that it is abnormally high this year. It's somewhat similar to last year but we will know more in the coming days,\" the diplomat who confirmed the Indian fatalities said. He also stated that some Indian pilgrims were missing too, but refused to provide an exact number.\n\nIn recent years, the hajj has occurred during the intensely hot Saudi summer. A Saudi study published last month indicated that temperatures in the region where the rituals are conducted increase by 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) every decade.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8184600908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:52:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:52:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:50:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://bdnews24.com/world/786afd72c289", "title": "Hundreds die of extreme heat on Hajj, reports say", "body": "A Muslim pilgrim pours water on his head to cool down from the heat, as he takes part in the annual haj pilgrimage in Mina, Saudi Arabia, June 17, 2024. REUTERS/Mohammed Torokman\n\nHundreds of visitors have died during the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Makkah amid scorching heat, according to press reports and foreign ministries.\n\nAt least 550 people have died on hajj, diplomats told French outlet Agence France Presse (AFP) on Tuesday. Three hundred and twenty-three of the dead were Egyptians, most of whom perished due to heat-related illness, AFP reported, citing two Arab diplomats.\n\nReuters was not able to immediately verify those numbers.\n\nStampedes, tent fires and other accidents have caused hundreds of deaths during hajj to Saudi Arabia in the past 30 years. The pilgrimage began on Friday.\n\nSaudi state TV said temperatures rose on Monday as high as 51.8 degrees Celsius (125.2 Fahrenheit) in the shade at the Grand Mosque in Makkah.\n\nA 2024 study by the Journal of Travel and Medicine found that rising global temperatures may outpace strategies to deal with the heat. A 2019 study by Geophysical Research Letters said that as temperatures rise in arid Saudi Arabia due to climate change, pilgrims performing hajj will face \"extreme danger\".\n\nThirty-five Tunisian citizens have died during the hajj, Tunisian news agency Tunis Afrique Presse said on Tuesday.\n\nMany of those deaths were due to extreme heat, family members said on social media, as other families continued to search for missing relatives in Saudi hospitals.\n\nThe Jordanian foreign ministry said it had issued 41 burial permits for Jordanian pilgrims on Tuesday. Earlier, the ministry said at least six Jordanian citizens died of heat stroke during the hajj.\n\nEleven Iranians have died and 24 were hospitalised during the pilgrimage, Iranian state news outlet IRINN said on Tuesday without giving the causes of death.\n\nThree Senegalese citizens also died during hajj, Agence de Presse S\u00e9n\u00e9galaise, said on Monday.\n\nOne hundred and forty-four Indonesian citizens died during the pilgrimage, Indonesian health ministry data showed on Tuesday. The data did not specify if any of the deaths were due to heat stroke.\n\nPHYSICAL EXERTION\n\nThe hajj is an annual pilgrimage that millions of Muslims make to Makkah to perform religious rites as taught by the Prophet Mohammad to his followers 14 centuries ago.\n\nA Saudi health official, speaking to Reuters on Monday, before many of the reports of deaths were issued, said that authorities had not noticed any unusual fatalities among Muslim pilgrims amid the extremely high temperatures.\n\nThe ministry had so far treated more than 2,700 pilgrims who suffered from heat-related illness, he added.\n\n\"Hajj is a difficult task, so you have to exert efforts and perform the rituals even in the conditions of heat and crowding,\" an Egyptian pilgrim told Reuters on Sunday.\n\nPilgrims used umbrellas to protect themselves from the sun, as Saudi authorities warned pilgrims to stay hydrated and avoid being outdoors during the hottest hours between 11am (0800 GMT) and 3pm.\n\nHajj, one of the largest mass gatherings in the world, is a once-in-a-lifetime duty for able-bodied Muslims who can afford it. It will end on Wednesday.\n\nMore than 1.8 million pilgrims were expected to take part this year, according to the Saudi General Authority for Statistics.", "source": {"uri": "bdnews24.com", They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat told AFP on Thursday, referring to Saturday's day-long outdoor prayers that marked the hajj's climax.\n\nThe diplomat said the principal cause of death among Egyptian pilgrims was the heat, which triggered complications related to high blood pressure and other issues.\n\nOn Wednesday they scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst {"uri": "2024-06-395057456", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:31:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:31:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.thedailystar.net/news/world/middle-east/news/scorching-heat-hajj-death-toll-surges-past-900-3637116", "title": "Scorching Heat: Hajj death toll surges past 900", "body": "Friends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims yesterday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Makkah, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP yesterday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nA second Arab diplomat told AFP yesterday that Jordanian officials were looking for 20 missing pilgrims, though 80 others who were initially reported missing were located in hospitals.\n\nAn Asian diplomat told AFP there were \"around 68 dead\" from India and that others were missing.\n\n\"Some (died) because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. Read less\n\nIn shocking news, over 550 Hajj pilgrims have lost their lives because of scorching temperatures. The news was confirmed by the diplomats on Tuesday, highlighting the challenging conditions of the pilgrimage. According to the Saudi national meteorology center, the temperature at the Grand Mosque in Mecca reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) on Monday.\n\nRead more: Heatwave In India: Hill Destinations That Are Unusually Hot This Year\n\nA significant number of the deceased, 323 Egyptians, succumbed primarily to heat-related illnesses, according to Arab diplomats.More from Travel NewsVideo of a tiger attacking tourist vehicle in Jim Corbett goes viralMountaineers conquer unclimbed peak in Pakistan's Gilgit-Baltistan regionTaiwan considers extending visa-on-arrival for Indian travellersMore News\n\nThe figure of 550 deaths was reported from the hospital morgue in Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, underscoring the toll of the extreme weather conditions on pilgrims. Jordan also recorded an increase in fatalities, with at least 60 deaths reported, surpassing an earlier official count of 41.\n\n10 visa-free countries famous for their rich heritage FacebookTwitterPintrest\n\nIn total, the reported deaths from multiple countries have now reached 577, as per an AFP tally based on diplomatic reports. The Al-Muaisem morgue alone accounted for 550 fatalities, making it one of the largest single sources of data on pilgrim deaths during this year's Hajj.\n\nRead more: Goa: No ban on entry to low-risk waterfalls; to remain accessible to public this year\n\nThe Hajj, one of Islam's five pillars, mandates that all Muslims capable of doing so undertake the pilgrimage at least once in their lifetime. Climate change has increasingly affected the Hajj, with a recent Saudi study noting a rise in temperatures of 0.4 degrees Celsius per decade in the area where rituals are performed.\n\nOn Monday, temperatures soared to 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca, according to the Saudi national metrology centre, exacerbating conditions for the pilgrims.\n\nEgypt's foreign ministry stated earlier on Tuesday that it was collaborating with Saudi authorities on locating missing Egyptians, while also acknowledging a number of deaths without specifying details. Saudi officials have reported treating over 2,000 pilgrims for heat-related stress, though specific updates on fatalities have not been provided since Sunday.\n\nLast year, various countries reported 240 pilgrim deaths during the Hajj, primarily among Indonesian nationals. Journalists at Mina, near Mecca, observed pilgrims attempting to cool off by pouring water over themselves, with volunteers distributing cold beverages and ice cream.\n\nDespite Saudi advisories to use umbrellas, stay hydrated, and minimise sun exposure during peak heat hours, many Hajj rituals require prolonged outdoor activities, such as prayers on Mount Arafat. Reports from pilgrims included sightings of motionless bodies and overwhelmed ambulance services, underscoring the challenging conditions faced by participants.\n\nThis year, approximately 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the Hajj, with 1.6 million travelling from abroad, according to Saudi authorities, highlighting the event's global significance and the immense logistical challenges involved in Earlier on Monday, the temperature here was recorded at a whopping 51.8 degrees Celsius.\n\nAmong the dead, 'at least 600' are from Egypt alone, according to an Arab diplomat cited by AFP. An Egyptian diplomat reportedly noted that these pilgrims significantly contributed to Egypt's death toll, citing service breakdowns in camps.\n\nThis year, approximately 1.8 million pilgrims participated in the Hajj, including 1.6 million from abroad. The pilgrimage's rituals often require extended outdoor stays, increasing exposure to intense heat.\n\nEarlier this month, Saudi officials removed hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca.\n\nCountries such as Indonesia, Iran, and Senegal also reported deaths among pilgrims, with many not specifying if they were heat-related.\n\nMeanwhile, Saudi Health Minister Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Jalajel reported successful health measures during the Hajj, including over 5,800 virtual consultations for heat-related issues, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nDespite advisories for pilgrims to use umbrellas, stay hydrated, and avoid sun exposure during peak hours, the extreme heat has posed significant challenges.\n\nClimate change is intensifying the heat challenges during the Hajj, with May 2024 being the hottest May on record globally. {"uri": "8186355693", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "05:12:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T05:12:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T05:10:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/world/68-indians-among-over-600-hajj-pilgrims-killed-in-saudi-heat-12752482.html", "title": "68 Indians among over 600 Hajj pilgrims killed in Saudi heat", "body": "At least 68 Indian nationals were killed as suspected heat-related deaths during the Hajj pilgrimage soared past 600, a Saudi Arabian diplomat said.\n\n\"We have confirmed around 68 deaths... Some were because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" news agency AFP reported, quoting the diplomat, who wished to remain anonymous.\n\nThis new count follows reports from two Arab diplomats on Tuesday, who indicated that 550 pilgrims had died during the Hajj. Among these were 323 Egyptians and 60 Jordanians, with heat being a primary cause of death, according to a Saudi diplomat.\n\nAdditional fatalities have been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, although in many cases, the cause of death has not been specified. According to AFP, the death toll has reached 645.\n\nOver 200 pilgrims reportedly died last year, with most of the victims being Indonesians. This year, Saudi Arabia did not provide specific information on the fatalities but reported more than 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion\" on Sunday alone.\n\nAn Indian diplomat mentioned that some Indian pilgrims were missing, though he did not give an exact number. He noted that this is a recurring issue each year and did not consider the number of fatalities to be unusually high compared to previous years. \"It's somewhat similar to last year but we will know more in the coming days.\"\n\nThe Hajj has taken place during the hot Saudi summer for several years. {"uri": "8184759207", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:21:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:21:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T06:20:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/world/middle-east/2024/06/19/more-than-550-pilgrims-die-at-mecca-as-temperatures-reach-50-degrees/", "title": "More than 550 pilgrims die at Mecca as temperatures reach 50 degrees", "body": "Temperatures reached 51.8 degrees Celsius in the shade of the Grand Mosque\n\nHundreds of visitors have died during the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca amid scorching heat.\n\nAt least 550 people have died on hajj, diplomats have confirmed. Three hundred and twenty-three of the dead were Egyptians, most of whom perished due to heat-related illness.\n\nTemperatures reached 51.8 degrees Celsius in the shade of the Grand Mosque in Mecca, Saudi state TV said on Monday.\n\nThe hajj is an annual pilgrimage that millions of Muslims make to Mecca to perform religious rites as taught by the Prophet Mohammad to his followers 14 centuries ago.\n\nStampedes, tent fires and other accidents have caused hundreds of deaths during hajj to Saudi Arabia in the past 30 years. The pilgrimage began on Friday.\n\n[ Israel threatens 'all out war' against Hizbullah as cross-border conflict escalates ]\n\nA 2024 study by the Journal of Travel and Medicine found that rising global temperatures may outpace strategies to deal with the heat.\n\nAmong the dead were 144 Indonesian citizens, 35 Tunisian citizens, 41 Jordanian citizens, 11 Iranians and many more were hospitalised.\n\nA Saudi health official, speaking to Reuters on Monday, before many of the reports of deaths were issued, said that authorities had not noticed any unusual fatalities among Muslim pilgrims amid the extremely high temperatures.\n\nThe ministry had so far treated more than 2,700 pilgrims who suffered from heat-related illness, he added.\n\n\"Hajj is a difficult task, so you have to exert efforts and perform the rituals even in the conditions of heat and crowding,\" an Egyptian pilgrim told Reuters on Sunday.\n\nPilgrims used umbrellas to protect themselves from the sun, as Saudi authorities warned pilgrims to stay hydrated and avoid being outdoors during the hottest hours between 11am and 3 pm.\n\nHajj, one of the largest mass gatherings in the world, is a once-in-a-lifetime duty for able-bodied Muslims who can afford it. It will end on Wednesday.\n\nMore than 1.8 million pilgrims were expected to take part this year, according to the Saudi General Authority for Statistics. - Reuters", "source": {"uri":
