{"uri": "8185874727", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:45:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:45:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:44:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://pointblanknews.com/pbn/news/loved-ones-search-for-missing-as-hajj-death-toll-passes-900/", "title": "Loved ones search for missing as hajj death toll passes 900 - Pointblank News", "body": "Relatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\n- Searing heat -\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years, mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, {"uri": "8185689583", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:00:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:00:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:59:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://globalnews.ca/news/10575627/hajj-death-toll-heat-wave-saudi-arabia-mecca/", "title": "More than 550 hajj pilgrims die as intense heat wave grips Saudi Arabia - National | Globalnews.ca", "body": "Upwards of 550 pilgrims have died, mostly due to heat-related illness, during this year's five-day hajj pilgrimage to Mecca, one of Islam's holiest cities.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, nor offered any official causes of death for the deceased. Hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nSeveral countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nThe hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam, and all Muslims with the ability to do so are required to complete it at least once. Even in the best conditions, it often comes with a high death toll.\n\nEach year, the hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be older with pre-existing health conditions, the paper added.\n\nAccording to the Saudi hajj authorities, more than 1.83 million Muslims are taking part in this year's hajj, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries.\n\nEach year, tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj without securing the required official visa in an attempt to save money. This cost-saving measure doesn't allow them access to the air-conditioned facilities along the hajj route, making the trek that much more dangerous.\n\nA diplomat, speaking to AFP on Tuesday, said a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims \"absolutely\" boosted this year's death toll. It's estimated that at least 320 Egyptian pilgrims have died on the route.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater for future pilgrimages. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when weather is cooler.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed more than 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an Associate Press count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.", {"uri": "8187405135", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:43:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:43:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:41:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/hajj-death-toll-passes-1000-33074111", "title": "Hajj death toll passes 1,000 as Mecca hit by brutal 50C heatwave", "body": "Harrowing pictures show bodies covered and left in the streets as they fall victim to soaring temperatures\n\nHajj, known to be the world's biggest gathering of Muslims has seen a staggering death toll of 1,000 pilgrims as a brutal heatwave sees temperatures soaring past 50C.\n\nHarrowing pictures show bodies covered and left in the streets as they fall victim to soaring temperatures, whilst many others suffer severe heatstroke. Those pilgrims who are unregistered have suffered the worst, being unable to access air-conditioned facilities and help from authorities.\n\nThe latest death toll includes 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered. A British Imam said the scene were \"harrowing\" and pilgrims walking through the streets were being confronted with those suffering from the heat. He told the BBC: \"There are so many stories from the pilgrims who are with me about what they saw in the streets, particularly last Sunday.\"\n\nAdding: \"As you were walking, you could not walk 20 yards except you would see someone struggling in the heat. People were doing whatever they could to shade themselves, they were taking water from kind individuals who were giving them towels, they were taking shade in hotel receptions.It was harrowing at times, I've never seen so many people struggle collectively.\"\n\nThe Imam blamed overcrowding, but also said authorities needed to learn lessons from what had happened. Around 1.8million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities. Each year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the hajj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly procedures for official hajj visas.\n\nThe pilgrimage is increasingly affected by climate change, according to a Saudi study published last month that said temperatures in the area where rituals are performed were rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade. Temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said.\n\nSaudi officials had advised pilgrims to protect themselves from the sun by using umbrellas, drinking plenty of water and avoiding exposure to the sun, with curfews reportedly put in place at camps telling people not to leave their tents during the hottest hours of the day. But many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime. In the coming years the date for Hajj, will come 11 days earlier in the Islamic calendar every year and will eventually fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nPilgrim deaths are reported every year with the heat and overcrowding being the main concern. The deadliest incident ever recorded at the pilgrimage was in 2015, when a stampede in the Mina camp killed over 2,400 pilgrims. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people. {"uri": "8185186397", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "11:13:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T11:13:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:13:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.newarab.com/news/550-hajj-pilgrims-die-heatwave-amid-negligence-accusations", "title": "550 Hajj pilgrims die in heatwave amid negligence accusations", "body": "At least 550 Muslim worshippers, around 323 of them were Egyptians, have died during the annual Hajj pilgrimage to Mecca, as temperatures approached 50 degrees.\n\nMost of the deaths were related to the extreme temperatures, the officials added, while one person died after sustaining fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush.\n\nTemperatures have pushed well past 40 degrees Celsius during the pilgrimage that around 1.8 million Muslims took part in this year.\n\nEgypt's ministry of foreign affairs issued an official statement saying they are making intensive efforts, in cooperation with Saudi authorities, to search for missing Egyptian citizens.\n\nIt added that the Egyptian embassy in Riyadh sent a consular mission to Mecca and the Muslim holy sites to monitor developments and conduct field visits to hospitals and medical centres where Egyptians have been taken.\n\nHajj is one of the five pillars of Islam, and a compulsory act of worship for all Muslims who are financially and physically able to complete it, at least once in their lifetime.\n\nAccording to The New Arab's Arabic language sister publication, Al-Araby Al-Jadeed, thousands of Egyptians took part in the pilgrimage this year without having an official Hajj visa, which further added to the overcrowding and limited their access to air-conditioned facilities provided by Saudi authorities.\n\nThe report added that many went on normal visit visas, typically used by people to see family members residing in the country, then went on to perform Hajj. The pilgrimage is performed mostly outdoors and takes days to complete.\n\nThe ministry says it has started to take measures to transport the bodies of the deceased back to Egypt.\n\nSocial media users shared videos from the pilgrimage, showing many people laying down on the floor after struggling to cope in the heat. The videos showed some of the people receiving medical attention.\n\nThe kingdom has implemented heat mitigation measures, including climate-controlled areas. It distributes water, and offers advice to pilgrims on protecting themselves from the sun.\n\nHowever, Saudi authorities have reported that they have treated over 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress on Sunday. They are yet to provide updated information since then.\n\n'Negligence'\n\nOnline, social media users criticised Saudi authorities, accusing them of negligence of pilgrims.\n\nMany used the Arabic-language hashtag #The_Egyptian_Pilgrims to share images and videos of people struggling in the heat.\n\n\"Hundreds of Egyptian pilgrims died when throwing stones at Jamarat [the ritual stoning of a representation of the devil during the Hajj], and the Saudi government is keeping the disaster a secret. Eyewitnesses say that they saw the bodies of pilgrims dumped in the streets amid the complete absence of medical and ambulance teams,\" one social media user alleged.\n\n\"Pilgrims are not dying from overcrowding but rather from poor organisation and negligence. There have been hundreds of deaths of pilgrims of different nationalities,\" another claimed.\n\nThe New Arab cannot verify any of the allegations.\n\nOthers called it a widespread disaster and used social media platforms to advise others on what to do if they have missing family members, instructing them to have their visa and passport information ready.\n\nAt least 60 Jordanians have also died according to diplomats, an increased from the tally of 14 given on Tuesday by Amman.\n\nIranian Red Crescent chief Pirhossein Koolivand added \"five Iranian pilgrims have lost their lives so far in Mecca and Medina during the hajj this year\", without saying how they died.\n\nHajj is being increasingly affected by climate change, with the UN's intergovernmental panel on climate change warning parts of the Gulf could become uninhabitable by the end of the century.\n\nMore than 10,000 heat-related illnesses were recorded last year, 10 percent of them heat stroke, a Saudi official told AFP this week.\n\nA Saudi study said regional temperatures were rising by 0.4 C each decade, and worsening heat may be outpacing mitigation measures.", "source": {"uri": "newarab.com", "dataType": "news", extreme heat", "body": "RIYADH: The death toll from this year's Haj has exceeded 1,000, an AFP tally said on Thursday (Jun 20), more than half of them unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe new deaths reported on Thursday included 58 from Egypt, according to an Arab diplomat who provided a breakdown showing that of 658 total dead from that country, 630 were unregistered.\n\nAll told around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage, one of the five pillars of Islam which all Muslims with the means must complete at least once.\n\nThe figures have come via official statements or from diplomats working on their countries' responses.\n\nThe Haj, whose timing is determined by the lunar Islamic calendar, fell again this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nThe national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade.\n\nEach year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to perform the Haj through irregular channels as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nSaudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca earlier this month, but it appears many still participated in the main rites which began last Friday.\n\nThis group was more vulnerable to the heat because, without official permits, they could not access air-conditioned spaces provided by Saudi authorities for the 1.8 million authorised pilgrims to cool down after hours of walking and praying outside.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. The Guardian newspaper reported Thursday that more than 1,000 pilgrims from different countries had died.\n\nIn a statement announcing the formation of the crisis unit on the orders of President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi, Egypt's cabinet said 28 deaths had been confirmed from a group of 50,752 officially registered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nMore: As 100 million broil under heat dome, more 'unbearable' temps on the way\n\nThe Egyptian statement gave no toll for unregistered pilgrims, saying Egypt was seeking an accurate inventory of the dead and missing and was coordinating with Saudi counterparts to arrange for the transfer of bodies.\n\nCompanies that had facilitated travel for unregistered pilgrims would be investigated and penalized, the cabinet added.\n\nDangerous heatwaves are scorching cities on four continents as the Northern Hemisphere marks the first day of summer, a sign that climate change may again bring about record-breaking heat that could surpass last summer as the warmest in 2,000 years.\n\nMore: Can you blame heat wave on climate change? Eye-popping numbers suggest so.\n\nCountries around the Mediterranean endured another week of blistering high temperatures that have contributed to forest fires from Portugal to Greece and along the northern coast of Africa in Algeria, according to the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Earth Observatory.\n\nA Reuters witness in Saudi Arabia said that during the pilgrimage thousands of pilgrims had lain on the streets, exposed to the sun, on the climb to Mount Arafat, one of the integral rituals of the journey.\n\nThe bodies of dead pilgrims were later covered with Ihram cloth - a simple garb worn by pilgrims - until medical vehicles arrived, the witness said.\n\nThe fifth pillar of Islam, the hajj is mandatory once in a lifetime for every able-bodied Muslim who can afford it and is the most significant manifestation of Islamic faith and unity. This year's event, which began last Friday, is expected to draw nearly 2 million pilgrims.\n\nClimate scientists have said rising temperatures pose a growing threat to the event, although heat-related Some are because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told AFP.\n\nThe death toll from the holy city of Mecca comes after two Arab diplomats told the news agency that 550 deaths had been recorded during the hajj, one of the five pillars of Islam that all Muslims with the means must perform at least once.\n\nThese deaths have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nEarlier this week, the Saudi Health Ministry reported 2,764 cases of heat stress on the first day of Eid Al Adha and Saudi Health Minister Fahd Al-Jalajel urged pilgrims to avoid peak summer hours (11 AM to 4 PM) when performing their remaining Hajj rituals.\n\nHe had also urged them to avoid direct sun exposure and stay away from hot surfaces, stressing that prevention is key.\n\nThe ministry's spokesperson reported that 2,764 cases of heat stress were treated on the first day of Eid.\n\n\"Pilgrims have undertaken a tremendous journey to perform Hajj,\" said the spokesperson as quoted by Saudi Pres Agency (SPA).\n\n\"Our role is to support them fully. We believe in prevention before treatment. We urge pilgrims to follow safety guidelines, such as using umbrellas during rituals and staying hydrated.\"\n\nThe spokesperson further reassured the public that the overall health of pilgrims remains positive.\n\nNo significant public health challenges or disease outbreaks have been reported. The ministry also reminded pilgrims of symptoms of heat stress and sunstroke, including nausea, headache, excessive sweating, and severe sneezing.\n\nMuscle fatigue from frequent movement and walking long distances is another potential concern. To prevent this, the ministry advises pilgrims to rest after completing each ritual, avoid carrying heavy items, wear comfortable shoes, and drink water before performing rituals.", "source": {"uri": This solemn pilgrimage to Mecca, mandatory for Muslims with the means, has been marred by reports of fatalities primarily attributed to heat-related illnesses. Egyptian and Jordanian pilgrims accounted for a significant number of the casualties, with diplomats confirming that most deaths were due to the extreme heat that swept through the holy sites.\n\nAccording to a report by NDTV, of the 550 fatalities, 323 were Egyptians, and 60 were Jordanians, predominantly succumbing to heat-related conditions during the pilgrimage rituals. The toll highlights the strenuous conditions faced by pilgrims, exacerbated by soaring temperatures that reached a blistering 51.8 degrees Celcius at the Grand Mosque in Mecca. The figures, compiled from the morgue at Mecca's Al-Muaisem neighbourhood, indicate a grim reality despite efforts by Saudi authorities to mitigate health risks during the hajj. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nMore than 550 hajj pilgrims have tragically died in Mecca as temperatures exceed 50C. A virtual hospital \"provided virtual consultations to over 5,800 pilgrims, primarily for heat-related illnesses, enabling prompt intervention and mitigating the potential for a surge in cases\", SPA said.\n\nThe Foreign Office warned: \"Contagious diseases spread quickly, particularly during Hajj and Ramadan. Flu, colds and respiratory problems are common. Prepare for extreme heat. During the summer months, the temperature may exceed 50\u00b0C. Consume adequate liquids and avoid prolonged exposure to direct sunlight.\"\n\nIt added: \"You must have a valid certificate of vaccination against the ACWY strains of meningitis 10 days before arriving for Hajj and Umrah. Some 70 Indians are believed to be among the dead. Saudi state TV said temperatures rose on Monday as high as 51.8 degrees Celsius (125.2 Fahrenheit) in the shade at the Grand Mosque in Mecca.\n\nMany of those deaths were due to extreme heat, family members said on social media, as other families continued to search for missing relatives in Saudi hospitals.\n\nThe haj is an annual pilgrimage that millions of Muslims make to Mecca to perform {"uri": "8185590059", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:45:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:45:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:43:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/relatives-search-missing-saudi-arabia-153622196.html", "title": "Relatives search for missing in Saudi Arabia as hajj death toll tops 900", "body": "Friends and family searched for missing hajj pilgrims on Wednesday as the death toll at the annual rituals, which were carried out in scorching heat, surged past 900.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8187516592", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:09:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:09:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:08:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.asianews.it/news-en/Climate-change-threatens-the-Hajj-as-over-a-thousand-die-from-heat-in-Makkah-60989.html", "title": "SAUDI ARABIA - ISLAM Climate change threatens the Hajj as over a thousand die from heat in Makkah", "body": "Riyadh (AsiaNews) - More than the fears of the war in Gaza and the risks associated with the crowds in the holy places, cause of fatal accidents with heavy tolls in the past, the number one enemy for the faithful in Makkah during the Hajj this year (14-19 June) is the heat.\n\nSo far more than a thousand people have died, AFP reports, based on data provided by various countries. Last year's death toll was around 240.\n\nSaudi authorities have not yet released any official figure, but Egypt is said to have paid the highest price with 658 deaths from heat and heatstroke, but at least 630 were unregistered pilgrims not eligible to participate.\n\nThe religious event has also seen accidents and deaths in the past, as well as outbreaks of communicable diseases like SARS, bird flu, and meningitis.\n\nEvery year, tens of thousands of pilgrims try to perform the Hajj without registering or paying the official permit, which can be costly.\n\nSaudi authorities moved out hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Makkah earlier this month, but many appear to have eluded security checks, joining other pilgrims during the first rites last Friday.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims are more vulnerable to heat and high temperatures because, without an official permit, they cannot access air-conditioned spaces provided by organisers for the more than 1.8 million authorised pilgrims, to cool off after hours of walking and praying outdoors.\n\n\"People were tired after being chased by security forces before Arafat day. They were exhausted,\" one Arab diplomat said today, referring to the outdoor prayer that marked the culmination of the Hajj last Saturday.\n\nAs the leading cause of death, heat can trigger complications like high blood pressure and other cardiovascular problems.\n\nMalaysia, Pakistan, India, Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, and Iraqi Kurdistan have all confirmed fatalities among their citizens.\n\nComplicating things is the fact that this year, Hajj fell during the scorching Saudi summer.\n\nSaudi Arabia's national meteorological centre reported a high of 51.8 degrees Celsius earlier this week at the Grand Mosque in Makkah.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, local temperatures are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius each decade with the future promising even more.\n\nThe Islamic calendar is lunar, so the pilgrimage moves back 10 days each year. Thus, while the Hajj is now moving toward winter, by the 2050s it will coincide with the peak of summer in Saudi Arabia. This could be \"fatal\" as Fahad Saeed, a climate scientist at Pakistan-based Climate Analytics, pointed out.\n\nHeat-related deaths during the major pilgrimage to Makkah are nothing new and have been recorded since the 1400s.\n\nA lack of acclimatisation to higher temperature, intense physical exertion, exposed spaces, and an older population makes pilgrims vulnerable.\n\nMore than 2,000 people suffered from heat stress last year, according to Saudi sources, and the situation will worsen as the planet warms up.\n\nAccording to a 2021 study published in the journal Environmental Research Letters, if the world warms by 1.5\u00b0 Celsius above pre-industrial levels, the risk of heatstroke for pilgrims participating in the Hajj will be five times greater.\n\nThe current deaths are thus a foretaste of things to come for tens of millions of Muslims who will undertake the pilgrimage in the coming decades.\n\n\"The hajj has been conducted in a certain way for more than 1,000 years now, and it's always been a hot climate,\" said Carl-Friedrich Schleussner, a scientific advisor at German institute Climate Analytics. \"But ... the climate crisis is adding to the severity of the climate conditions.\"\n\nHence, some rites, Schleussner notes, like the climb to Mount Arafat have become \"incredibly dangerous to human health.\"", "source": {"uri": "asianews.it", "dataType": "news", Some are because of natural causes and we had many old-aged pilgrims. 600 Egyptian pilgrims have been confirmed dead during the 2024 Hajj pilgrimage in Mecca, Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe deaths were linked to the searing heat that reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) on Monday, June 17.\n\nAccording to The Punch, an Arab diplomat disclosed this to AFP on Wednesday, June 19.\n\n\"All of the (newly confirmed) deaths were because of the heat as well,\"\n\nThe diplomat said after Arab officials earlier reported a figure of at least 323 Egyptian deaths.\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe Guardian reported that family and friends of an Egyptian pilgrim, Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, have flooded Facebook and other social media networks with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nMahmoud was said to be unaccounted for since Saturday, June 15.\n\nA family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said:\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her.\"\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nLegit.ng recalls that the Saudi Ministry of Hajj and Umrah restricted pilgrims from proceeding to the Jamarat Bridge for the stone-throwing ritual.\n\nThe stone-throwing at the devil ritual between 11am and 4pm was halted due to extreme heat.\n\nIn another report, Legit.ng reported that authorities from Jordan and Iran said at least 19 pilgrims from their countries have died during the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia amid soaring temperatures in the region.\n\nJordan's foreign ministry announced that \"Fourteen Jordanian pilgrims have died and 17 others are missing\" while performing hajj rituals.\n\nSeparately, Iranian Red Crescent Chief Pirhossein Koolivand reported that \"Five Iranian pilgrims have lost their lives Some are because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume,\" the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told AFP.\n\nRelatives scoured hospitals and pleaded online for news, fearing the worst after temperatures hit 51.8 degrees Celsius in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, on Monday.\n\nAbout 1.8 million people from all over the world, many old and infirm, took part in the days-long, mostly outdoor pilgrimage, held this year during the oven-like Saudi summer.\n\nAn Arab diplomat said that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\", from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nThe haj is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims with the means must complete it at least once.\n\nIts timing is determined by the Islamic lunar calendar, shifting forward each year in the Gregorian calendar.\n\nFor the past several years the mainly outdoor rituals have fallen during the sweltering Saudi summer.\n\nAccording to a Saudi study published last month, temperatures in the area are rising 0.4 degrees Celsius (0.72 degrees Fahrenheit) each decade.\n\nIn addition to Egypt, fatalities have also been confirmed by Jordan, Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous {"uri": "8187476053", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:36:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:36:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:36:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/1/133039/Egypt-vows-punishment-to-companies-behind-unregistered-pilgrims-travel-after", "title": "Egypt vows punishment to companies behind unregistered pilgrims' travel after Hajj deaths", "body": "CAIRO - 20 June 2024: Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly has stated that an investigation will be launched into the companies responsible for organizing the travel of unregistered Hajj pilgrims following the unfortunate deaths of several Egyptian pilgrims this year.\n\nIn a statement on Thursday, the premier said that these companies resorted to unofficial means to facilitate the pilgrims' travel without providing them with logistical services or adhering to the regulatory frameworks.\n\nHe emphasized that decisive decisions will be taken and severe penalties will be imposed to prevent the repetition of such violations in the future.\n\nBased on the directives of President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi, there is a task force established to monitor and manage the crisis of the Egyptian pilgrims' deaths.\n\nThe crisis task force comprises officials from relevant ministries and authorities.\n\nIts responsibilities include providing support and assistance to the families of the deceased and studying the causes of their deaths, as well as taking measures to prevent its recurrence.\n\nThe Egyptian Hajj mission this year totaled 50,752, with a total of 28 deaths, Madbouly said, citing data from the Ministry of Health. He added that this is the lowest percentage of deaths among Egyptian pilgrims in previous years.\n\nHowever, due to the lack of registered data for unregistered pilgrims with the medical mission, it has been challenging to monitor their health conditions, Madbouly affirmed.\n\nHe stressed that \"anyone who facilitated such irregular travel will be held accountable.\"\n\nMadbouly stressed that a consular task force, under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is currently conducting field visits to hospitals in Saudi Arabia.\n\nThe task force aims to obtain data on Egyptian pilgrims there, whether receiving treatment or deceased, and cross-referencing it with the information provided by the families of those reported missing.\n\nThe Cabinet affirmed the presence of a significant number of Egyptian pilgrims who are not registered in the official Hajj databases.\n\nThis requires additional effort and time to search for the missing individuals and locate their families, the Cabinet added.\n\nFor this reason, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has dedicated emergency rooms that operate around the clock and can be contacted by citizens.\n\nAccording to an Arab diplomat who spoke to Agence France-Presse (AFP), this year's Hajj season has been marred by the deaths of at least 600 Egyptian pilgrims, primarily due to the extremely high temperatures.\n\nThis brings the total deaths among pilgrims this year to more than 900, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomat stated that Egyptian officials in the Kingdom has received 1,400 reports of missing pilgrims.\n\nThe Hajj pilgrimage, which took place in the year 1445 AH, attracted nearly 2 million pilgrims who endured scorching heat.\n\nOn Monday, temperatures in Makkah reached a staggering 52 degrees Celsius, as reported by Saudi Arabia's National Center for Meteorology (NCM).\n\nOne of the diplomats interviewed by AFP emphasized that the significant presence of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims this season has played a substantial role in the high death toll among Egyptians.\n\nThe influx of unregistered pilgrims has resulted in a breakdown of service provision.\n\nAn Egyptian official overseeing the country's Hajj mission stated, \"The presence of irregular pilgrims created immense chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, leading to a collapse in the services provided.\"\n\nHe further explained that the pilgrims were deprived of essential necessities such as food, water, and adequate shelter, which resulted in fatalities due to the extreme heat.", "source": {"uri": "egypttoday.com", One of the diplomats stated, \"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" - barring one, who died from injuries sustained in a minor stampede incident due to overcrowding. About 1.8 million people attended the pilgrimage.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official Haj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool off after hours of outdoor prayers, Mohammed said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now I don't have a clue.\"\n\nHe is far from the only one desperate for information.\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe searchers include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me Out of the total, at least 323 of those who died were Egyptians.\n\nAs per reports given by the media agency AFP, most of the pilgrims succumbed due to heat-related illnesses. Meanwhile, at least 60 Jordanians also died due to the scorching heat.\n\nSo far, the total number of deaths has been reported to be 577. It has crossed the total at the morgue in Al-Muaisem, one of the biggest in Mecca, which was 550.\n\nOn Monday, Saudi authorities issued warnings to pilgrims to avoid the sun and urged them to postpone the rituals till after 4 p.m. (local time).\n\nIslam's holiest city recorded 51.8 degrees Celsius on Monday, while other nearby holy sites recorded 48 degrees Celsius maximum temperature.\n\nSome 1.8 million pilgrims took part in this year's Haj, one of the five pillars of Islam, which began in Mecca on Friday evening amid the blistering heat.\n\nBuses and trains are used {"uri": "8187514830", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:07:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:07:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:06:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://tass.com/society/1806205", "title": "Pilgrims who died in Saudi Arabia mostly performed Hajj illegally  --  Russian mufti", "body": "Rushan Abbyasov emphasized that most of the pilgrims' deaths were due to overexertion caused by the extreme heat\n\nMOSCOW, June 20. /TASS/. The pilgrims who died in Saudi Arabia while performing Hajj, the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca, mostly did so illegally, without Hajj visas, Russian Mufti Rushan Abbyasov told TASS.\n\nEarlier, the Agence France-Press (AFP) news agency reported that over 1,000 pilgrims had died in Saudi Arabia during Hajj, and about 800 people were reported missing. In turn, diplomatic sources told TASS that five Russians were among those dead.\n\n\"According to my information, most of the deaths were caused by illegal pilgrims, who simply stood in the open sun. Legal pilgrims, who paid for their entire trip, were given special tents with all the necessities. These pilgrims [who died] were mostly illegal pilgrims, they came without Hajj visas, so they stayed outside and were exposed to the open sun for a long time. This year, Saudi Arabia is very hot,\" he said.\n\nThe mufti emphasized that most of the pilgrims' deaths were due to overexertion caused by the extreme heat.\n\nHe said that several hundred Russian pilgrims also tried to visit Saudi Arabia illegally. \"Several hundred pilgrims did try to use the so-called 'invitations' to visit cheaper than it is customary for official tour operators. And this year Saudi Arabia has been very harsh in evicting them from Mecca. They took them out of the holy places so that they could not perform the pilgrimage rites, because they violated Saudi legislation by not obtaining all the necessary accreditations, visas and so on,\" Abbyasov pointed out.\n\nThe Hajj is an annual pilgrimage to Mecca that every Muslim is required to make if he or she has the opportunity. {"uri": "2024-06-396322435", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:17:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:17:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:17:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2024/06/363353/government-responds-to-deaths-of-moroccan-pilgrims-during-hajj", "title": "Government Responds to Deaths of Moroccan Pilgrims During Hajj", "body": "Hajj death toll surpasses 1,000, with extreme heat and unregistered worshippers contributing to the staggering figure, including 17 Moroccan pilgrims.\n\nBeni Mellal - The Moroccan government has addressed the tragic deaths of 17 Moroccan pilgrims during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.\n\nIn a press conference following a government council meeting today, government spokesman Mustapha Baitas stated that he does not have specific information regarding the circumstances of the deaths.\n\nBaitas provided a brief comment during his responses to journalists' questions, indicating that other agencies will be responsible for presenting various details on the matter.\n\nThe government spokesman's reserved statement comes amidst angry outcry from Moroccan pilgrims who endured what they described as \"catastrophic conditions\" during the pilgrimage.\n\nAccording to the news outlet \"M\u00e9dias24,\" citing private sources, the number of Moroccan pilgrims who died while performing Hajj rituals this year has reached 17.\n\nThe same outlet clarified that this figure is part of an annual average ranging between 30 and 45 deaths among Moroccan pilgrims each year.\n\nThe Moroccan Hajj delegation this year included 34,000 pilgrims, with 15% of them over the age of 82, a demographic considered most vulnerable to the risk of high temperatures.\n\nMecca experienced a record-breaking temperature of 51.8 degrees Celsius last Monday, according to the Saudi National Center of Meteorology.\n\nA Saudi study published this month indicated that temperatures in the region where the Hajj rituals take place are rising by 0.4 degrees Celsius per decade, increasingly impacting the pilgrimage due to climate change.\n\nSaudi authorities reported that the total number of pilgrims this year reached around 1.8 million, with 1.6 million coming from abroad.\n\nThe death toll from this year's Hajj has surpassed 1,000, according to an AFP tally, with more than half being unregistered worshippers who performed the pilgrimage in extreme heat.\n\nThe Saudi meteorological center reported the record high temperature at the Grand Mosque in Mecca earlier this week.\n\nTens of thousands of pilgrims attempt to join the Hajj each year through irregular channels, as they cannot afford the often costly official permits.\n\nWhile Saudi authorities reported clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month, it appears that many still participated in the main rituals.\n\nRead also: Hajj 1445 Concludes with Farewell Tawaf Ritual\n\n\u00a9 Morocco World News. {"uri": "8187678220", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:37:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:37:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:35:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://therussophile.org/more-than-1000-perish-during-hajj-with-most-deaths-attributed-to-extreme-heat.html/", "title": "More Than 1,000 Perish During Hajj, With Most Deaths Attributed to Extreme Heat - Russia News Now", "body": "More than 1,000 people participating in the Hajj to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, have died as of Thursday as temperatures in the holy city reached 125\u00b0F at the Grand Mosque.\n\nThe tragedy serves as an example of how the climate crisis is making mass gatherings more dangerous, especially in warmer parts of the world. Saudi Arabia is heating 50% faster than the rest of the Northern Hemisphere, and by 2050, The Washington Post and Carbon Plan estimated that temperatures would rise high enough in Mecca to make it dangerous to be in the sun for 182 days a year.\n\n\"Words fail. Words fail,\" the activist group Climate Defiance wrote on social media in response to the deaths.\n\n\"Stop it with your vapid odes to incrementalism. Stop it with your 2050 pledges,\" the group added. \"Humanity is barreling to the brink. Open your eyes!\"\n\n\"For so many, religious rituals are a sacred and central part of their identities,\" the group continued. \"Now merely practicing a faith proves a literal death sentence.\"\n\nMecca is the holiest city in the Islamic religious tradition, and making the Hajj, or pilgrimage, there is one of Islam's Five Pillars. The Hajj always draws hundreds of thousands of people from all over the world, with more than 1.8 million registered pilgrims attending this year. The timing depends on the Islamic calendar, which follows a lunar cycle. In 2024, it fell between June 14 and June 19 in the Gregorian calendar, coinciding with Saudi Arabia's hotter period.\n\n\"The Hajj is considered one of the Five Pillars of Islam, along with belief in Allah, prayer, fasting, and charity. It is intended to be a sacred part of life,\" Climate Defiance wrote. \"Due to profit-driven, fossil-fueled global hearing, it is now a part of death.\"\n\nAt the close of this year's pilgrimage, a total of 1,081 people were reported dead as of Thursday, according to an Agence France-Presse tally based on official statements or diplomats' reports. The majority -- 658 -- were from Egypt, and a Saudi diplomat told AFP that the heat was the primary cause of death.\n\n\"Ambulances were moving nonstop, collecting people left and right,\" pilgrim Ahmad Bahaa, a 37-year-old Egyptian engineer who works in Saudi Arabia, told The Washington Post. \"People were sleeping on the sidewalks... I saw someone right in front of our tent who collapsed and could not even move.\"\n\nIncluding Egypt, deaths were reported from around 10 countries, according to AFP: They included 183 from Indonesia, 58 from Pakistan, as well as fatalities from Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan, and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. Other countries including Jordan and Tunisia have said some of their citizens died because of high heat, The Associated Press reported. Saudi authorities reported more than 2,700 \"heat exhaustion\" cases on Sunday, according to AFP.\n\nDue in part to the large numbers of people who attend, the Hajj can be dangerous even under ideal climactic conditions. In 2015, more than 2,400 people died in a stampede during the \"Rami al-Jamarat,\" or stoning of the devil, ritual in Mina, near Mecca. In total, more than 9,000 people have died at mass religious gatherings in the past 119 years, and more than 5,000 of those deaths were at the Hajj. Last year, the death toll was more than 300, according to AFP.\n\nHowever, as public safety expert Milad Haghani wrote in The Conversation, \"while most Hajj fatalities have been due to crowd crushes and stampedes, a new threat has emerged: extreme climate.\"\n\nSaudi Arabia has taken steps to protect pilgrims from extreme temperatures, such as informing pilgrims about heat risks, setting up field hospitals, and installing misting systems and portable water stations.\n\n\"Yet the extreme heat proved overwhelming,\" Haghani noted, \"indicating more needs to be done.\"\n\nThere are other factors that exacerbate risk: Unregistered pilgrims, who attend unofficially to avoid paying for expensive permits, cannot enter air-conditioned areas set up for registered visitors, as AFP noted; 630 of the 658 Egyptians reported dead were unregistered, as were more than half of the overall death toll. Another factor is that many pilgrims attend the Hajj when they are older and have saved up the money to go, making them more vulnerable to heat-related complications.\n\n\"There has been a noted uptick in heat-related deaths as global warming gets worse but I have never heard of anything like what has happened over the Hajj in Saudi Arabia this year,\" journalist S\u00e9amus Malekafzali posted on social media. \"Over 1,000 people have died over the course of a week, almost all from heatstroke.\"\n\n\"There is already significant infrastructure to deal with the Gulf Arab heat around Mecca and Medina, but I don't know if there is a way to outpace the massive amounts of heat and humidity that is going to beset southwestern Saudi Arabia,\" Malekafzali continued. \"Even in December, it can get above 100\u00b0F.\"\n\nJeff Goodell, author of the book The Heat Will Kill You First, wrote on social media in response to the deaths that \"our world was built for a climate that no longer exists.\"\n\nThe situation is likely to get worse as the burning of fossil fuels continues to push global temperatures higher. The Post analysis finding that Mecca would be dangerous in the sun for more than half the year by 2050 also found it would see 54 days dangerous even in the shade.\n\n\"Let that sink in. Fossil fuels will have caused the holiest city in Islam to be virtually uninhabitable for 50% of the year,\" Climate Defiance wrote.\n\nA Saudi study published in March found that dry-bulb temperatures in Mecca had risen by 0.4\u00b0C per decade and wet-bulb (which incorporates humidity) by 2\u00b0C. A 2019 study by Massachusetts Institute of Technology researchers concluded that, even with emissions cuts, the Hajj would take place while temperatures surpassed the \"extreme danger\" limit between 2047 and 2052 and again between 2079 and 2086.\n\n\"Climate change does not discriminate by religion, ethnicity, nationality,\" Marina Romanello, the executive director of The Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change, wrote on social media. \"Hundreds died in the pilgrimage to Mecca, practicing their sacred ritual, as temperatures rise to nearly 50\u00b0C [122\u00b0F]. Unless we take urgent action, this will be just the beginning.\"\n\nClimate Defiance concluded: \"This loss of life is a tragedy and sadly it's also a harbinger of what is to come. The pilgrims who perished are there canary in the coal mine. We must mourn their deaths, but we must also ACT. It is not too late but time is running out. This is not a drill. This is a fire.\"", "source": {"uri": "therussophile.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "TheRussophiles"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajj", "type": "wiki", to address Egyptian Hajj deaths", "body": "CAIRO - 20 June 2024: President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi has ordered establishing a crisis cell led by Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly to address the deaths of Egyptian pilgrims during this Hajj season, 1445 AH.\n\nAs per the president's directives, the crisis cell will closely monitor and manage the situation regarding the deceased pilgrims, the Egyptian Presidency said in a statement.\n\nThe Egyptian Presidency extends its deepest condolences and sympathies to the families of the victims and reaffirms the government's commitment to providing necessary support during this unfortunate event.\n\nSisi emphasized the immediate need for coordination with Saudi authorities to facilitate the repatriation of the deceased and ensure all necessary arrangements are made in this regard.\n\nScores missing, dead\n\nAround 56,000 Egyptians embarked on the Hajj pilgrimage this year, which spanned over the past week.\n\nWhile pilgrims have started returning to Egypt, a significant number of them are now reported missing, with many tragically losing their lives due to the extreme heat.\n\nTemperatures in Makkah hovered around a staggering 50 degrees Celsius, as reported by Saudi Arabia's National Center for Meteorology (NCM).\n\nAccording to an Arab diplomat who spoke to Agence France-Presse (AFP), this year's Hajj season has been marred by the deaths of at least 600 Egyptian pilgrims, primarily due to the extremely high temperatures.\n\nThis brings the total deaths among pilgrims this year to more than 900, according to an AFP tally.\n\nThe diplomat stated that Egyptian officials in the Kingdom has received 1,400 reports of missing pilgrims.\n\nOn Thursday, Cairo announced the establishment of consulate field teams to conduct visits to hospitals in Makkah and the holy sites to search for missing Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nAdditionally, a consular mission has been stationed at the East Arafat Hospital and the Muaisem medical complex around the clock, the Egyptian Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims\n\nHowever, the ministry said that unregistered Egyptian pilgrims, available in pilgrims this season has played a substantial role in the high death toll among Egyptians.\n\nThe influx of unregistered pilgrims has resulted in a breakdown of service provision.\n\nAn Egyptian official overseeing the country's Hajj mission stated, \"The presence of irregular pilgrims created immense chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, leading to a collapse in the services provided.\"\n\nHe further explained that the pilgrims were deprived of essential necessities such as food, water, and adequate shelter, which resulted in fatalities due to the extreme heat.", {"uri": "8186891606", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:12:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:12:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:12:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/1/133036/Egypt-facilitates-return-of-Hajj-pilgrims-repatriation-of-deceased-ones", "title": "Egypt facilitates return of Hajj pilgrims, repatriation of deceased ones", "body": "CAIRO - 20 June 2024: Cairo is coordinating the safe return of Egyptian Hajj pilgrims and the repatriation of the deceased individuals whose families wish to bury them in Egypt.\n\nIn a statement on Wednesday, the Ministry of Emigration announced that the Egyptian consulate in Jeddah has established a 24/7 operations room to receive phone calls from citizens who have lost contact with their relatives in Makkah, Madinah, and the holy sites.\n\nThe operations room can be reached at (00966565702002).\n\nThe Ministry of Foreign Affairs has also provided dedicated phone numbers for citizens to report missing Hajj pilgrims and request the repatriation of deceased pilgrims.\n\nAccording to diplomats who spoke to Agence France-Presse (AFP) on Tuesday, this year's Hajj season has been marred by the deaths of at least 550 pilgrims, including 323 Egyptians, primarily due to the extremely high temperatures.\n\nThe bodies of the deceased are currently being held at the hospital morgue in Makkah.\n\nThe Hajj pilgrimage, which took place in the year 1445 AH, attracted nearly 2 million pilgrims who endured scorching heat.\n\nOn Monday, temperatures in Makkah reached a staggering 52 degrees Celsius, as reported by Saudi Arabia's National Center for Meteorology (NCM).\n\nOne of the diplomats interviewed by AFP emphasized that the significant presence of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims this season has played a substantial role in the high death toll among Egyptians.\n\nThe influx of unregistered pilgrims has resulted in a breakdown of service provision.\n\nAn Egyptian official overseeing the country's Hajj mission stated, \"The presence of irregular pilgrims created immense chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, leading to a collapse in the services provided.\"\n\nHe further explained that the pilgrims were deprived of essential necessities such as food, water, and adequate shelter, which resulted in {"uri": "8186368059", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "05:21:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T05:21:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T05:20:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2472538/families-plead-for-news-as-hajj-heatwave-claims-over-900-lives", "title": "Families plead for news as hajj heatwave claims over 900 lives", "body": "Deaths among Egyptians had risen to at least 600, with the total reported deaths now at 922\n\nFamily and friends searched desperately for missing Hajj pilgrims on Wednesday, as the death toll from the pilgrimage, held in extreme heat, surpassed 900.\n\nTemperatures in Mecca reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 Fahrenheit) on Monday, causing widespread fatalities among the 1.8 million participants, many of whom were elderly and frail.\n\nAn Arab diplomat reported that deaths among Egyptians had risen to at least 600, with the total reported deaths now at 922. Egyptian officials in Saudi Arabia have received 1,400 reports of missing pilgrims.\n\nA second Arab diplomat reported that Jordanian officials were searching for 20 missing pilgrims, while 80 initially reported missing were found in hospitals. An Asian diplomat mentioned around 68 dead from India, with more still missing.\n\nOne missing pilgrim Mabrouka bint Salem Shushana from Tunisia was unregistered and lacked access to air-conditioned facilities. Her husband, Mohammed, has been searching hospitals with no success.\n\n\"She's an old lady, tired and feeling extremely hot with no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I searched all the hospitals but still have no clue about her whereabouts.\"\n\nSocial media platforms like Facebook have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information. Among those searching are family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt, begging me to post on Facebook to help track her or find her,\" said a family friend in Saudi Arabia, who spoke anonymously to avoid conflict with authorities. \"The good news is that she's not on the list of the dead, giving us hope she's still alive.\"\n\nHajj has coincided with the Saudi summer in recent years, exacerbating the heat risks. Fatalities have been confirmed in several countries, including Jordan, Indonesia, and Iran.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not released official death figures but reported over 2,700 cases of heat exhaustion. Many pilgrims attempt the Hajj through unofficial channels to avoid costly permits, a trend that has increased since the introduction of a general tourism visa in 2019.\n\nEven those with official permits, like 70-year-old Houria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif from Egypt, are at risk; she has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAuthorities continue to search for the missing, hoping to locate survivors amid {"uri": "8187526232", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:16:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:16:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:15:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2024/06/heat-old-age-heart-conditions-blamed-over-1000-deaths-hajj", "title": "Heat, old age, heart conditions blamed for over 1,000 deaths at Hajj", "body": "Muslim pilgrims circle the Kaaba, Islam's holiest shrine, in the holy city of Mecca on June 18, 2024, at the end of the annual Hajj pilgrimage. - AFP via Getty Images\n\nMore than 1,000 deaths have been reported from the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as of Thursday, with extreme heat as high as 125 degrees Fahrenheit (52 Celsius) being a major culprit and as impacts of climate change challenge the region.\n\nWhat we know: Agence France-Presse reported on Thursday that around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths at the annual Islamic pilgrimage. More than half of those who died were unregistered pilgrims, according to the outlet. Reuters reported on Wednesday that at least 562 people have died, with 307 of the deaths coming from Egypt alone.\n\nThe Hajj is an annual pilgrimage by Muslims to Mecca, Mount Arafat and other holy sites in Saudi Arabia. Pilgrims are required to register with Saudi authorities, though some go unofficially.\n\nThis year's Hajj has taken place in extreme heat, with temperatures reportedly reaching 125 degrees Fahrenheit (52 Celsius) at Mecca's grand mosque this week. The more than 1,000 deaths is four times higher than the at least 240 who died in 2023.\n\nMany of the deaths have been linked to the heat. The Jordanian Foreign Ministry said in a statement on Tuesday that 41 citizens on the pilgrimage had died due to sunstroke.\n\nJordan's state broadcaster Al-Mamlaka reported on Wednesday that Jordanian pilgrims who were not part of the country's official delegation had to walk in the sun to reach Arafat, causing death and injury.\n\nA Kurdistan Regional Government official told the Iraqi Kurdish news outlet Rudaw on Tuesday that 15 people from the region died in relation to the heat wave during the Hajj. KRG spokesperson Karwan Stoni told AFP on Monday that heat and heart attacks were the reasons for the deaths, adding that 12 of the dead did not have official Hajj permits and therefore could not access air-conditioned areas.\n\nSaudi officials have not commented on the number of deaths, but have repeatedly urged pilgrims to follow safety precautions such as avoiding direct sun exposure, using umbrellas and staying hydrated. Saudi authorities said last Saturday that they had cleared more than 300,000 unregistered pilgrims from Mecca ahead of the Hajj, according to the official Saudi Press Agency.\n\nIran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported on Tuesday that 11 Iranians died during the Hajj, mostly due to heat stroke and old age.\n\nTunisia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a Tuesday statement that 35 Tunisians had died during the event. Of those who perished, 30 traveled to the kingdom on tourism or visas for the Umrah, or visits to Mecca outside of the designated Hajj period.\n\nPakistan's Ministry of Religious Affairs said on Wednesday that at least 35 Pakistanis had died during the Hajj. The ministry did not list specific causes of death, but noted the extreme heat in the area, according to reports in the country.\n\nMalaysia's Religion Minister Datuk Mohd Na'im Mokhtar said on Thursday that 14 citizens died, mostly due to heart disease, pneumonia and blood infection, Malaysian media reported.\n\nOther deaths were confirmed by the governments of India, Senegal and Sudan, according to AFP.\n\nWhy it matters: Climate change is hitting the Middle East and North Africa on a wide scale this summer. Kuwaiti authorities announced temporary power cuts on Wednesday, citing struggles to meet demand during peak hours.\n\nPeople in the region rely on power for cooling systems during the summer heat. Power supplies are relatively stable in the Gulf, but public electricity is only available for part of the day in Lebanon, Iraq, Syria and other parts of the region, prompting those who can afford it to use fuel-powered generators.\n\nAlgeria has experienced protests this month over water shortages. The North African country's water supply has been diminished by intense heat and a lack of rainfall.", "source": {"uri": "al-monitor.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Al-Monitor"}, "authors": [], She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said. \"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now, I don't have a clue.\"\n\nHe is far from the only one desperate for information.\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThe searchers include family and friends of Egyptian pilgrim Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, unaccounted for since June 15.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he did not want to anger the Saudi authorities.\n\n\"The good news is that until now we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"", "source": {"uri": "straitstimes.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8187651843", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:11:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:11:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:10:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://truthout.org/articles/more-than-1000-perish-during-hajj-with-most-deaths-attributed-to-extreme-heat/", "title": "More Than 1,000 Perish During Hajj, With Most Deaths Attributed to Extreme Heat", "body": "Climate advocates warned that urgent action on fossil fuels is needed to avoid more deaths.\n\nMore than 1,000 people participating in the Hajj to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, have died as of Thursday as temperatures in the holy city reached 125\u00b0F at the Grand Mosque.\n\nThe tragedy serves as an example of how the climate crisis is making mass gatherings more dangerous, especially in warmer parts of the world. Saudi Arabia is heating 50% faster than the rest of the Northern Hemisphere, and by 2050, The Washington Post and Carbon Plan estimated that temperatures would rise high enough in Mecca to make it dangerous to be in the sun for 182 days a year.\n\n\"Words fail. Words fail,\" the activist group Climate Defiance wrote on social media in response to the deaths.\n\n\"Stop it with your vapid odes to incrementalism. Stop it with your 2050 pledges,\" the group added. \"Humanity is barreling to the brink. Open your eyes!\"\n\n\"For so many, religious rituals are a sacred and central part of their identities,\" the group continued. \"Now merely practicing a faith proves a literal death sentence.\"\n\nMecca is the holiest city in the Islamic religious tradition, and making the Hajj, or pilgrimage, there is one of Islam's Five Pillars. The Hajj always draws hundreds of thousands of people from all over the world, with more than 1.8 million registered pilgrims attending this year. The timing depends on the Islamic calendar, which follows a lunar cycle. In 2024, it fell between June 14 and June 19 in the Gregorian calendar, coinciding with Saudi Arabia's hotter period.\n\n\"The Hajj is considered one of the Five Pillars of Islam, along with belief in Allah, prayer, fasting, and charity. It is intended to be a sacred part of life,\" Climate Defiance wrote. \"Due to profit-driven, fossil-fueled global hearing, it is now a part of death.\"\n\nAt the close of this year's pilgrimage, a total of 1,081 people were reported dead as of Thursday, according to an Agence France-Presse tally based on official statements or diplomats' reports. The majority -- 658 -- were from Egypt, and a Saudi diplomat told AFP that the heat was the primary cause of death.\n\n\"Ambulances were moving nonstop, collecting people left and right,\" pilgrim Ahmad Bahaa, a 37-year-old Egyptian engineer who works in Saudi Arabia, told The Washington Post. \"People were sleeping on the sidewalks... I saw someone right in front of our tent who collapsed and could not even move.\"\n\nIncluding Egypt, deaths were reported from around 10 countries, according to AFP: They included 183 from Indonesia, 58 from Pakistan, as well as fatalities from Malaysia, India, Jordan, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia, Sudan, and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region. Other countries including Jordan and Tunisia have said some of their citizens died because of high heat, The Associated Press reported. Saudi authorities reported more than 2,700 \"heat exhaustion\" cases on Sunday, according to AFP.\n\nDue in part to the large numbers of people who attend, the Hajj can be dangerous even under ideal climactic conditions. In 2015, more than 2,400 people died in a stampede during the \"Rami al-Jamarat,\" or stoning of the devil, ritual in Mina, near Mecca. In total, more than 9,000 people have died at mass religious gatherings in the past 119 years, and more than 5,000 of those deaths were at the Hajj. Last year, the death toll was more than 300, according to AFP.\n\nHowever, as public safety expert Milad Haghani wrote in The Conversation, \"while most Hajj fatalities have been due to crowd crushes and stampedes, a new threat has emerged: extreme climate.\"\n\nSaudi Arabia has taken steps to protect pilgrims from extreme temperatures, such as informing pilgrims about heat risks, setting up field hospitals, and installing misting systems and portable water stations.\n\n\"Yet the extreme heat proved overwhelming,\" Haghani noted, \"indicating more needs to be done.\"\n\nThere are other factors that exacerbate risk: Unregistered pilgrims, who attend unofficially to avoid paying for expensive permits, cannot enter air-conditioned areas set up for registered visitors, as AFP noted; 630 of the 658 Egyptians reported dead were unregistered, as were more than half of the overall death toll. Another factor is that many pilgrims attend the Hajj when they are older and have saved up the money to go, making them more vulnerable to heat-related complications.\n\n\"There has been a noted uptick in heat-related deaths as global warming gets worse but I have never heard of anything like what has happened over the Hajj in Saudi Arabia this year,\" journalist S\u00e9amus Malekafzali posted on social media. \"Over 1,000 people have died over the course of a week, almost all from heatstroke.\"\n\n\"There is already significant infrastructure to deal with the Gulf Arab heat around Mecca and Medina, but I don't know if there is a way to outpace the massive amounts of heat and humidity that is going to beset southwestern Saudi Arabia,\" Malekafzali continued. \"Even in December, it can get above 100\u00b0F.\"\n\nJeff Goodell, author of the book The Heat Will Kill You First, wrote on social media in response to the deaths that \"our world was built for a climate that no longer exists.\"\n\nThe situation is likely to get worse as the burning of fossil fuels continues to push global temperatures higher. The Post analysis finding that Mecca would be dangerous in the sun for more than half the year by 2050 also found it would see 54 days dangerous even in the shade.\n\n\"Let that sink in. Fossil fuels will have caused the holiest city in Islam to be virtually uninhabitable for 50% of the year,\" Climate Defiance wrote.\n\nA Saudi study published in March found that dry-bulb temperatures in Mecca had risen by 0.4\u00b0C per decade and wet-bulb (which incorporates humidity) by 2\u00b0C. A 2019 study by Massachusetts Institute of Technology researchers concluded that, even with emissions cuts, the Hajj would take place while temperatures surpassed the \"extreme danger\" limit between 2047 and 2052 and again between 2079 and 2086.\n\n\"Climate change does not discriminate by religion, ethnicity, nationality,\" Marina Romanello, the executive director of The Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change, wrote on social media. \"Hundreds died in the pilgrimage to Mecca, practicing their sacred ritual, as temperatures rise to nearly 50\u00b0C [122\u00b0F]. Unless we take urgent action, this will be just the beginning.\"\n\nClimate Defiance concluded: \"This loss of life is a tragedy and sadly it's also a harbinger of what is to come. The pilgrims who perished are there canary in the coal mine. We must mourn their deaths, but we must also ACT. It is not too late but time is running out. This is not a drill. This is a fire.\"", "source": {"uri": "truthout.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Truthout"}, "authors": [{"uri": "olivia_rosane@truthout.org", "name": "Olivia Rosane", "type": "author", "isAgency": Some are because of natural causes and we had many old-age pilgrims. And some are due to the weather conditions, that's what we assume.\"\n\nThe death toll has risen from 550 which was notified by Saudi officials on Wednesday.\n\nFatalities have also been confirmed by Indonesia, Iran, Senegal, Tunisia and Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan region, though in many cases authorities have not specified the cause.\n\nThe highest number of casualties came from Egypt.\n\nThe diplomat who confirmed the Indian fatalities said there were also some Indian pilgrims missing, but he declined to provide an exact number.\n\n\"This happens every year&mldr; We can't say that it is abnormally high this year,\" he said.\n\n\"It's somewhat similar to last year but we will know more in the coming days.\"\n\nTemperatures in the Muslim pilgrim city touched 51.8 degrees Celcius on Monday, according to the National Center for Meteorology.\n\nMost of the rituals of the Hajj, an annual pilgrimage that Muslims are obligated to make at least once in their lifetime, are held outside under the direct sun. Pilgrims are often exposed to extreme heat as they walk around the Kaaba in circles.\n\nThe Hajj has been facing the wrath of climate change recently but that is not stopping pilgrims from visiting the holy site. Around 1.8 million pilgrims took part in the hajj this year, 1.6 million of them from abroad, according to Saudi authorities.\n\nStudies suggest that increasing humidity and temperatures pose a threat to the health of pilgrims. Researchers from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles predict that the annual pilgrimage could turn more dangerous from 2047 to 2052 and from 2079 to 2086 during the hottest months of the year.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajj", {"uri": "8186026431", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:35:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:35:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:33:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.trtworld.com/middle-east/unbearable-heat-in-saudi-arabia-claims-900-lives-at-hajj-18175057", "title": "Unbearable heat in Saudi Arabia claims 900+ lives at Hajj", "body": "Deaths among Egyptians alone jump to at least 600, bringing total death toll from scorching heat during annual Islamic pilgrimage to 922.\n\nDeath toll at the annual Hajj pilgrimage, which were carried out in scorching heat in Saudi Arabia, has surged past 900.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told the AFP news agency on Wednesday that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to \"at least 600\" from more than 300 a day earlier, mostly from the unforgiving heat.\n\nThat figure brought the total reported dead so far to 922, according to an AFP tally of figures released by various countries.\n\nThe diplomat later added that Egyptian officials in Saudi Arabia had received \"1,400 reports of missing pilgrims\", including the 600 dead.\n\nMabrouka bint Salem Shushana of Tunisia, in her early 70s, has been missing since the climax of the pilgrimage on Saturday at Mount Arafat, her husband Mohammed told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nBecause she was unregistered and did not have an official Hajj permit, she was unable to access air-conditioned facilities that allow pilgrims to cool down, he said.\n\n\"She's an old lady. She was tired. She was feeling so hot, and she had no place to sleep,\" he said.\n\n\"I looked for her in all the hospitals. Until now, I don't have a clue.\"\n\nFacebook and other social media networks have been flooded with pictures of the missing and requests for information.\n\nThose searching for news include family and friends of Ghada Mahmoud Ahmed Dawood, an Egyptian pilgrim unaccounted for since Saturday.\n\n\"I received a call from her daughter in Egypt begging me to put any post on Facebook that can help track her or find her,\" said one family friend based in Saudi Arabia.\n\n\"The good news is that until now, we did not find her on the list of the dead people, which gives us hope she is still alive.\"\n\nHouria Ahmad Abdallah Sharif, a 70-year-old Egyptian pilgrim, has been missing since Saturday.\n\nAfter praying on Mount Arafat, she told a friend she wanted to go to a public bathroom to clean her abaya, but she never came back.", "source": {"uri": "trtworld.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TRT World"}, "authors": [{"uri": "noureldein_ghanem@trtworld.com", "name": "Noureldein
